PARA.TAB: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Stephen Martin) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Televising of the House of Representatives, Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)The proposed conditions for broadcasters appended to the report dated October 1993 of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on the Televising of the House of Representatives on the review of the arrangements for the televising of the House of Representatives, be amended—
(a)by omitting condition 4 (Withdrawn Remarks) and substituting the following condition:
"4.Withdrawn Remarks

Remarks in respect of which a Member claims misrepresentation or otherwise seeks withdrawal, and which are subsequently ordered to be withdrawn, or are voluntarily withdrawn, are not to be rebroadcast.";
(b)by inserting after condition 4 the following condition:
"4A.Points of order
Points of order, and matters claimed to be points of order, are not to be rebroadcast."; and
(c)by inserting after condition 5 the following condition:
"6.Penalties
Non-compliance with the guidelines listed above may incur the following penalties for the stations involved:
(i)first breach—access to the broadcast service withdrawn for three sitting days;
(ii)second breach—access to the broadcast service withdrawn for six sitting days;
(iii)such other penalty as is agreed by the Standing Committee on the Televising of the House of Representatives.
Breaches of the guidelines shall be considered and determined by the Standing Committee on the Televising of the House of Representatives.".
(2)These amendments to the conditions have immediate effect.

This motion arises out of a report from the House of Representatives Standing Committee on the Televising of the House of Representatives that you, Mr Speaker, tabled yesterday on the review of the arrangements for the televising of the House Representatives. Mr Speaker, you quite correctly, in the terms in which that committee had been set up, stated at the conclusion of your remarks that these guidelines having been arrived at were therefore automatically implemented. I think that what you said was correct.

PARA.TAB: Quite clearly, that was a most undesirable oversight of the House when we established and put the committee in place some years ago. No committee operating on behalf of this chamber and set up to discuss the proceedings of this chamber ought, on major issues, be empowered to change practice substantially without reference back to the chamber. I think giving the committee that authority is an oversight on our part. Parties are not permitted as a result of that to have a broader discussion within their organisations about the changes of practice that a committee brings down, unless we do something similar to that which is being done by the government today by taking sections of that report and restoring the status quo ante to allow that broader discussion, at least within our own ranks—it is up to the opposition to decide what to do in its ranks—of the issues raised in the committee's report. Only two sections of the committee's report have been picked up in this way in this motion.

There were a series of other suggestions about how the camera work ought to be done in association with the broadcasting of parliament. They are not incorporated in this motion. What is incorporated are two specific areas which were the subject of some deliberation at the time this committee was set up. A great deal of thought was put into the regulations associated with them at that time. The regulations go to the way in which points of order and withdrawn remarks are rebroadcast. It is taken as read that in any direct broadcast of proceedings it will be absolutely impossible for us to put in place any processes which change the way in which the live performance is broadcast over the airwaves. In practical terms, this goes to the treatment of broadcasts in reproduction, in news services and in other programs, and in the production of a particular parliamentary broadcast when it is rebroadcast later in the evening.

There are very sound reasons why we originally chose to go down the road we did when we set in place these rules associated with the way in which points of order and other material might be broadcast. It is not sufficient to say that powers exist in other sections of the media—the print media, for example—to repeat what is said in this place in print form in any way, shape or form they see fit. I think it is true that the print media are not as fully aware of the privilege covering this place as they ought to be.

This would apply equally to the rebroadcast on television of parliamentary materials as it does to the print media. For example, I think the press has missed the point of a ruling given a very long time ago by Speaker Snedden about the qualified nature of privilege on the repeating of materials in this chamber. I remember Speaker Snedden being very concerned about a habit developing in the chamber of people making adjournment speeches in which they heavily libelled others and then distributing or shunting those adjournment speeches around their electorates in order to deal with their enemies believing that they were under some form of parliamentary privilege. Speaker Snedden pointed out at that time that privilege in this place is absolute, but privilege in the way in which it is reported goes to context and context actually requires virtually the re-presentation of the entirety of a debate before that qualified privilege can be certain to be upheld in any subsequent action for libel.

That applies to the print media, but there is a difference between the televised and print media. The televised media brings into stark focus in a way no other media do the presentation of any issue in this chamber. It provides an opportunity to focus on a very limited area and present it in such a way that people may be damaged way beyond the capacity of a newspaper report or anything like it to do that damage.

When we originally looked at this matter we decided, for a very sound reason, that the most effective way of handling what amounts to the reportrayal of disorderly conduct in this place—that is, the raising of bogus points of order and, more particularly and more importantly than that, the delivery of remarks which are required by parliamentary processes to be subsequently withdrawn—was to place limitations on the ways in which that might be rebroadcast. This was done knowing that, when initially broadcast, those withdrawals and points of order would be placed in the context of the totality of the presentation of either that period of debate or, in practical terms, question time—which is all that people are really interested in broadcasting live—whereas when subsequently bits and pieces were extracted from question time that context could never be provided in the way in which that rebroadcasting was handled.

There is no question that points of order and abuse in this place which produce withdrawal are done for substantial political effect, not for the opportunity to actually correct somebody's behaviour under the standing orders. Nobody who sits in this place in question time can comprehend anything other than that bogus points of order are repeatedly raised and that no-one can do anything other than to acknowledge that, in the robust exchange here, we libel each other and others outside the parliament with great ferocity and that the withdrawal that results from that in no way requires apology or alternative explanation. Under the standing orders it is possible to get away with a muttered, `I withdraw', and that is the end of the matter.

The notion that one gets balance by the presentation of a remark which obliges withdrawal and then the subsequent withdrawal is a nonsense. Of course it does not. Basically what stands is the piece of abuse and the subsequent light-hearted retraction of it. The standing orders do not require apology and do not permit an opportunity for a person slated in this chamber to stand up and say, `You ought not to have called me that because these things apply and you were erroneous in your assumptions as to the detail of my character'.

From our point of view these rules have been absolutely fundamental as far as basic, decent practice in this chamber is concerned. Whilst others in the chamber may differ, in his presentation to the committee the clerk was definitely of that point of view. Concerning withdrawn remarks, paragraph 2.25 of the committee's report says:

SPEECH.PARA: By contrast the Clerk of House of the Representatives stated that he would not favour the lifting of the prohibition on the televising of withdrawn remarks. He referred to a hypothetical situation where a Member, just before an election, could make an outrageous statement which could have serious political consequences. The Member could be ordered to withdraw the remark, but if the rebroadcast of withdrawn remarks was permitted, it would allow the remark to be rebroadcast.

There is no question about that. We all know the name of the game here. The situation to which the clerk referred is not a hypothetical situation, it is in fact our daily fare. There is not a question time that goes past when remarks on either side of the chamber are not required to be withdrawn. There is not a question time that goes past when a bogus standing order is not put forward.

PARA.TAB: Basically, a change of regulations in this area would permit acts of ratbaggery to be salient acts and would encourage disorderly conduct in this place. The clerk was right to warn about the potential for disorderly conduct being encouraged by remarks like this being put forward. No doubt there are some in the House who would look forward to an opportunity to slander the names of their colleagues and then make a bogus withdrawal. They would be cheerful about the fact that subsequently their remarks would be carried on evening news services. No doubt a number of honourable members in this place would delight at that prospect. It would be a sad day for the processes of this chamber if a majority of honourable members thought that way.

The government is moving these propositions to effectively recommit this issue for further consideration by the parties. It gives us a chance to discuss the committee report rather than have it automatically adopted in this chamber. We can then see the direction we ought to take. The government's motion also does one other thing: it restores the penalties associated with the initial requirements on the rebroadcasting of remarks.

Generally in this area—and others—the committee has sought the capacity to be unbound by any set of guidelines as to how penalties might be applied. That is not appropriate. If penalties are to be provided in the area of broadcast activities, those penalties ought to be capable of being the subject of discussion in this place and not just be automatically accepted. I believe that is an essential protection for the committee. There will always be members who will have views as to how those requirements ought to be enforced when there is a transgression of the rules associated with broadcasting. Almost invariably, those views will be at variance, at least amongst some, with whatever decision the committee arrives at. In those circumstances, it is a protection for the committee if it knows it has in place a set of requirements that have been discussed in this chamber. Indeed, that was the case prior to the presentation of this report.

I do not think it is in the interests of anyone in this House to produce a set of circumstances that reward repeated disorderly behaviour. There has been enough rhetoric on both sides of this chamber—observed more in the breach than in the undertaking—about lifting standards and ensuring that the ways in which we treat each other, and people external to this place, are in accordance with what would be accepted as reasonable practice on the doorstep of any household that any of us might approach when we are going around canvassing at election time.

There is no question that in the heat of discussion and debate this principle is not very easy to observe. In the cold light of day, when we are out there speaking about how we think of ourselves and what we think is significant in the way in which this chamber ought to conduct itself, we state things which are totally at variance with the way in which—within an hour or so—we are in fact operating in this place. Because we are incapable of meeting our own high standards when we make those presentations outside this chamber, we should not find ourselves rewarded when we stoop into the gutter. We would be rewarded if, in a rebroadcast of proceedings, people were capable of ignoring the entirety of what went on in question time to focus on a set of remarks—invariably libellous and invariably not germane to any issue of very serious import to this country, and which may not necessarily be offhand but studied—used to ridicule, destroy, or whatever, members either inside or outside this place. It has to be remembered that the withdrawal of remarks often protects people outside this chamber as well as those inside this chamber.

When we look at the way in which parliamentary proceedings have been rebroadcast, I do not think anyone can reasonably argue that the flavour and the content of any set of remarks or considerations in this chamber have not had reasonable opportunity for adequate coverage. We might disagree with it, but we have to acknowledge that often there is a hell of a lot more excitement and interest in the portrayal of this place when honourable members, who are not careful of the House's reputation, go a step further and move outside, or skirt around, the issues of policy and stoop to personal abuse. That personal abuse is then focused upon.

It is not sufficient to get up in this chamber and argue—as indeed it is argued in this report—that the print media can do it, that radio can do it, so why is television uniquely set aside for this treatment? All I can say is that those who would seriously argue that point have never been involved in a political campaign. Anyone can go to a set of surveys done by any advertising agency; anyone can look at the charts of charges that apply to advertising in any of the various sections of the media and know why television is different from any other element of portrayal of debate in this place. By a quantitative order of magnitude it is so massively more effective in getting a point into the lounge room of the average Australian that that quantitative difference takes on a qualitative character.

Any serious student of the media and its role in politics could not conceivably, truthfully, come to any other conclusion. The very fact that this has been the focal point of interest for some considerable period of time is more than ample evidence of the fact that that is the case. If nothing else, the simple commonsense and experience of people in this chamber would be a demonstration of it. To get up and advocate the alternative here, to encourage this process or to argue that in some way or other it effectively meets the democratic principle, is simply a cover for a position aimed at rewarding bastardry in this place. There is no question about that. It is simply a cover for an opportunity to reward a piece of ratbaggery. When we look at the definitions of terms in the report, we see that it is simply that: a piece of ratbaggery.

Ratbaggery, by definition, must be withdrawn. The proposition here is that what, by definition, must be withdrawn can be rebroadcast unfettered—unfettered except for the fact that the withdrawal is obliged to be rebroadcast also. But everybody here knows very well how withdrawals take place. Many people in this chamber, including me, have been obligated to make a withdrawal. After a member has libelled someone, a simple statement here saying, `I withdraw', on the Speaker's instructions is all that is required. No apology or no alternative explanation from a person so libelled is in any way, shape or form required by the standing orders. That is fine. In the conduct of debate in this chamber it is reasonable that that should be the situation, but it ought not to be the situation that that behaviour be uniquely rewarded.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not surprisingly, the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) was fairly flat and unenthusiastic. I am not the least bit surprised because let there be no doubt that behind this motion lies the long Italian hand of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). Let there be no doubt at all that this is another exercise in prime ministerial hubris. Let there be no doubt that the Prime Minister seeks, through the instrument of the Leader of the House today, to maintain the outrageously lopsided set of procedures that this House operates under. Those procedures disgracefully favour the government. They unreasonably hobble the news networks of this country in their efforts to make a faithful reproduction of not only the answers given by ministers but the cut and thrust and the flow and flavour of question time.

PARA.TAB: The government is using its numbers today at prime ministerial behest to overturn a decision of a committee of this parliament comprising a majority of the government's own members. This attempt by the Leader of the House—which will undoubtedly, with the weight of numbers, be successful—is a sorry reflection on you, Mr Speaker. You were the Chairman of the Standing Committee on the Televising of the House of Representatives. A unanimous decision was made by this committee. The committee comprised you, the honourable member for Brisbane (Mr Bevis), the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Cameron), the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Knott), the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price) and the honourable member for Riverina (Mr Hicks). Unanimously the committee decided that this restriction should go. The Leader of the House has come in here this morning at the behest of the Prime Minister. So full of hubris is the Prime Minister after some of the flattering press he got this morning that he has decided to reverse a decision which went through the committee unanimously and automatically came into effect last night.

TALK.START.PARA: —Across party lines.

—The decision was made across party lines. It was not a coalition recommendation; it was a recommendation from the government's own committee. The Presiding Officer of this House chaired the committee. Only yesterday he announced that the committee's recommendations would take effect immediately. What is the Leader of the House concerned about? Why is he so worried about restoring a modicum of balance, particularly to question time?

PARA.TAB: The Leader of the House used an absolutely extraordinary argument. I want to take apart the one argument he advanced. He said the reason why television should not be allowed to reproduce points of order taken at question time is that many points of order are without substance. He actually used the words that points of order were taken to achieve a political purpose. Can he not accept that most answers given in this parliament, particularly by his Prime Minister, are given to achieve a political purpose?

Apparently it is all right for the Prime Minister to get up at question time to traduce the reputation of the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson), to make all sorts of distorted, outrageous, dishonest, duplicitous, deceptive comments about the motives of the Leader of the Opposition. It is all right for those to be broadcast. The Prime Minister can say terrible things about the Leader of the Opposition that can go through the living rooms of Australia every night but, if the Leader of the Opposition or somebody on our side of the House attempts, by a point of order, to contradict a false allegation, that point of order cannot be reproduced. How can the Leader of the House possibly justify that double standard? He cannot. That is why his argument is a shabby, flimsy argument, and that is why he does not have his heart in this. He knows what I am saying is correct. He knows damn well that, if points of order are abused, so are ministerial answers.

The quintessential abuse of the answer in this parliament is by the person whose hand is behind what the Leader of the House has done this morning, and that is the Prime Minister. Quite a number of people have said to me, `It is amazing Keating let that go through', but of course he has not. He cannot bear to allow a modicum of balance to come into this place. He once again displays that deep authoritarian and intolerant streak which is a hallmark of his approach to parliamentary politics. He likes to believe he is a great parliamentary performer. He is like a boxer in the ring when his opponent has one hand tied behind his back. Government members can be great performers when the rules are made to suit them and to suit them alone.

What more does the government want? Will it close down question time altogether next time? Will it deny us the right to ask questions? It has taken away censure motions; it has taken away matters of public importance. It denies free speech by this decision. Part of free speech is to broadcast what people say. There is not much free speech if people do not know what is said in this place. The networks asked unanimously, as I understand, that it be possible to reproduce points of order. The government is denying that request. Here is this great government that believes in freedom of speech.

The truth is that in the political arena, whenever the rules do not suit the government, it seeks to change those rules to its advantage. The government tried to do it with political advertisements, and the High Court knocked it over. This recommendation slipped through for 24 hours. I happened to talk to a representative of one of the networks only 10 minutes before I heard about this motion. The individual remarked to me how terrific it was and that it was something the networks had wanted for a long time. That sort of jubilation lasted less than 24 hours, until the Prime Minister caught up with events.

In the process of course the government is delivering a snub to its own Speaker. It is a matter for him to decide how he feels about that, and I will say no more. But he was the chairman of this committee. Unanimously committee members decided to confer this normal entitlement on the news networks of Australia. The fact of course is that, when the Prime Minister caught up with this, he went berserk. I understand that he and the Speaker had quite an exchange about it, but that is a matter for the Speaker to handle. I put my case on the merits and on the facts. The Prime Minister wants the right to call people names such as sleaze-bags, scumbags and criminal garbage, and go unrebuked.

TALK.START.PARA: —He can't.

—Yes, he can. Government members want that right. They want the Prime Minister to go on potentially for 45 minutes giving an answer and have the colourful bits run through the living rooms of the nation at night but, if somebody on our side has the temerity to get up and say, `Hang on. That is a bit rough. Under standing orders it is out of order', government members do not want that rebroadcast. Of course they do not. They are interested in running here a show, the rules of which are loaded to assist them. That is what they want, and every single action they take is designed to deny legitimate equality of expression.

PARA.TAB: There is a debate at the present time about the nation's constitutional set-up. The government funds one side of the argument but not the other. It tried to knock off political advertisements because the Labor Party was broke in the lead-up to the last election. The Prime Minister has caught up with this and realises the potential for him to be exposed. Everybody who follows the proceedings of this parliament knows how much the Prime Minister abuses question time. He gives long, politically loaded answers, full of venom, bile and personal abuse.

He wants the unrestricted right to have the colourful parts broadcast into the living rooms of Australia; but if anybody on our side dares to protest, that protest is not allowed—by his edict—to go into those same living rooms. The Leader of the House calls himself a democrat, a believer in equality of speech in this parliament. No wonder he showed a marked lack of enthusiasm for this motion. I cannot believe the Speaker did not run this matter past the Leader of the House before he made his announcement yesterday. I find it very hard to believe that my opposite number in this place did not turn his mind to it before the announcement. I find it very hard to believe that if he had turned his mind to it, he would have done other than—in a fair-minded fashion—come to the conclusion that the Speaker and the rest of the committee were absolutely right; the networks were right; and what I am saying today is right.

When the Prime Minister found out about it, flushed with the heady hubris of yesterday, he thought, `While I am on a roll, I will knock over that mob opposite. I will not allow their points of order to be rebroadcast on the evening news bulletins'. That is what this is all about: bending the rules and behaving in an authoritarian fashion. It is classic old-style New South Wales Labor Party politics: if you have the numbers, use them and hang the principle.

There is a fine principle at stake. The Prime Minister talked yesterday about warming the hearts of the Labor Party for another couple of generations, but people's hearts can be warmed occasionally by a little simple faith in free speech. It is a pretty important thing in this country. Australians may seem pretty laid back about it, but if over a period of time they see one side loading it too heavily in its favour they go a bit feral. Those opposite can push their crude abusive numbers one or two steps too far. This is an example where that is being done.

The committee's proposal—a committee on which there was a majority of Labor Party members—was fundamentally decent and correct. It was not earth shattering; but it was correct. In the name of free speech, if it is all right to rebroadcast prime ministerial abuse in an answer and to broadcast a politically loaded answer to an apparently innocuous question, it ought to be all right to rebroadcast a politically loaded point of order.

Through you, Mr Speaker, does the Leader of the House really believe that one principle applies to the prime ministerial answer but another applies to the point of order? If the politics are out of order in the point of order, why are they not out of order in the answer? That is the logical dilemma. Put aside the rhetoric and look at the fairness and logic. That is the government's problem. Not only is this a crude use of numbers, in the worst possible way, but it does not have any logic or reason on its side. The Leader of the House knows that. I know that on occasions he likes to clothe his arguments with logic and reason. On this occasion, all of the logic and reason rests on the side of the decision taken by the committee.

It was always intended that broadcasting the proceedings of question time, which is the most sought after part of the parliamentary day, would reflect not only the substance but also the flavour and the colour. Part of the flavour and colour of question time is the to-and-fro of points of order. Of course many points of order are politically loaded; but so—the Leader of the House must acknowledge in the name of fairness—are most answers. He knows that, I know that, we all know that.

Why is it fair for the Prime Minister to say whatever he may want and have his answers rebroadcast but not fair for the Leader of the Opposition or me to take a point of order and have that point of order—perhaps of equal political content—rebroadcast? That is why what the government is doing is fundamentally illiberal. It is undemocratic and a repudiation of the good sense, impartiality and judgment of its own Speaker. It is a remarkable snub to the Speaker. It is perhaps 18 years since I have seen a government so openly and seriously snub its own Speaker. You know that.

Everything, so it seems, must be sacrificed on the altar of the Prime Minister's overweening hubris. That is what this is all about. The Prime Minister believes, flushed with some favourable headlines this morning, that he can get away with an abuse of the numbers he has in this House. The government does not have merit, logic or decency on its side. The only thing it has on its side is the true weight of numbers. Sometimes that does not succeed in the bar of public opinion. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I support my colleague the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard). This proposal that has been brought forward today by the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) is a gigantic leap; but not a leap forward. It is a leap back into our dark past, a drop back into history, taking us back to the dim dark ages of communication.

PARA.TAB: One of the greatest institutions in the parliament is the committee system which operates not only here in the House of Representatives but also in the Senate. The committee that was set up with you, Mr Speaker, as the head, crossed party lines and looked at every angle and respect of this matter. It came back to the parliament with a unanimous decision—across party lines and represented by every party in this place. It looked at what is a most important issue. When we are elected to this place by our constituents—we are here by their vote and at their discretion—they expect communication. They expect us to put forward their issues in this House and they expect that those issues will be communicated to the government and to other members so that they can see we are representing them. They can hear the proceedings on radio on broadcast days and now, with the advent of television, they are able to see some of them.

What they will be able to see, if this motion by the Leader of the House goes through, will still be the one-sided and edited version of what occurs in this place. If this motion is successful; if the government, by virtue of its numbers, forces it through this House, we will still see a one-sided picture. There will be no response by way of points of order. As my colleague the honourable member for Bennelong said, the opposition sometimes has the opportunity—not always—on matters of procedure to take a point of order and to make a political point on a point of order, just as the Prime Minister or another minister may respond to a question at question time.

But communication is a two-way street. If the proceedings of this House are able only to be broadcast but not televised in greater detail to the people who put us in this place, we will have a breakdown of the communication processes between our constituents and us. All they will see will be a one-sided display of what occurs in this House.

The government is taking us back at least 10 years. Is it frightened about television? Is it frightened that the opposition parties might bring up something which will embarrass it? Is that not what opposition is about—keeping governments accountable?

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what democracy is about.

—That is what democracy is about, as my colleague the honourable member for Aston says. This proposal is about democracy. It is about enabling the people, who elect us to represent their interests, to see the executive government held to account. That is why we have ministers. The ministers have to accept the responsibility that they are accountable not only for the administration of their departments but also to the people of Australia, who want to see that the government of this country is run in a true and democratic way. How can we communicate that to the public without the expansion of the television coverage of this House?

PARA.TAB: When television was first introduced into the House, it was introduced virtually as a trial, as, no doubt, was the broadcasting of parliament when it first commenced in the old Parliament House back in the 1940s. Now the government is trying to overrule a committee which was served by some very fine members who have given their time and thought to this issue. They have looked at the trial over a period and said, `This trial has been successful, but there are still flaws in it because the democratic processes are not being served as well as the public demands they should be. The public has a right to see that the government and the ministers take responsibility and are accountable to the Australian community in accepting that responsibility to administer government in a true, fair and democratic manner'.

It is quite obvious that the Prime Minister has given instructions to the Leader of the House that this matter is not to proceed, despite recommendations from what, as I have said, is one of the great institutions of this parliament, the committee system, which meets across all party boundaries, right across party lines, and tackles the very hard decisions which not only the government but maybe the coalition is having difficulty with. The members of all the parties sit down in this committee framework and reach decisions which they believe are in the true and best interests of the Australian community—not in the interests of members of the House but in the interests of the people we represent out there, who have no voice in this chamber or the Senate chamber.

The difficulty of some of those decisions over the years has been excruciating for some committees. All of the too-hard basket questions end up with parliamentary committees. Members of committees go through the processes, do a lot of soul searching and look at the evidence that has been put before them. There has been some well-documented evidence put forward through the trial processes that we have had with the televising of the parliament. The message has been communicated to members of the public that the members of parliament who represent them are here keeping the government accountable and making sure that it is responsive to what the community wants.

In the proposal brought forward by the Leader of the House this morning what the government is saying is, `We'll show you what we think you should see'. It is another form of censorship. It is interesting to see the Minister for Justice (Mr Kerr) sitting at the table. He surely could not condone this motion, because what the government is saying is, `We will restrict what the public will see coming out of their house of parliament, their parliament which is representing their interests'. How could the Minister for Justice possibly support saying, `We will restrict what you see. We won't let you see anything that the opposition parties might bring up which holds us accountable. We won't show you that. We will show you only the nice things which the government is doing.'?

We cannot possibly tolerate that in Australia because that is the first step of breaking down our democratic processes in this House—to cut off the communication between this parliament and members of the public who elect us. How can the Minister for Justice sit there and support this? He should be over here fighting the government on this issue. He should be supporting the recommendation brought down by the Speaker of this House and the committee, which comprised representatives of all of the parties. The committee took this on board, weighed up the evidence, looked at what has happened in the historical period that we have had television coverage in this House and made a decision that it should proceed a little further; that we should be able to expand this television coverage so that everyone in this House has the opportunity to take a point of order and bring the executive government to account.

If honourable members talk to people in the community, they will find that members of the public think too many decisions are made behind closed doors. They want to see and know what is happening. That is where radio broadcasting has helped. But why not give them the visual coverage so that they can see exactly what is happening in here and what the government is doing? We should make government members accountable, put them on the stand and let them tell the public exactly what is going on. The committee has deliberated long and hard and taken into consideration all of the aspects of providing that communication to people out in the community. After all, they are the people that we represent.

One of the claims of the Leader of the House is that the government is a progressive government. But the government is going to start censoring what comes out of this place. It is going to restrict the ability of the community to see what comes out of the parliament. It is going to prevent the public from seeing how it is held to account. It is all very fine for executive government to make decisions in the ministerial wing and to come in here and, simply because it has the weight of numbers, bulldoze this measure through, knock it out and prevent people from seeing how the government is held to account. It is an absolute disgrace, and it is a black day for this parliament.

It is a black day for the committee system because the government has brought into disrepute the committee system established by this parliament. The recommendation of the committee was supported unanimously. The Leader of the House heard about it in this House yesterday and heard what the Speaker had to say in support of it. Yet suddenly, overnight, the Prime Minister has stepped in and said this will not proceed. He has said to the Australian public, `We are going to censor what you see coming out of the Australian parliament. We will decide what you should see in relation to what occurs in this House'. There is no way that the Australian community should have to tolerate that type of decision making by any government.

I cannot understand why the left wing of the Labor Party is supporting this. Where is the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Howe), the leader of the left wing? He should be over on this side of the House supporting us. He should be on this side of the House this morning supporting freedom, communication and democracy—all of the things that he believes in and stands up for. I will be very interested to see where all of the left wing members of the Labor Party sit when this matter is resolved, because I think that they could not possibly go back to their faction and say, `We supported this. We supported the suppression of information coming out of the Australian parliament, we supported the restriction of information to the people who elected us, and we supported the repression of a flow of information contrary to what had been recommended by a joint parliamentary committee comprising members of both sides of this chamber'. I find it an absolute disgrace. I think that the comments that the honourable member for Bennelong has made have brought the government to account and it should not proceed with this motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLeay The Hon L.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —If one listened to the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) and his colleague the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Reid), one would think that we were repealing the Bill of Rights, withdrawing the Magna Carta and that this was bigger than the Reichstag fire and everything else.
—You are.

—The honourable member for O'Connor says we are. I am glad the honourable member is going to take part in this debate because he is probably one of the better examples of why these provisions should be maintained. We heard the honourable member for Bendigo talk about censorship and how terrible it was that some things that are said here cannot be shown. The honourable member for Bennelong went on at great length about how we should televise, in his words, politically loaded points of order.

PARA.TAB: I say to the honourable member for Bennelong and the honourable member for Bendigo that they should have looked at the standing orders before they made those rather outrageous and silly statements. The standing orders of this place provide specifically that one cannot make remarks that reflect on another member. But the honourable member for Bennelong and the honourable member for Bendigo not only want to be able to flout that; they want to be able to do that and get a run on the television.

As the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley), the honourable member for Bennelong and the honourable member for Bendigo have said, this is an argument about what we will televise and what we will not televise. Why is there great interest in televising? It is because television is a most powerful medium. It is the most powerful medium that there is. It is also the medium that is most susceptible to stunts. Television does not go in for editorialising. Television does not give one the whole story. Television is made up of short grabs. The 6 o'clock news is about little pieces of information from which people draw inferences.Those members who have spoken against the proposal by the Leader of the House want to see those sorts of stunts—and that is all they are—rewarded. The honourable member for Bennelong might unjustifiably—or even justifiably—feel that the standing orders do not let opposition members do and say what they would like to do and say. I remind him, as I have reminded him here frequently in the past, that the great majority of the present standing orders were determined by members of his party when they were in power. They determined them—in the words of some of his colleagues in the past—in an attempt to make sure that they had their way. If the honourable member for Bennelong is worried about that, maybe the solution was in his hands in those days. He should have made sure he was a little more liberal and democratic then than he says he wants to be now.

The standing orders are there to protect the dignity of the House. For members to come in here and say that we should not only have a mechanism whereby we can stand up and make all sorts of outrageous allegations and stupid points of order, but also have a reward by seeing such actions televised on the news that night, is just a joke, and they know it.

The proof is in the pudding. The proof in the pudding is that 90 per cent of the points of order that are made are out of order. Very few points of order are upheld by those occupying the chair in this place, be they members of the Labor, Liberal or National parties, because most of them are not in order; most of them are stunts that are attempted to be used by people to break up someone else's speech or, as the honourable member for Bennelong said, inject a politically loaded point into the middle of question time. The censorship in this is in the standing orders because the standing orders say that members cannot do that. But those opposite want to be able to not only do it but get a reward for it. That is a little bit of extravagant hypocrisy in my view.

It is interesting that opposition members have only spoken about this one area. They have only talked about politically loaded points of order and why they should be able to do that. It is very interesting that we have not heard from the honourable member for Bennelong about the other parts of this proposed resolution—the part that relates to the rebroadcasting of withdrawn remarks. No doubt the honourable member for O'Connor will get up and say he thinks we should be able to rebroadcast withdrawn remarks, but I do not think many other people in this place would want to justify that. That is the other side of the coin of censorship—that is, having people use this place to make outrageous allegations and attacks on people under the cloak of parliamentary privilege and, having done that, having withdrawn those remarks in the House, get the reward of having them run on television that night.

It is bad enough when people come in here and make unsubstantiated attacks on individuals. It has always been to my sorrow that the House never accepted the Senate's standing order which allows individuals from outside this place to have the Presiding Officer come in and run their defence for them. The House never took up that recommendation of the Standing Committee on Procedure when I was a member of it. Maybe in the future that will occur.

What is being argued here is that we should go further—that members should be able to stand up in this place, make an outrageous and disgraceful attack on somebody, be asked by the chair to withdraw it, in a sotto voce way say, `I withdraw, Mr Speaker', and then have it run on the 6 o'clock news that night. They have stood up in front of all their colleagues and withdrawn it; it is implied in the withdrawal, if one reads House of Representatives Practice, that they are not only withdrawing, but apologising. So they stand up and say, `Look, I was wrong, I apologise, but thank God they are going to run it on the news tonight. I'll get them, won't I?'. That is what the honourable member for Bendigo and the honourable member for Bennelong—and, no doubt, the honourable member for O'Connor—are arguing we should do.

That is really pretty good stuff, is it not? Honourable members can come in here and say anything. They can even retract it, but they can then go and see their mates in the media and say, `That was a nice little red hot number I gave you today; put it on, won't you?'. Of course, they will do so. Why does the media want to run these things? It is because it is interested in the circus of the place. It is not interested in the substance of the place.

One of the things that members of the media used to come and see me about when I was the Speaker was that they wanted to do these two things, and the other thing they talked about was that they wanted to film disorder in the place. They wanted to be able to film someone jumping from the balcony into the chamber. They wanted to be able to film the honourable member for O'Connor being taken out of the chamber by the Serjeant-at-Arms when he refused to leave the chamber one day after being named. They want to run this minutiae. That is the sort of thing they want to run. They do not want to run the decent speeches that the honourable member for Aston (Mr Nugent) might make in this place. They want to show that sort of stupidity.

I do not think any opposition member is actually going to be game to get up and say that they want withdrawn remarks to be able to be run. I would find it incredible if someone did, because it is an absolute nonsense. It is an absolute nonsense that someone should be able to come in here, slander somebody terribly, withdraw in front of his colleagues, but still be able to have that slander run on television later that night.

At issue here is the question of whether politically loaded points of order will be run, and whether disgraceful, and in most cases unwarranted, attacks on people—which have been withdrawn, resiled from and apologised for—will be run. I do not know why any honourable member would want some remark that he or she had withdrawn and, by implication, apologised for, run on television that night. I do not know why any honourable member would want to do that unless he or she had come in here with malice in their hearts and with the deliberate intention of using the standing orders to make the allegation, quickly withdraw it, sit down and see the person so maligned get a run on television later that evening.

Some members of the opposition have demonstrated an interesting change of heart here today. It would be interesting to know whether the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) agrees with the honourable member for Bennelong because, in his submission to the committee, the Leader of the Opposition wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Mr Speaker,
Thank you for your letter of 10 June regarding your review of the arrangements of televising the House of Representatives and seeking the views of Members.
As a general rule, I think the current rules governing the televising of Parliament work well and do not require major revision.
He went on, taking up some of the line of the honourable member for Bennelong:

I note that Mr Eoin Cameron has raised with you whether it is appropriate to maintain a prohibition on the showing of points of order and I agree with his view. While some points of order may be only procedural,—

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!
—If the honourable member for Bennelong had been here earlier to hear my remarks he might understand the context of this. The Leader of the Opposition continued:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . others are integral to proceedings in the House and it may be necessary to refer to them in a balanced report of events . . .
Perhaps the Standing Committee could discuss the merits of the existing ruling in this regard.

Neither the Leader of the Opposition, nor the honourable member for Bennelong nor the honourable member for Bendigo in his response have said that they would like to see—in the words of the honourable member for Bennelong—politically loaded remarks re-run. However, the honourable member for Bendigo did say something interesting. He wrote:
Thank you for your recent letter . . .
I have had discussions with the Honourable John Howard . . . who I understand will be making representations to you on behalf of the Coalition.
I do not think that he did. His name does not appear in the evidence or the submissions. Perhaps he forgot about it. However, quite properly, he is getting his chance here today.

PARA.TAB: What we are doing now is what we do with most committee reports. Committees meet, they report to the House, there is some discussion and the House makes a decision. The procedures committee will be reporting in the next few weeks about the sitting times of the House and changes to standing orders. No-one would suggest that the honourable member for Bonython (Dr Blewett) should stand up here, make his report, sit down and leave it at that. People will want to have something to say about the matter. On this particular issue, the honourable member for Bennelong forgot to put in the submission that his colleague said he would be making. He has a chance to have his say now, and that is as it should be.

I do not believe that anyone can substantiate an argument for having these malicious, withdrawn statements run on television. The opposition might feel that it cannot get its view across in question time and should be able to do it via politically loaded points of order. However, the standing orders prevent that. If the opposition were playing the game properly it would not be able to take that action because of the standing orders. It ought to look at its behaviour rather than try to breach the standing orders and have that sort of thing run on television as a result.

We should consider the fact that by lifting the prohibition on re-running withdrawn remarks and points of order we will not be dramatically changing the view the community has about how this parliament is run. What will happen is that the people who come in here and get involved in stunts will be rewarded. All this is a very significant reward for people who would rather drag the place down than make considered interventions and properly use—

TALK.START.PARA: —That's a reflection on the chair, you know.

—No, it is not, because the chair rewards people involved in stunts by putting them out. That is what we should be doing. We should be looking at that rather than allowing the opposition to run the line that we should be involving ourselves in those sorts of stunts. (Time expired)

—Mr Speaker, I do not know how you are feeling today as chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on the Televising of the House of Representatives. As a member of that committee, I am feeling very disappointed and very angry. It is said that we should not speak when we are angry because we might say things for which we might be sorry afterwards, so I will not speak for very long. I simply want to say how disappointed I am with the action the government has taken.

PARA.TAB: I was very surprised by the remarks made by the honourable member for Watson (Mr Leo McLeay) in this debate. He is a former Speaker and, as I understand it, a former chairman of this committee—a committee of which I have been a member for some time. I believe that this committee has adopted a very responsible attitude. Although we want the people of Australia to be well informed about what is happening in the parliament, one of our main aims was to ensure that parliament is not brought into disrepute, and we have worked very hard to that end.

I have been a member of the committee since its formation. We have nursed along the issue of the televising of parliament in order to achieve the satisfaction of ensuring that the people of Australia are well informed about what is happening here, while at the same time ensuring that the parliament is not brought into disrepute. I know that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is very concerned about some of the recommendations, but those recommendations show how very keen we have been to do that. We do not want television footage of people jumping off balconies into the chamber, and the recommendations ensure that we will not be seeing that. In many other areas as well we have made sure that nothing will take place that will harm the parliament.

I have sat in this parliament day after day for many years now and I have witnessed the parliament degenerating. It is degenerating in the first place because of the limit imposed on the number of questions asked at question time. I sit here and I see one man in his grab for power and hear talk of a republic. I warn the people of Australia that they will get more of the same—the taking on of dictatorial powers—if that is the way we go.

I have heard those same speakers on the government side who talk about what should not be allowed to happen in the parliament almost denigrate their colleagues in this place by suggesting that we are playing politics when we stand up to take points of order. We are allowed to stand up and take points of order. It is part of the democratic system under which we live. On any one day, there could be 500 people in the gallery watching what is going on in the parliament. Why should people watching their television sets not be able to do the same? Is this some form of censorship? Do we have the right to tell people what they are allowed to see of this parliament?

I have sat here and watched this parliament gradually deteriorate. There is a limit on the number of questions that can be asked and on the way in which those questions are answered. We listen to the Prime Minister and other ministers attack the opposition, getting stuck into them over matters totally unrelated to the question. In my electorate of Riverina we have a number of difficulties. The farming sector has a serious problem. There is high unemployment. When I come in here at question time I want some answers, but I am not getting any. We are becoming frustrated by the way in which this parliament is being run. We want some answers from the government. The only recourse we have is to stand up on a point of order and ask the Prime Minister of the day to please answer our questions. We are here to represent our electorates and our people want to know what he is going to do to overcome these problems. The electorate is used to rudeness.

The government has been eroding the representative value of members of parliament in their electorates. On the one hand, it sets up regional committees all over the place for political purposes; on the other hand, it puts up the price of fuel—an action which will wreck any regionalisation program we are trying to implement. All over the place we are seeing jobs for the boys. No wonder we in the parliament are becoming demoralised, and no wonder the people whom we represent are becoming demoralised.

I went into a shop the other day and I was talking about the parliament. A person of Greek heritage said to me, `You must get rid of the Prime Minister'. I asked why. I thought that he would say something about unemployment or the state of the nation. He said, `Two school children came into my shop the other day calling each other scumbags. Where do you think they get that from? They get it from the parliament; it is disgraceful'. If the Prime Minister and ministers are allowed to get away with that, why are we not allowed to stand up and take points of orders to correct that situation?

A number of matters have been raised today. I was surprised at the former speaker, the honourable member for Watson, getting up here trying to protect the Speaker. I saw the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) trying to drum up speakers to talk on this issue. I do not believe that anyone in this parliament really believes in what the government is trying to do. The government is trying to do away with the televising of points of order and other matters. It set up this committee and, like many other things that it is trying to do, in the middle of the game it shifted the goalposts.

What are we supposed to do? We are members of parliament. We are all equals in the parliament. No-one in this parliament is more equal than anyone else. You, with your dictatorial powers, say, `I am sorry, but you fellows really do not have what it takes'. You are not just talking about our side of the parliament; you are also talking about your own side of the parliament. You say, `We will change the rules because the Prime Minister is not happy with this report'. The Prime Minister wants to be a dictator. He is being a dictator, and these rules will apply.

I know that you, Mr Speaker, must be very hurt. I know that you had a session with the Prime Minister last night. I know that when we sat down in that committee to determine what we would do we were very careful. As I said before, we are worried about the institution of the parliament. The Prime Minister hardly ever makes a statement in the parliament. He is either at the Press Club or some doorstop. We find out through the back door exactly what will happen to this nation.

What has happened to the parliament? The problem is that we are treated with contempt. We are elected by the people of Australia to represent them in this parliament, and that is what we are trying to do. I think this is a form of censorship. I think not only should we, in the parliament, be very upset about what is happening today, but also the people of Australia should be very upset.

As you, Mr Speaker, would know, being the chairman of that committee, the number of people watching the proceedings of parliament on television is increasing dramatically. I am surprised when I go back to my electorate to learn just how many people have watched the parliament and know exactly what is going on. I think it is time now for some democracy to be brought back to the parliament. Members of parliament should be given their correct stature; that is, we are not dictated to by a person who appears, to me, to be a megalomaniac.

I think the parliament should overrule the Leader of the House on this matter. I ask the Leader of the House to go back to the Prime Minister and say, `The best thing that we can do for democracy is to go along with this report. This committee had a charter, and it followed its charter'. We did not do anything that we should not have done. As the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) says, it is surprising that the Prime Minister was not onto this matter quicker. Obviously, his advisers were a bit slow off the mark, when we are trying to get a bit of democracy back into the parliament. I know that members of the government will try to defend the indefensible. This decision to oppose the report's recommendations is indefensible and we, on this side of the House, are very upset about it. I am personally upset and angry, because I am a member of that committee. I believe that the people on the committee from both sides of the parliament were very responsible people.

I ask you, Mr Speaker, and the Leader of the House to go back to the Prime Minister again when he returns home and put the proposition to him that we want some more democracy back in this House. This parliament is the centre of democracy in this country. We are being overruled. We can no longer have censure motions; we have guillotines. What is the point of having a parliament? I say to the people of Australia, `Be very careful about what is happening in our parliamentary system today. Have a look around at the various electorates, see what is happening, see where the money is being spent, see what is happening here in the parliament to try to gag our debate'.

I was surprised to hear the Leader of the House say that we all stand up on frivolous points of order and that we are obviously not responsible. We have been elected by our electorates, so we must have something going for us. He is telling us that we cannot stand up and carry out our true parliamentary duties and enact democracy as it should be carried out in this country.

I know, Mr Speaker, that you are hurt. I would say that you are very disappointed. I am disappointed and angry. If I keep going on, I will say things that I really should not say and will have to retract them. So I will finish now and thank you for your indulgence.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like the member for Riverina (Mr Hicks) I, too, was a member of the Standing Committee on the Televising of the House of Representatives. I would like to express briefly—and I will keep my remarks brief, because I know that others would like to have their say on this particular issue—my disappointment, because a lot of work and effort went into this particular report. To work on this committee with you, Mr Speaker, as the chairman was a singularly pleasurable experience. Our meetings were cordial. We heard lots of evidence from media outlets in this country and from various television organisations. To a man and woman, when they gave their evidence to the committee, they were entirely supportive of what the end result has been.

PARA.TAB: I think that this motion is just a further example of the erosion of democracy in this place. I cannot imagine how this could possibly have happened. I could have been knocked down by a feather this morning when I was told that this particular motion was to be brought before the House.

I did make the remark some time ago that I cannot understand why, in the first place, we had restrictions on the televising of the parliament. Obviously, there had to be some small restrictions, but on particular issues. In the previous report, The eyes have it, when I asked about the restrictions placed on it, I was told that the kybosh was put on it by the then Treasurer, now the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). I have absolutely no doubt that he is the man behind the kybosh being put on this proposal this morning. I was particularly pleased to see that my suggested title for this report was adopted—To see or not to see: this is the answer. Unfortunately for the people of Australia, it seems that the Prime Minister believes that they cannot see what goes on in this place. I find that extraordinarily disappointing. I would like to register my bitter disappointment at the way in which the parliament is being treated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I thank you for the call, because I have been mentioned, as you would know, a couple of times on this issue. At the time of election to your high office, you may recollect that in speaking to congratulate you I gave a brief and potted history of circumstances that occurred in this parliament and what I believed, amongst other things, was the deterioration of the way in which the parliament was conducted, particularly at question time. At that time—and I would like the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) not to leave for a minute because I wish to make a personal plea to him—I also drew your attention to the treatment received by Speaker Cope when he was voted down by his own party on a decision that he had taken. I seriously ask—and I hope that the Leader of the House might listen for a moment—him to defer this matter.

PARA.TAB: Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I am quite seriously asking the Leader of the House to defer this matter. If he uses his numbers on this issue, it will be an effective vote of no confidence in the Speaker.

PARA.TAB: Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Government members can laugh about that. I beg them not to push for a vote on it. Most Speakers in this situation would do as the government obliged Speaker Cope to do—resign in the chair. The government is casting a vote of no confidence in its Speaker. I do not want to make that a big political point.

PARA.TAB: I plead with the Leader of the House: don't do it. Go away, wait till the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) comes back from Cyprus and say, `Do you really want to do this, considering that the Speaker of the House of Representatives, as chairman of a committee, stood up in this place yesterday and said, "I recommend, and I have agreed'—let us underline `agreed'—`that forthwith points of order, in particular, and matters that have been ordered to be withdrawn be available for rebroadcast on television."?'. Any effort to overturn that report in this fashion is a vote of no confidence in the Speaker.

I remind the Leader of the House that, when his side of politics last did that, his father walked out of the chamber. He would not vote against the Speaker. The government should not do it. I beg the government not to do it, because that is what it is doing. The government can try to mess it up in any way, but the facts are that it has happened.

Let us look at some of the facts. The fact is that yesterday, while the Speaker was on his feet, the Prime Minister was telling the Leader of the House, `Stop him doing this'. The Leader of the House replied, `It is too late; we will have to deal with it tomorrow'. The government cannot dealt with it tomorrow. It should not vote no confidence in its own Speaker. That is what the government is doing. Please do not do that. Please go away and think about it—adjourn this debate. Let us talk about it again later. Standing order 98 states:

SPEECH.PARA: Any Member may at any time raise a point of order which shall, until disposed of, suspend the consideration and decision of every other question.

That is pretty clear as to the rights of members of this place. We are looking at a situation where the suggestion has been made that every point of order taken in this place is somehow despicable. I ask the minister to go back to the Hansard record—everything is on the record here; history cannot be rewritten in this place—read the points of order and see whether they are despicable.

TALK.START.PARA: —They're frivolous.

—The honourable member for Herbert has just said that they are frivolous. That is a decision for the Speaker, not for him. As the honourable member for Watson (Mr Leo McLeay) has just told us, the Speaker often rules against members. Furthermore, if we televise these things and a member gets up and his or her arguments to the Speaker are frivolous, do honourable members not think that the Australian public will wake up to that? Do honourable members think the public are so silly that they would not recognise that? They would have been listening to the Prime Minister; they would have listened to the question; they would have heard the point of order. They would have made their judgment on the point of order claiming that the Prime Minister was not relevant to the question. They can make a judgment on that. One loses, and it might be the person who makes the point of order. The Prime Minister is frightened that the public judgment will be that he is irrelevant and that he is not answering the question. That is the clear judgment of those that see the first run, the uncut version. How can it be said that a point of order is not part of the fundamental processes of this place and should be censored out of any rebroadcast?

PARA.TAB: That is happening now with the ABC's re-run. We are told at the beginning that it is a cut down version and that this and that have been taken out. If I happen to be away from the place and I suddenly hear a member run on—

TALK.START.PARA: —There's nothing to cut out, Wilson.

—Points of order are cut out. We suddenly hear somebody talking and it is completely illogical because the point of order that warranted the further comment, or the ruling of the Speaker, has been cut out. It cannot be understood because bits have been taken out. I challenge the honourable member for Watson. All the complaints by him about the abuse of points of order are not justified by the written record. We can argue until we are blue in the face as to whether or not an answer is relevant. There is a legion of evidence and precedents as to what is and what is not relevant.

PARA.TAB: If the honourable member for Herbert believes that there are so many frivolous points of order, let them be rebroadcast. Wilson Tuckey, the honourable member for O'Connor, will take the pain. I will be seen in the community.

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, you have.

—Is that not funny? That is why I have now got the safest conservative seat in Australia and the second safest seat in Australia. Someone passes some judgment. The honourable member hangs on by his fingernails. What do the electors think of him? What will they think of him when I go to Townsville and tell them that he is a censor and he is anti-democracy?

PARA.TAB: I will now spend some time dealing with the other matter, that of withdrawal. A member can only be called upon to withdraw if there is a specific allegation against a member. But when the Prime Minister generalises about the opposition as dogs returning to their vomit, that is not withdrawn. That cannot be withdrawn. The precedents are there. It might be considered unparliamentary. The Speaker of the day did not consider it to be; it is still on the record. When the Prime Minister referred to the opposition as political harlots, that was not withdrawn. My response to him was that it was not only withdrawn; it was removed from the Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —So it should have been.

—The honourable member remembers it. He might like to tell us what I said. The simple fact is that that raises another point. I have in front of me the House of Representatives Parliamentary Practice, which says, although there is no standing order:

SPEECH.PARA: Exceptionally, offensive remarks ordered to be withdrawn have been deleted from the records.

Surely that is the test that this House should apply to accommodate the bleatings of the honourable member for Watson. If there is to be some matter before us, surely it should be that, where the Speaker considers the matter should be deleted from Hansard, then it should not be rebroadcast. Otherwise, it is part of the parliamentary record, it is in the book, it is available to all the people who listen here and it is available to those who listen to the direct broadcast. It is available to be rebroadcast on radio but not on television. Why is that? The minister just told us, `Too many people watch television. We can't possibly have points of order being programmed on television. You couldn't possibly have a debate on the issues'. A point of order may be followed by a dissent motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you come back to the motion?

—I have not left the debate, I am totally relevant on these two particular issues. The first issue is a resolution of this parliament in contravention of a decision of the Speaker to prevent the rebroadcast on television of points of order. It is a joke. I just do not know why those opposite are that frightened. It is not an issue. There is minimalist evidence of actual points of order being used in an abuse of the process. The honourable member for Herbert says that they are frivolous. I do not know. Various speakers have ruled differently on that point. Standing order 98 unequivocally gives members the right to take a point of order and to take it in the forms of the parliament. Immediately they are not, they can be rolled, they can be punished and they can be kicked out. Why remove it from being televised? Those opposite are worried that their Prime Minister in the public eyes, if not in the eyes of the Speaker, may be found to be irrelevant. Maybe they will side with us on the point of order. I am sure they are not worried about my being found frivolous and irrelevant. I just could not believe that. That is the risk I take if this is publicised. I am quite happy to take that risk. Those opposite are worried and, more importantly, the man who has organised this vote of no confidence in the Speaker is worried that people will wake up to what is being done. For what reason? The committee as a whole has said that it is appropriate to rebroadcast points of order, and of course it is. It is fundamental to the process of any debating forum. It is not prevented anywhere else. It is not prevented in the Senate. Members of this House were whingeing a little while ago about how we were giving the Senate powers for which it was not entitled. The ministers in the Senate are not frightened by it. Why are they frightened down here? Why cast a vote against the Speaker?

PARA.TAB: I repeat: the government should not go ahead with this vote. It will be reported as a vote of no confidence in the Speaker. It is very silly and it is wrong because the Speaker was right. He has taken a unanimous judgment, along with a bipartisan committee, which heard the evidence. He is right. Why do this to him? Why is it only the government side that does these sorts of things to Speakers, such as former Speaker Jim Cope? Why do those opposite do it? The reason is that they have to show the strength of their muscle. The Prime Minister and the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) are recorded as the only two remaining members who voted down a Speaker.

The father of the Leader of the House refused that; he walked out. This is going to be a great test for the government side. There are some old members here who might remember that situation—the honourable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding) would be one. I would like to see where he casts his vote on this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer too.

—I would be very interested to see what happens. The father of the Leader of the House must be livid about this situation—the fact that his son gets up here and proposes a motion that, to all intents and purposes, is a vote of no confidence in the Speaker. Please do not do it.
—Absolute rubbish.

—If the honourable member thinks it is rubbish he has a very poor understanding of the forms of this place. No doubt Gough Whitlam thought it was rubbish to prevent his Leader of the House moving the appropriate motion after a minister had defied the Speaker. No doubt he thought it was rubbish and no doubt government members thought it was a big joke when they all sidled in here and voted against the request of their own Speaker. It is only a request. I name the so-and-so.

PARA.TAB: As honourable members might remember, it was the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) who on that occasion had to move the motion. Those opposite denied their Speaker a request and they are now denying this Speaker another request. It is as simple as that. They may want to do it, but I cannot. If we on this side suddenly got the feeling that we should vote with the government, I would have to vote against my side simply because I would not undermine the Speaker in that way. If those opposite want to do it, they can go ahead; they will go on the record. In time to come a young member of parliament will stand up here—as I did in referring to the case of Speaker Cope—and remind the parliament of how those opposite voted against the Speaker. The Speaker recommended it. It is there in black and white. He was correct. But those opposite are prepared, by this motion, to vote him down.

I do not know what the Speaker will do. It depends on how much of a man that he feels he is. But there is no doubt what he should do if those opposite take this vote. Fundamental to my position here, I say: do not do it, do not take the vote, wait until the Prime Minister comes back, and when he comes back say, `Do you realise what has happened?'. What a joke it is. There is no problem at all in the Senate. Why would those opposite do it? (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am bound to say to my colleague the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) that I have heard better speeches from him in this place. I am pleased to note that he entered this debate because of his concern for the proper functioning of this institution. The honourable member has, for a variety of political reasons, built up a not very envious record of having been asked to leave this place on a number of occasions. I do not hold that against him because that is part of his view of how parliamentarians make points. I simply say to my colleague, as one who has been in two parliaments for 31 years, that the real test of a parliamentarian is not how you throw the bucket but how you throw the bucket and not get thrown out.

PARA.TAB: In my view, what we are talking about today should not be regarded in terms of an opposition view or a government view, because there is no government view. It should not be put on the basis that, somehow, if honourable members vote against this proposal, it is a vote of no confidence in my friend and colleague the Speaker. If that argument had any merit at all, then the Speaker would not need to have a committee. All he would have to do is to say, `That is what is going to happen', and that is what would happen.

This Speaker, as other Speakers, has never claimed or sought to establish a doctrine of Speakers' infallibility when it comes to the actions of committees which they chair. It is palpable nonsense to say that to reject aspects of these findings is some kind of a lack of confidence in the Speaker or in any of the members of this committee.

The point I want to make, and I put it to my colleagues in the opposition very seriously, is that we are all transients in this place. What is important about this institution is the institution itself. I, for one, make no apology for the fact that I believe one of the great gifts that came to us as a result of our British heritage was the institution of parliament and the concepts that have come out of Westminster. I believe that we serve this parliament best if we seek to deal with these problems in terms of our history and our tradition, again without any reflection upon the Speaker.

I have seen Speakers come and go; I have seen Prime Ministers come and go; I have seen governments come and go; and I have seen oppositions come and go. That is the nature of this institution. There are certain people who, over time, serve the parliament and embody much of the wisdom of the parliament. I refer honourable members to the remarks of their colleague the Clerk of the House of Representatives. We have all been in situations when we have seen things getting a bit tough and rough where the Speaker, or Speakers, has referred to the Clerk of the House for his advice and wisdom. I refer to clause 2.25 of the report:
