SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Clerk of the House of Representatives stated that he would not favour the lifting of the prohibition on the televising of withdrawn remarks.

He referred to a hypothetical situation where a member would come in here full of nulla fides. To that view I would add that one of the important things of this institution is that what we say in here is the subject of absolute legal privilege. I ask honourable members to think about it. When honourable members who have been in parliament for any length of time look back on some of the things they have said and done there is not one of them who would not say, with a view to a more charitable disposition for people in opposing political parties, that perhaps they could have been a little bit more charitable on a particular occasion. I have said harsh things in this place to some of my colleagues.

PARA.TAB: When the honourable member for O'Connor first came into this place he made it publicly known that he was proud of the fact that he kept bar. Censoring does take place on television. The honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) knows, as anybody who has held a senior political position would know, that for all the times he has spoken into the camera for five minutes, either at a doorstop or in a television studio—unless the program is going live—he would be lucky to get 20 seconds. If there is a decent murder or decent rape going on in the local community he will not get any time at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are no decent rapes.

—No, of course the honourable member is right. I accept that. We have to ask ourselves whether we want to build into this institution a situation where a skilled and experienced parliamentarian can come into the House with a premeditation to attack in the most personal and vindictive way a parliamentary colleague on the other side, knowing that at some stage, if he can get enough words out quickly, he will withdraw when he is asked to withdraw. That is equivalent to an apology. It is equivalent to saying, `I know I broke the standing orders. I know that I was acting outside the good sense and responsibility of this institution'.

PARA.TAB: We now have a proposition where I or any member could do that. Although we would apologise to the chair and to our colleagues by the act of withdrawing, if it is a dull day in the community, it could be run on the television networks of this nation. Are we to believe that that is in the interests of this institution? Of course it is not. We can see the great interest that the press and the media have in this debate by the way they are covering it.

Let me tell honourable members a story about the way in which I believe parliamentary institutions operate. When I was Leader of the Opposition in Victoria, I was approached by a journalist from the Melbourne Herald. He said he wanted to raise with me some matters pertaining to a very senior minister in the Victorian government. He had a fairly lurid account for me of the marital situation of that particular minister. I said to him, `What have you got for me about his irresponsibility in his portfolio?'. There was no suggestion of that at all. The important point was that if I, as Leader of the Opposition, wanted to raise this, using some of the forms of the House, I could be guaranteed front page coverage for several days. I presented my compliments to his editor and told him that if he wanted to run that sort of material he was free to run it but that Her Majesty's opposition was not going to deal with that level of politics.

I also went back to my caucus and told the members what had happened, in case any one of them should be approached. I then got a unanimous vote from the caucus. I would hope that that level of political morality could still operate. I also told the journalist that I felt that I had a duty to inform the minister concerned of that approach so that he knew of it. I did that and I got quite a different view of the facts. This institution, for better or for worse and for all the imperfections of its members—and we all have them—is the repository of the democratic fabric of this nation.

It is a nonsense proposition that will greatly damage this institution to say to the media, `As an individual member, I can come in with malice aforethought. I might not be here all that long, but I can do a job not merely upon a parliamentary colleague but upon a businessman outside who might be entirely innocent. I can make all sorts of allegations under privilege. I can break the standing orders and be called to account because I am acting outside the traditions and the practices of this House. But that is good news which can go over the television networks of this nation'.

This institution, as an institution, has all the imperfections of those of us who compose it. But it should not be forgotten that, to the media, parliamentarians are fair game. Parliamentarians are continually brought to task, but so too are their children. I remember some vague misdemeanour involving the children of a former Speaker. It was front page news. It was an event that occurred every day of the week in my community but it was front page news because he was the Speaker of this parliament—and the same standard will be applied to all of us.

Do opposition members think for one moment that it is freedom to change the standing orders of this place so that honourable members can make an allegation in here, withdraw and apologise but still have it run by the media? Is that freedom? That is giving the people who run the media the right to censor what happens in this parliament.

I have seen great speeches made in this parliament but they have never got the coverage in the media, particularly on television, which is afforded a decent stoush at question time. A few angry words, a few angry exchanges, uncharitable remarks outside the framework of the standing orders, which will be withdrawn, will always get a better headline than a thoughtful or a deliberative speech from whichever side of the parliament.

So I say, on the basis of my own not inconsiderable experience—I am still in the position where most opposition members have not spent as much time in opposition as I have; so I understand their frustration and feelings—that it should be remembered that we are all simply passing through this place. We all have a duty to the institution of parliament to maintain concepts which have come down over generations of parliamentarians and make these institutions perform their functions more effectively. Cheap shots and political muckraking take place from time to time in every parliamentary institution that I have ever seen, because that is the nature of politics in our community.

TALK.START.PARA: —You'd know about it.
—I have done my share but I have never been thrown out, and that is the test of a good parliamentarian.
—So getting away with it is okay.

—Getting away with it is not okay, but at least it is within the standing orders. Let me give a simple example. Just as the honourable member for O'Connor probably has a file on me, I explained on one occasion in the heat of question time how he came to get his nickname, `Iron Bar'. I do not have to go over that again; I have done that. It was not charitable, but it was truthful. Of course, I said things that I think I withdrew.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members are now saying that that is all right, that is all fair game, because the manager of the local television station can run that in full. There have been personal exchanges from both sides across that table which have not done this institution any credit at all. Dealing in marital relationships or any of that stuff is of no interest to the development of this political institution, and the community does not expect it. But opposition members are now saying that, when that occurs, it will be all right if the manager of the local television station reckons that is worth a few points and runs it—even though it is withdrawn and apologised for.

I believe we should look to the wisdom of the clerks, as Speakers and this parliament have often done in the past. Looking to the view of the Clerk of the House of Representatives, the evidence that was given was about not merely the past of this institution and the hard lessons that have been learned from time to time, but about the future of this institution, how it relates to the rest of the community and, more importantly, how it sees itself.

We have all said things in this place which we may subsequently regret. We have all said things that are uncharitable. That is part of the process. But the institutions of Westminster and the Westminster tradition have learned how to deal with that. This particular concept and the recommendation that has been made go against those traditions and, if we accept the recommendation—and I do not care who has signed it—it will lead this institution into nothing but trouble. It will deliver even more power to those who run the media and the press in this country.

At the end of the day, I trust more in the judgment of my political colleagues, I trust more in the judgment of this institution, than I trust those gentlemen whose basic motive is not just simply to present their news but to present that which they think will provide some aspect to their operations which will enhance their listening audience, regardless of how salacious or silly it is. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call the Leader of the House I would like to make two comments briefly. The first goes to an issue raised by the honourable member for O'Connor. The report which is being debated here today or parts thereof—and I repeat that it is parts thereof because there are substantial other parts of the report which are not the subject of this particular motion—was tabled in this place by me yesterday in my capacity as chairman of the Standing Committee on the Televising of the House of Representatives. Under the terms of the resolution which established that committee, it actually says that the chairman of that committee shall be selected from amongst the members who are appointed to that committee. I therefore did not deliver that report as Speaker; I delivered it as chairman of the committee.

PARA.TAB: The second point that I would go to is an assertion which was contained in the comments of the honourable member for Bennelong and repeated by the honourable member for Riverina, when it was suggested that various words were used, that I had quite a discussion or that I had quite a session with the Prime Minister last night on this report. I have not, since the tabling of this report, discussed it with the Prime Minister. I make that categorical statement here in the course of this debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, with your indulgence, let me make it clear that I do not dispute the accuracy of what you said about your own conduct in respect of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). But, Mr Speaker, are you telling the parliament that you were not involved in any way in discussions on that side of the House regarding the course of action taken this morning by the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) in that, in substance, as the Speaker of this place and as chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on the Televising of the House of Representatives, the first you found out about it was when you looked at the Notice Paper this morning? Is that what you are telling us?

—I repeat for the honourable member for Bennelong that I am saying that, in reference to the comments that both you and the honourable member for Riverina made, I have not discussed this matter with the Prime Minister.

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Mr Beazley) put:
That the question be now put.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, the Prime Minister's remarks—
—Order! The honourable member does not have the call.

PARA.TAB: Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Original question put:
That the motion (Mr Beazley's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, on a point of clarification: firstly, does the resolution carried by the parliament have immediate effect?
—Yes.

—Secondly, I raise a point of order. During the first of the two divisions we have had, clearly audible to a number on the opposition benches, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) said quite deliberately, `This is designed to keep vermin like you off the air'. That is what the Prime Minister said. I regard that, and I am sure my colleagues do, as offensive. I ask that you require the Prime Minister to withdraw it.
—When honourable members were coming in here there were some words from both sides of the parliament. That particular—

PARA.TAB: Mr Howard interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Wait until I have finished. Indeed, there were words from both sides. I certainly did not hear the Prime Minister. It was in the course of a division, and that is where the issue ends.
—I move dissent from your ruling.
—Order! Before people get too excited, I have given an explanation to that particular issue.
—I was raising a point of order, Mr Speaker.
—Correct, and I have given an explanation on that, and I have said in explanation that that was in the course of a division and that is where, as far as I am concerned, the matter ends now.
—So that is your ruling?
—That is my ruling now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the ruling be dissented from.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Speaker, I move dissent from your ruling for the very simple reason that we have just had a very lengthy and I think a very useful debate about a decision taken by the government to overturn a unanimous decision of a committee of this House, having the full authority of this House, which was chaired by you. The whole thrust of our argument in that debate was that by not allowing the full rebroadcasting of what takes place at question time the government was conferring an unfair advantage on the government. Colourful, critical, offensive or insulting remarks could be made by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and other ministers during question time and those remarks could be rebroadcast over the airwaves in the evening. We on this side of the House had absolutely no opportunity—through a point of order, interjection or interruption—to restore some balance to the flow of question time because of this restriction introduced by the government in defiance of a recommendation of a committee chaired by you. Do you know what the reply of the government was in the course of that debate, what the reply of the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) was and what the reply of the former Speaker, the honourable member for Watson (Mr Leo McLeay), was?

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I take a point of order on the question of relevance. This is a debate about whether your ruling was incorrect. It is a strictly technical point. What the honourable member is now doing is canvassing the previous debate in a manner irrelevant to whether your ruling was in accordance with the standing orders. He is out of order.

—I find that the minister's point has some validity. The honourable member for Bennelong has been here long enough to know that, in the sort of motion that he has moved, the technical aspects of it are to be canvassed. I would ask him to come to those.

—I understand that, but in order to establish how I believe your ruling to be incorrect I obviously must provide the background. The reason that I took that point of order was to illustrate the very dilemma that faces us on this side of the House. Audibly to all of us on this side of the House, the first remark the Prime Minister made when he entered the chamber was, `What are you grubs up to now?'. That was the first remark the Prime Minister made. Then when there was some comment made about free speech from this side of the House, do you know what the Prime Minister's reply was? He said, `This is designed to keep vermin like you off the air'. I repeat: `This is designed to keep vermin like you off the air'.

PARA.TAB: Not only is that a highly offensive statement but also it is an incredibly revealing statement. That really went to the substance of the whole argument that we had been putting this morning; that is, that by denying to the networks of this nation a capacity to rebroadcast what we say by way of points of order the government is given an enormous advantage.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. This is not relevant to the question of whether you ruled correctly at all.
—What are you worried about?
—I am just trying to keep opposition members in order. The honourable member for Bennelong is obliged to say why your ruling was incorrect.

—Order! The minister again raised the point of technical relevance under this particular motion. I suspect now that the honourable member for Bennelong has in fact given enough background to illustrate the point that he is going to come to.
—I have reached the penultimate stage of the background.
—No, you have reached the entire background.

—The ultimate stage of the background is that the defence of the government and the Prime Minister is, `Oh, no, when you give answers you can't get away with blue murder because if you say anything nasty, if you say anything offensive, it has to be'—

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. I think that one of the most serious motions that can be before the House is dissent from the Speaker's ruling. The issue here is whether you have acted correctly or incorrectly in your ruling in a division. It is very important that the opposition treat the motion with the seriousness it deserves and return to the point about your ruling, not the previous debate.
—Order! I have already suggested the honourable member for Bennelong do that and I am sure he will now.

—I think that is a bit rich coming from somebody who has just collectively dissented from the Speaker's ruling, which is exactly what government members opposite collectively did twice just 10 minutes ago. So government members should not give us any lectures about dissenting from the Speaker's ruling and respecting the role of the Speaker. Those opposite should not give us any of those lectures.

PARA.TAB: The basic defence of the government to what it was doing was to say that if, in the course of question time, the Prime Minister or any other minister in full flight says something that is offensive, says something that should not be said, or something that is out of order, they can be required to withdraw because it is contrary to standing orders. Everybody on the government and opposition front benches knows damned well what the Prime Minister said when he came in here. It is typical of the way in which there is one standard for Paul Keating and another standard for anybody else. That is how this parliament is being run. If the Prime Minister had his way, that is how this nation would be run.

I took the point of order because you, Mr Speaker, did not require the Prime Minister to withdraw what he said. In accordance with long practice and the conventions of the parliament, Mr Speaker, you might at least have asked the Prime Minister, `Did you make that remark?'. Then the Prime Minister would have been required to make up his mind on the spot whether he was going to lie again—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Bennelong will withdraw that.
—Or whether he was going to be deliberately economical with the truth again. I withdraw. I have more respect for the standing orders than the Prime Minister does.
—Order! The honourable member for Bennelong knows that I have given a ruling in respect of the use of words. He will withdraw.

—I withdraw it. I did 30 seconds ago, Mr Speaker. I repeat that you, Mr Speaker, did not even ask the Prime Minister whether he had made that remark. In my experience, when there is some legitimate doubt as to whether a remark has been made, normally the Speaker would ask the person, `Did you make the remark complained of?'. If the answer is, `Yes, I made that remark', the Speaker then asks the opposition, `Do you find that remark offensive?'. If the opposition says, `Yes, we do find that remark offensive', the Speaker invites the person who has offended to withdraw the remark.

PARA.TAB: What we find very disturbing on this occasion, Mr Speaker, is that you did not even ask the Prime Minister whether he made the remark. I do not have the sharpest hearing in this House, and I do not mind admitting it, but I heard it very, very clearly. I repeat the words: `This is designed to keep vermin like you off the air'. That is the stock-in-trade language of a man who now parades himself as a great Australian statesman. I think the people of Australia ought to be aware of this. This is the man who would have himself hailed as the great healer of the nation. That is how much contempt he has for the ordinary people of this nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to a point of order, Mr Speaker, on the very issue we are debating. There was a remark made from the opposite side which was clearly heard on this side. That is why two of us rose to our feet. We ask that that remark be withdrawn if that is the basis of what is being said.

—Order! As I tried to say in the explanation, honourable members on both sides of the House would be aware that at different times people are tending to say words which can be taken as offensive. I suggest to both sides that in the course of this debate honourable members should remain silent and let the speaker be heard in relative silence.

—The gravamen of our complaint and the reason why I took the unusual step of moving dissent from your ruling, Mr Speaker, is that I drew your attention to the words used by the Prime Minister. In anybody's language they were very offensive words, the sorts of words that bring this institution into contempt—not the sorts of words that should be used by any member of this parliament, and certainly not by a man who would want himself to be regarded as some kind of representative of the essential unity of this nation. This bloke, who is now running around Australia trying to get everybody to believe that he is a great statesman, has so much respect for this institution that he regards all of us collectively as vermin. They were his words.
—I wish to raise a point of order, Mr Speaker. This is not an occasion for a generalised discussion about the motives and attitudes of members of this House; it is a question for discussion—
—Of course it is.

—No, it is not. It is a question for discussion about whether or not a standing order has been properly enforced. The motives and attitudes of all of us sitting in this chamber are of complete irrelevance to that.
—The Leader of the House again goes to the question of the technical relevance of a motion of this nature. The honourable member for Bennelong will come back to that aspect.

—I repeat that the core of our complaint in relation to this point of order is that a remark was made which was clearly audible to me and four or five of my colleagues on the front bench, and I am sure clearly audible to the Leader of the House, who is an honest man. I challenge him to deny having heard what the Prime Minister said. The Leader of the House is an honest bloke and I trust him on questions such as this. He knows quite well that the Prime Minister made the remark complained of.

PARA.TAB: We resent this most of all and have moved this motion of dissent because I would have expected you, Mr Speaker, to at least have asked, `Prime Minister, did you make that statement?'. It would then have been on the Prime Minister to decide whether he was going to be deliberately economical with the truth again, as is his wont, or whether he was going to own up to the fact and withdraw the remark. But you did not do that, Mr Speaker, and that is why I am moving dissent from your ruling, and that is why I think you are wrong. That is why I think, for good and substantive reasons, not insubstantial reasons, the parliament ought to support my motion of dissent from your ruling.

The background of this has to be understood. There has been almost two hours of debate on a matter of very important parliamentary principle: whether there should be equality of rebroadcasting opportunities of the proceedings of question time and the proceedings in this parliament. One must bear in mind that the whole substance of the government's defence of its decision to repudiate you, Mr Speaker, and all the other members of the committee, is that if anything is said that should not be said there is machinery available under the standing orders to make certain that those words are withdrawn.

This is exactly what I decided to do; I decided to put that argument to test. I thought, `Maybe the Leader of the House is right, maybe the honourable member for Watson is right and maybe I have it all wrong. What I will do is take a point of order and rely on the interpretation of those opposite of the standing orders, the forms and conventions of this parliament. I will say, "Mr Speaker, the Prime Minister has said something; it is very offensive to be collectively described as vermin'". Those words may come freely to the lips of the Prime Minister, but they are not the sorts of words somebody aspiring to be some great national hero should be using. He freely uses those sorts of words. Against that background, I listened to a very impassioned speech from the honourable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding), who I think makes a very interesting contribution to the deliberations of this parliament. I thought that maybe I had got it all wrong and that maybe I was under a total misapprehension as to how the standing orders should operate.

I thought I would put it to the test; that I would do the very thing the government said could be done to stop remarks such as, `You are all vermin' being made without there being a requirement that it be withdrawn. So I put it to the test. I said, `Let's find out whether what those opposite have been saying is fair dinkum or not; let's find out whether my understanding of how the standing orders operate is fair dinkum'. It did not take very long to find out who was right and who was wrong. Mr Speaker, you did not even ask the Prime Minister whether he had made the remark. I know that you may not be on speaking terms with him at the present time as a result of what happened this morning, but at least you might have done it, Mr Speaker.

Time and time again when there have been exchanges such as this across the floor of the House, the normal practice of the Speaker is to ask the person who made the allegedly offensive remark, `Did you make that remark?'. That has happened from time immemorial. The honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown), who is a practitioner of this House, knows that that is the case; the honourable member for Melbourne Ports, who is a practitioner of this place, knows that is the situation; and so does the Leader of the House. Yet we are expected to cop a ruling such as this, having been lectured for two hours about how balanced, fair, reasonable and decent the standing orders of this place are, and having been told that they are all designed to stop ministers, and Prime Ministers in particular, making offensive attacks on the opposition.

The complaint made by the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) in his contribution to the debate was to the effect that the nature of the standing orders is that generalised slurs cannot be withdrawn. That was our very argument. It is the reason that half an hour ago you, Mr Speaker, unconscionably loaded the rules of this House even more in favour of the government. That is why I took the point of order. I thought that at the very least, against the background of this whole incident, you would have said, `Prime Minister, did you say collectively to the opposition, "This is designed to keep vermin like you off the air."?'. Those words were said clearly by the Prime Minister.

You said, `There is a lot of noise during divisions and it is often very hard to hear'. Why did you not say to the Prime Minister, `I did not hear what you said, but the honourable member for Bennelong claims you said to the opposition, "This is designed to keep vermin like you off the air".'? Why did you not say, `Prime Minister, did you make the remark complained of'? The Prime Minister then would have been able either to be economical with the truth again, deliberately mislead the public and the parliament again or, alternatively—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! You again are lapsing into using euphemisms for the same description that I have asked members not to use.
—The Australian public understands exactly what I am saying.
—Will you withdraw that?
—Withdraw which remark?
—As I said, `economical with the truth' is only a euphemism—euphemisms for what I have ruled are not permissible.
—Are you asking me to withdraw the expression `deliberately economical with the truth'?
—I am.
—You are asking me to withdraw `deliberately economical with the truth'.
—I am.
—Can I say `economical with the truth'?
—You will withdraw.

—Of course I will withdraw because I have other things to say. That can be dealt with on some other occasion. I think that is a very rough ruling, but we are quite used to it. I simply say again that the normal practice of this place while that division was being taken would have been for you, on complaint, to have asked the person complained about, `Did you make the remark?'. I have heard you do that on a number of occasions in the short time you have been Speaker. I heard your predecessor do it on many occasions and I have heard his predecessor do it on many occasions. I have sat here under something like seven or eight Speakers; and that is the normal, sensible, rational and intelligent thing to do if you have not heard what has been said. It puts the person on the spot; he has to be truthful.

PARA.TAB: But you did not do that. You let the Prime Minister off. You were not prepared to even ask him. I know there is probably a lot of bad blood between you and the Prime Minister at present as a result of the way you were rolled, repudiated and insulted—effectively, all the mates voted no confidence in you. They have really done a Cope job on you, without any doubt in the world. I know there is bad blood; you might at least have shown some modicum of respect for the forms of this House by asking the Prime Minister, `Did you say what is complained of you?'. But you did not. That is why I moved dissent from your ruling and that is why I hope those fine practitioners of the parliamentary art on the other side of the chamber will join us on this occasion.

You have given a bad ruling. Through that bad ruling you have demonstrated the force and veracity of the case we put this morning. You have demonstrated the arrogance and hubris of the way your party runs this parliament. You have highlighted the foul language of the Prime Minister and his insulting way of dealing with people he does not agree with. Basically, I think you have given a very bad ruling. It ought to be overturned; and I hope the parliament does overturn it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?

TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

—I take a point of order. A dissent from the Speaker's ruling is a highly technical debate. It cannot proceed by canvassing material that is utterly irrelevant to the question of whether you made a correct ruling on this occasion.

—I suggested in the course of the contribution by the mover of this motion that it is a technical motion and, accordingly, have requested on a couple of occasions the speaker to come back to it. I request the Leader of the National Party to do so.

—I come right back to it centre stage by saying that you are custodian of the proceedings of this House at all times and that you occupy the chair. As custodian at all times, in division and out of division, you have certain responsibilities to discharge to members on both sides of the House.

PARA.TAB: In terms of discharging those duties, there are precedents which are relevant, including the way that the Australian Labor Party dumped on Speaker Cope at the time. I will not dwell on it, but you know, Mr Speaker, that if this goes to the absolute test you will get dumped on in a similar manner.

Further, Mr Speaker, hanging over your office and hanging over you in this context is the undermining of your position which flows from the committee report which you gave to this parliament. You had total confidence in the committee. It was a unanimous report of the committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order.

—Order! The Leader of the House has anticipated what I was going to say. We are getting back into debate that has already taken place in this place. I respectfully ask the Leader of the National Party to come to the technical aspects of this particular debate.

What we had, as the honourable member for Bennelong correctly pointed out, were interjections by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) of the worst kind, using terms like `What are you grubs up to now?' and `We are going to get you vermin off the air'.

PARA.TAB: Those interjections are in keeping with some of his other interjections such as `Like a dog returning to its vomit' and `pansies in the Senate'. They are all definitely relevant.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order. It is irrelevant to the debate to read a sort of taxonomy of terms like that without clearly establishing why those terms are relevant. The honourable member for Farrer is not even citing the points of time when it was required that they be withdrawn.
—The Leader of the National Party will come back to the technical aspects of this debate.
—The opposition is clear cut on this, whilst the government is extremely sensitive after the shambles which occurred in this morning's motion. I specifically refer to standing order 78, which says:

SPEECH.PARA: When the attention of the Speaker is drawn to words used, he shall determine whether or not they are offensive or disorderly.

You have failed on that count, Mr Speaker. That is charge No. 1 today. You had the responsibility to carry out standing order 78 in the interests of upholding your duties as Speaker. You failed to uphold that responsibility because you did not ask the Prime Minister whether he used those words and whether, therefore, he would withdraw those words. I take the point of order of the honest Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) and on that technical point, Mr Speaker, I quote from page 485 of the House of Representatives Practice:

PARA.TAB: It is the duty of the Chair to intervene when offensive or disorderly words are used either by the Member addressing the House or any Member present. When attention is drawn by a Member to words used, the Chair determines whether or not they are offensive or disorderly.
Once the Chair determines that offensive or disorderly words have been used, the Chair intervenes and asks that the words be withdrawn.

SPEECH.PARA: So the technical aspects are there in very clear-cut terms, both in the standing orders and in the House of Representatives Practice. So it was not an unreasonable hurdle which we invited you to jump today in terms of maintaining the traditions of this parliament, but you did not jump, Mr Speaker. Why not? It is because you have been got at. You have been got at in the last 24 hours in a way which left you swinging in the breeze in a very unsatisfactory way for members of the House of Representatives.

PARA.TAB: I draw the attention of the House to the fact that it is the Prime Minister who is the cause of both the previous motion and this proper dissent motion being moved today. It was also the Prime Minister, who was then the Treasurer, who said on 8 March 1984:

SPEECH.PARA: Yet we have this piece of vermin, the Leader of the National Party, here today attacking Mr Ducker on his position as Chairman—
Immediately, the Deputy Speaker, Mrs Child, intervened and said:
The Treasurer will withdraw that remark.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's right.

—Action was taken on the run, and it was entirely appropriate, as the Leader of the House says. It was also entirely appropriate in the circumstances here this morning because—to anticipate the argument of the Leader of the House—there was no let-out merely because it took place in a division.

PARA.TAB: Mr Speaker, I am sure you regard yourself as collecting your pay for each and every hour of the day that you occupy the chair. That is quite appropriate. You are on the job whilst ever you sit in that chair. You are on the job in terms of maintaining the decorum of the parliament whilst ever you sit in that chair. It is entirely appropriate for members to take points of order in divisions. There are procedures for that. It is entirely appropriate that you respond to those points of order. However, we are moving a motion of dissent because you stopped short in your response.

Yesterday you responded on the matter of the Ku Klux Klan. You will remember that the Special Minister of State (Mr Walker) said that the members of the opposition were members of the Ku Klux Klan. That was a pretty abrasive comment to make on the floor of the House. You immediately responded and asked the Special Minister of State to withdraw that comment. Why then did you not require the Prime Minister today to withdraw the equally bad statement that he made in relation to vermin; a statement that was clearly heard on both sides of the House?

Mr Speaker, you have torn up convention by your conduct in the chair today. You, sir, have lost the confidence of members on this side of the House by your conduct in the chair this day, and on other days as well. You, sir, have presided over a situation where there has been a steady deterioration in the number of questions that members are allowed to ask in the course of question time.

To your credit, on 6 October you ruled in part that answers should be relevant and `not excessively long'. However, you immediately drifted away from that ruling. That is why we charge you this day, Mr Speaker, by virtue of this dissent motion, with failing to respond to standing order 78. In the context of what that standing order required of you, you should at least have asked the Prime Minister whether he made that statement. If he had, you should have told him that it was unparliamentary language and required him to withdraw it.

That has happened in the past. It happened as late as yesterday, but today something is different. We know what is different. It is not only the shadow of Cope; it is also the shadow of Keating. We remember the time when the then Treasurer went around to the office of the then Speaker, the honourable member for Watson (Mr Leo McLeay), and `splattered blood around the walls' to knock the then Speaker into shape. We know that the Speaker lives in dread of a telephone call from the Prime Minister's office after question time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I take a point of order. This has absolutely nothing to do with the technical nature of this debate.
—The Leader of the National Party will come back to the technical aspect.

—The Speaker can only handle the technical proceedings of this House if he feels that he has the complete confidence of the Prime Minister and the government. Clearly, in the aftermath of the proceedings of the last 24 hours, the Speaker feels very lonely indeed. That does not excuse his conduct in not taking appropriate action during this division.

PARA.TAB: We have seen a double standard being used today in respect of the core matter of this dissent motion moved by the honourable member for Bennelong. There is obviously one rule for members of the opposition and one rule for this Prime Minister. This Prime Minister lashes out at people with the sorts of interjections which are relevant to the technicality of this debate. Those interjections include terms such as `alley cat', `dullards', `brain damaged' and `friends of tax cheats'.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have already been through that. The Leader of the National Party will come back to the motion.

—Mr Speaker, I take a point of order. Unless those epithets are used with accompanying documentation to show that they were withdrawn, and the circumstances in which they were withdrawn, they can scarcely be relevant to this debate.
—The Leader of the House has made a valid point. The Leader of the National Party will come back to the technical aspects.

—Some were required to be withdrawn. The brilliant proof of that is right here in the Hansard of 8 March 1984, page 752, which records an exact replica of this incident. When the then Treasurer used the word `vermin', he was instantly required to withdraw it. Today, nine years later, when in the course of this debate he again used the word `vermin', as verified by my colleagues on the front bench, as can be verified by you if you act honestly, why was he not required to withdraw? The answer for the Leader of the House, when he speaks at the dispatch box, is to confirm that the Prime Minister did utter that word `vermin' and therefore confirm that indeed this motion of dissent is correct and he should in fact withdraw.

PARA.TAB: So I make the point, Mr Speaker, that we have absolute double standards in relation to the application of your duties as custodian of the responsibilities of this House. It is an unacceptable double standard, and it is a double standard which will only be addressed if this dissent motion is carried by the House on this occasion, because otherwise we will have a continuing deterioration of fair conduct and fair play and modus operandi in relation to the proceedings of this House.

The government, the opposition and the Independents are all entitled to reasonable protection under the standing orders and under parliamentary practice and the parliamentary conventions. The convention, the precedent, is absolute. Here is the word `vermin'—it was asked to be withdrawn. It was the same culprit then as today, the Prime Minister up to his mischief once again. Shame on him. But the main point of this debate is you, Mr Speaker, and your discharge of the onerous responsibilities that you have as Speaker of this House.

Had you asked one other question on the occasion, none of this dissent would have taken place. That was simply, in accordance with longstanding convention, to invite the Prime Minister to confirm or otherwise whether he had stated those words and then invite him to withdraw them. That is not too much of a hurdle in all the circumstances. It is not mitigated by the fact that it took place in division; not at all. There are responsibilities you are required to have and continue to have in division. It is for those reasons, Mr Speaker, that we are absolute in our support of the dissent motion and point out to you, sir, that you have failed in the conduct of the duties of the House and in your responsibilities to the House by your total and abject failure to require of the Prime Minister that he withdraw those comments. They are unparliamentary and unacceptable, and therefore there should have been no hesitation on your part in asking for that withdrawal. I support and second the dissenting motion before the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, in all dissent debates you are in the difficult situation that you cannot respond. You are in a position as Speaker where you rely persistently in this chamber on the help of members of parliament to uphold your high office. Of course, you are not being assisted by the way in which the opposition continues to behave in this place.

PARA.TAB: Let me go to the substance of the debate as to whether or not your ruling was correct.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Leader of the House might resume his seat for a minute. Since honourable members are so caught up with standing orders and the roles that people play, I once again bring to their attention standing order 55, which says:

INTERJECT.PARA: When a Member is speaking, no Member may converse aloud or make any noise or disturbance to interrupt him.
In the spirit of this debate, I ask for honourable members on my left to show some restraint so the minister can be heard.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank you for your protection, Mr Speaker, but it is also a protection of your position, because at least I am one of the members of parliament standing in this debate who are defending your integrity and the accuracy of your rulings. And so you should be defended, and so you should be assisted by all members of the House in this regard.

PARA.TAB: The last opposition spokesman, the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer), got up attempting and, I do agree, to start—unusually for the opposition in this debate—to address the technicalities of this issue when he pointed out that the term `vermin', used on a particular occasion, had been obliged to be withdrawn. So it should have in those circumstances. It was quite clear from the context that the honourable member for Farrer described that it was being presented in the course of a debate. Obviously the then Treasurer was standing at the dispatch box making that point, the word was called upon to be withdrawn and it was withdrawn. In the context of the debate it was, firstly, clearly audible to the Speaker; secondly, in the context of proceedings which would be recorded in Hansard; and, thirdly, picked up by the opposition at that point of time, and at that point of time a withdrawal was called for. In all those circumstances, everything that happened in that situation was perfectly understandable, and a withdrawal was called for and the word was appropriately withdrawn.

Likewise, there may be circumstances in which the House is effectively in session, Hansard is recording, debate is going on, exchanges take place across the chamber, words are used and the Speaker may not hear those words. When those words are drawn to his attention, he will seek to ascertain whether or not those particular words have been used and subsequently in the course of that debate—
Mr Tuckey interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Stop heckling and listen. In the course of that type of occurrence, it is virtually mandatory on the Speaker to make those sorts of queries and to establish whether or not offence has been given.

PARA.TAB: That is in the ordinary course of debate. Any reading of Parliamentary Practice, even a cursory reading, would cause honourable members to comprehend that what takes place outside the processes of recorded debate in this chamber effectively has different practices applied to it. Let me assist the House by quoting not from any views that I might have but from an appropriate authority in that regard, and that is, of course, House of Representatives Practice—

TALK.START.PARA: —What page?
—Page 311. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: Decorum should prevail during a division, and it is not in order for Members to engage in debate or exchange remarks across the Chamber. Conversation audible to the Chair has been regarded as disorderly. Remarks made during a division are not regarded as part of the proceedings of the House and are not recorded by Hansard.

There is clearly a very different situation applying. If during a division the Speaker hears across the chamber a set of remarks being made, he may choose—he is not obliged to, he may choose—to intervene to require a withdrawal or some other process to quieten the place down. It is clearly a different situation from that when the person is operating in the normal course of debate in this place, and that differential has effectively been established by the operations of these standing orders.

PARA.TAB: Quite clearly you did not hear any remarks passed across the chamber during that division, Mr Speaker. If you had, you may have chosen to cause those to be withdrawn or have chosen to ignore them. The fact of the matter is that you did not hear any remarks that were exchanged across the chamber. You will never get to hear or read those remarks because any remarks passed across the chamber during a division will simply not be recorded and not enter into the parliamentary record.

The point of seeking withdrawal of unparliamentary language or of epithets that honourable members find offensive and all the rest of it is that what is said in this chamber goes into the record, is capable of being disseminated and stands against the member or members concerned for all time, as long as the country shall last and records are kept. That is one of the reasons, apart from preserving good order in the place, why the Speaker acts to protect the reputation of members when there is a requirement for him to do so. But none of that occurs in the course of an interchange in a division, unless people are silly enough to want to place that interchange on the record subsequently. During a division none of that occurs. Therefore, the Speaker is in a situation where, in order to maintain the order of the place, if he hears a discussion that he finds unparliamentary or whatever, he may act to deal with it, but he is not obliged to query anyone in the chamber on remarks that may be exchanged during that period of time, because those remarks are not part of the proceedings of this House. They are not part of the proceedings of this chamber.

I might say that, of course, honourable members do have to be a little careful because remarks that are exhaled in those exchanges are not necessarily the subject of coverage by privilege either. From time to time, in some of the interchanges that I have heard, remarks have simply been directed at a generality and are, therefore, unlikely to be the subject of any legal action, as it is virtually impossible to libel a class. Considering some of the epithets that I hear across the chamber from time to time directed personally at individual members about the legality of their actions or the truthfulness with which they conduct themselves, it would be as well for members of this chamber to recognise that they are not necessarily covered by parliamentary privilege during a division. It is a pretty open question in legal circles as to whether or not that is the case. There is argument both at state parliamentary level and from this chamber that goes both ways on that issue. Clearly, there is precedent that establishes a different order of events for what is taking place when we are officially in session and another set of arrangements for when we are not actually formally engaged in the proceedings of this place.

I get back to the point. It is only sensible that the chamber should recognise that. It is sensible that the chamber should have one set of attitudes and one set of procedures about words that will become part of the historical record and therefore need corrections, and other sets of words which do not require that at all. When the House is in its full proceedings, those standing orders, 77 and 78, apply that oblige action from the Speaker to deal with that sort of problem, whether or not the Speaker happens to have heard remarks during an interchange. If those remarks are drawn to his attention the Speaker shall act under standing orders 77 and 78 to deal with them. In the course of a division, the position is put as permissive; and House of Representatives Practice only goes to describing a set of circumstances in which he, the Speaker, has himself heard the remarks that have been exchanged across the chamber. The Speaker has quite clearly established that in this case that was not the case.

The opposition, in using this motion as another way of getting at the government or whatever, and choosing to do so through you, Mr Speaker, is effectively trying to turn important distinctions in standing orders on their head. Do they not always get into it when they get an opportunity to do so! The real standing orders and the actual application of the standing orders are neither here nor there as far as the opposition is concerned, and those opposite will take any opportunity not to challenge you on the veracity of the way in which you control standing orders but simply fling epithets at you and attempt to get at the government via that process. It is simply a standard pattern of practice on the part of the opposition for mauling the Speaker.

You, sir, in your ruling, were absolutely correct. You are entitled to the defence of members of this House, whether or not they like what they think they heard from the Prime Minister, whether or not they think that what they think they heard from the Prime Minister was in accordance with what would normally be the interchange in this place. All of that is irrelevant. What is at point here is whether or not you are correctly upholding the standing orders. That is all that is at point here in this particular matter—not whether we like the proceedings, but whether or not you correctly uphold standing orders. Manifestly, sir, you have done so; manifestly you have done so in so far as this parliamentary practice is concerned, and as far as the standing orders are concerned.

So as far as we are concerned, on this side of the House anyway, Mr Speaker, you are entitled to a defence on this matter. Not only are you entitled to a defence, you are entitled to support as clearly you are correct. I move:
That the question be now put.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Original question put:
That the motion (Mr Howard's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to inform the House that the Special Minister of State, Mr Walker, will be absent from question time today. In his absence I will take questions on Mabo.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —They are the shags on the rock over there. Questions relating to other areas of ministerial responsibility should be addressed to the Minister for Finance, Mr Willis, who is currently representing the Treasurer.

—My question is directed to the Acting Treasurer. Given that the Prime Minister acknowledged on the 7.30 Report last night that the compensation bill for native title is likely to be many hundreds of millions of dollars, and in light of the Treasurer's commitment on 18 August that there will be no further increases in taxes in this parliament, will he give a guarantee to the Australian public that the federal government will not increase taxes in order to pay for that compensation?

—In referring to the Prime Minister's comments last night, the questioner should also have mentioned that the Prime Minister said that this bill for Mabo compensation would accrue over many years—in fact, decades. In those circumstances, clearly the kinds of costs which were mentioned by the Prime Minister on that program, hundreds of millions of dollars, are not likely to be dumped on the budget in the course of the next year or so. This is something which will accumulate and, clearly, will have to be taken into account in formulating the budget in future years as we assess the size of that compensation bill. At this stage we clearly cannot foresee what the exact amounts will be in the next year or two or three, but we are clearly aware that there will be an accumulating bill to some degree. This is something we will take into account in future budget arrangements.

PARA.TAB: In making our decisions on Mabo and making our decisions in relation to accepting the liability for compensation, we did so with our eyes wide open and with full recognition of the fact that this was a highly appropriate action for the Commonwealth to be taking and that it would be impossible in the circumstances to take any other approach such as to deny compensation. For instance, would the opposition want to impose the compensation on the owners of leases? That would obviously be extremely difficult and would cause enormous problems for industry. That would not be possible.

The states will be liable to some degree for compensation bills accumulating in the future, but clearly the Commonwealth has to accept a substantial liability in all those circumstances. That is the best outcome for the nation, and the nation as a whole, through the Commonwealth budget, will have to pay that bill as it accumulates. But it is not something which will force an immediate major adjustment of the budget; it is something which will accumulate on the budget over ensuing years for the next decade or two.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Attorney-General. Will the Attorney-General advise the House how the government's native title package will ensure the states maintain control of the land management system while ensuring that native title interests will not be compromised?

—I thank the honourable member for his question. Obviously the Commonwealth's approach to the High Court decision has always been based on two essential lines: primarily to achieve a just and fair outcome for the interests of Aboriginal and Islander people in Australia but, secondly, obviously to preserve the integrity and certainty of Australia's land management system. We have always recognised in that process that the states are the central land managers in our system of government. Accordingly, the Commonwealth has attempted to obtain basic agreement with the states as to those measures which are necessary to ensure that the states can legitimately maintain that role.

PARA.TAB: Firstly, the legislation will enable the states to validate those grants and interests which may have been rendered invalid by the existence of native title and the operation of any other law. Secondly, the states will be able to control the issue of grants of interest over native title land by establishing their own processes, provided that those processes meet the criteria set out in the Commonwealth's legislation. That is a very important point, of course, in that most of the debate has been about the economic use of land and how that would be determined. The Commonwealth's proposal will enable the states to maintain control over that process. That, of course, is the core of the land management issues which have been of concern to the states.

It should be noted that this does mark a very reasonable and commendable attitude on behalf of Aboriginal and Islander people to accept this part of the package, given that they do have—and I think with some justification—some concerns about bodies like mining wardens courts, given their past experience of such bodies. To come to a situation where they accept the states being able to maintain control over such a process is a major point in gaining agreement on this package.

The Commonwealth will, of course, ensure that the interests of native titleholders are not compromised in the way in which the states act in this matter. To that extent, we will have to be satisfied by a state that it will have satisfactory procedures for notifying interested parties of proposals to make grants over land matters and make sure that native titleholders know what is going on. But there are provisions for bona fide negotiations with native titleholders. The hearings of objections by a recognised state tribunal will take account of a wide range of considerations, such as the effect of the proposed grant on the preservation of native title and its effect on native titleholders' way of life, protection of matters like sacred sites, and so on.

In all, this is a good proposal which enables the states to maintain their proper role in land management, at the same time ensuring that the interests of native titleholders are maintained. I note that the package has been broadly welcomed by state leaders. Clearly, they want to see the detail, and that is understandable. But we have had positive statements, for instance, from the Premier of Victoria, Mr Kennett, who made the very valid and correct point that this is an issue of such national importance that it should not be put in the corner of party political debate. He urged all Australians to look at it in that way. I certainly urge opposition members to adopt the advice of their Victorian state colleague.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also directed to the Attorney-General. I ask: will respondents to native title claims receive financial help from the Commonwealth for their legal costs?

—This is a matter which has been raised with the government by industry groups, notably the National Farmers Federation. The government does have the matter under consideration and I will be able to report more fully after those discussions are completed.

—Has the Prime Minister seen reports of a National Australia Bank business survey on the Australian economy? Can he provide the House with an assessment of the survey? Will the signs of an emerging consensus on fiscal policy, Mabo and industrial relations increase confidence and support economic expansion?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member very much for the question. The National Australia Bank survey released yesterday shows further signs of a pick-up in the recovery. It was a large survey of 750 firms. It indicates a continuing positive trend in the September quarter, with a pick-up in trading conditions, export sales, profitability, employment, and forward orders.

PARA.TAB: The indication is that the improved business conditions were broadly based, consistent with the Australian Chamber of Manufactures survey yesterday. ANSWER.PARA: The fact is, we took a principle position against four taxes. We stayed rock solid on that position. We were disappointed that in the end we didn't win.

It seems that it is the lot of the opposition leader to come second in all contests.
