The Liberal Party, after its defeat, was in a mood for playing politics with everything. In the short term that might be a winner. In the long term I think it does great damage to the way the Liberal Party is perceived in the community at large.
In an article written in the Advertiser by Mr Olney—

TALK.START.PARA: —This is not relevant.
—It goes to the same point about the budget and the budget tactics. The article said this:

ANSWER.PARA: One source said, `There was some consternation in the party room about the level of complacency and confidence about the party's position so soon after the election loss. It was a bit disillusioning'. `There's a feeling that we'll never learn', another said. One MP caused laughter when he pointed out that he'd heard the same optimistic presentation shortly after the 1990, 1987 and 1984 elections which the coalition had lost.
That is the same point as I made last week: the coalition is always easily pleased in defeat and always consoled in opposition. That adds a lot of cheer to the parliamentary process.

PARA.TAB: Let me conclude by saying that there is a recovery coming through now which is broadly based. One of the shadows hanging over it is the opposition's behaviour in the Senate. Even with that behaviour, the budget bills are being passed, bond yields are falling as a consequence, and the opposition is left marginalised and sidelined—just like the cartoon today in the Canberra Times. Members of the opposition are like shags on a rock. They are sitting up above water level as the shags are handling their business with them, let me put it that way. Even the opposition's obstructionism will not be able to stop the recovery coming through.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Attorney-General. It is a simple, direct question: will valid pastoral leases extinguish all native titles?

—The answer to that is to be drawn from the judgments of their justices in Mabo No. 2. I think it is the balance of legal opinion—a majority of the judges, four of them, concluded this—that a valid issuing of a leasehold interest by a government would have extinguished native title. It certainly is the case that it would have extinguished it to the extent of any inconsistency. That means any leaseholders in this country, be they pastoral or otherwise, can be totally confident if they have a valid lease—

PARA.TAB: Mr Costello interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I warn the honourable member for Higgins.
—They can be totally confident, if they have a valid lease, that they can exercise and enjoy their full rights under that lease. So there is no question whatsoever—
—What about claims that will arise?

—The Leader of the Opposition asks me about claims. Obviously, every Australian has a right to go to court and make a claim. I can make a claim against the property of the Leader of the Opposition, if it is my inclination to do so. The important point is not whether someone has a right under our law to make a claim; the important point is the prospects of success of that claim. That is something which the opposition is trying to whip up fear and concern about amongst the Australian people. Of course, opposition members know full well that, in order to succeed, a native title claimant has, first, to satisfy the test established in the High Court—that is, the unbroken, continuing association of the claimant with the land in question—and, secondly, to prove that no inconsistent action of government has extinguished the title.

PARA.TAB: From the facts, we know that every existing titleholder is going to be guaranteed title either because in the first place the titleholder had a valid lease which has not impacted upon native title whatsoever or because in those limited numbers of cases where native title could, in operation with some other law—say, the Racial Discrimination Act—possibly invalidate the title, the government, by its legislation, is ensuring certainty and continuance of title.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training. Can the minister advise the House of the implications of the Victorian government's program of school closures and its implications for Commonwealth support for education in that state?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Free The Hon R.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Dunkley for his question, but I must say that responding to it gives me no pleasure. As the honourable member would know, the Commonwealth's commitment to schools in Victoria is second to none. This year the Commonwealth is spending over three-quarters of a billion dollars on school education in that state. That is an increase of 1.6 per cent in a tight budgetary environment. But schools—as the Victorian Minister for Education, Mr Hayward, is constantly telling us all—are primarily a state government responsibility. It is a responsibility that Mr Hayward appears intent on abrogating. At the same time as the Commonwealth is increasing its financial support to Victoria's schools, Mr Hayward appears to be intent on dismantling one of the best education systems in the country.

PARA.TAB: My department has prepared an analysis of education expenditure in this year's Victorian budget, and I must say it is a chronicle of shame. Victorian government spending on primary education is down 5.3 per cent. I know that this is a decision which would not have the support of the opposition spokesman on schools in this place, the honourable member for Menzies. In an interview in the Canberra Times last month, the honourable member is on the record as wanting `more money spent on the early stages of education'. He went on to say:
The reality has been that primary schools have missed out in terms of the proportion of education dollars for a long time.

ANSWER.PARA: I hope that the honourable member for Menzies will take the opportunity to share his views with Mr Hayward as well as with the Canberra Times. I must say that primary schools are not the Victorian government's only victims. It has also slashed spending on secondary education by 5.9 per cent, and spending on schools support is down 5.8 per cent. If all of this were not enough, in addition Mr Hayward wants to sack 3,000 teachers.

PARA.TAB: The raw figures themselves are bad enough but they disguise the real impact of the Hayward hatchet. The real impact is on people such as the principal of Bulleen Primary School, Mr Kevin Maguire, who wrote a eulogy in last Saturday's Age for his school, which is to be closed. I will quote a little from Mr Maguire's letter because it makes the human tragedy of Victorian schools all the clearer:
Yesterday, my school died. Killed by Government fiat. Sacrificed to economic expediency.
With it dies a little bit of myself. No thanks for the countless hours devoted to ensuring that the school functions effectively.
With it dies a culture developed over the past 30 years. One that concerns itself with fairness and equity.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Maguire's school, like hundreds of others in Victoria, is being closed or is at risk of being closed because the Victorian government decided that they are an easy mark.

PARA.TAB: Honourable members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for O'Connor and the honourable member for Ballarat will cease interjecting across the chamber. Those on my right will also cease interjecting.

—Mr Maguire may well become a target under the Victorian government's infamous order 140, which was circulated to schools in that state last month. Under order 140, Victorian teachers have been banned from speaking out publicly against the Kennett government. More than that, order 140 also bars teachers from accepting gifts and from lending money to each other. I will just put aside the letter to the Age. If Mr Maguire has been guilty of lending a colleague $5, he may well be 140ed in the near future.

PARA.TAB: The Victorian government is not just destroying school communities; it is also doing its petty best to make their ends humiliating. Today's Herald-Sun reports:

ANSWER.PARA: Schools on the State Government's closure list have had their budgets "frozen" . . .

Their principals are also forbidden to spend more than $50 on their schools without departmental permission. It looks as though Mr Hayward is getting rattled by the prospect of open debate of his policies because he is planning to end all judicial rights of appeal against any of his decisions to close schools in Victoria.

PARA.TAB: It is ironic that all of this is happening in Victoria, the supposed cradle of liberalism, the home of Robert Gordon Menzies, who said that his party spoke for the `forgotten people'. The people the heirs of Menzies are now forgetting are the kids of Victoria. Mr Hayward keeps telling us that he runs Victoria's schools. In conclusion, while the Commonwealth is happy to provide all the supplementary funding possible under budgetary constraints, it would actually help if Mr Hayward got round to running his schools instead of closing them.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Attorney-General. Why does the government intend to include a preamble in the Mabo bill expressing the view that valid pastoral leases should extinguish native title when, as the Prime Minister informed the House yesterday, `the preamble is not part of the act (and) would not change the law'? If the preamble is intended to be an expression of what the common law ought to be as stated by the Prime Minister, why is it not included as a substantive measure in the bill? Lastly, given that his long answer to the last question was, in a word, no, what assurance can pastoralists put on the preamble to protect their valid leases against native title claims?

—As the honourable member would well understand, a preamble to an act is not an operative part of the act but the preamble to this bill will be an important part inasmuch as it will state the objectives which the government is attempting to maintain with the act as well as stating what we believe the position of the law to be.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member wants the government, essentially, to extinguish absolutely all possibility of native title rights existing in pastoral or other interests in this country.
Mr Reith interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Flinders has asked a question.

—One would have to ask oneself: what is the basis of the concern and fear which the honourable member is suggesting? We have already had the position of Aboriginal and Islander people agreeing with the proposition that a validated lease will extinguish all native title in the pastoral lease. One would wonder whether Aboriginal and Islander leaders, having come to that conclusion about validated leases, would be rushing off to court trying to secure any sliver of rights which may remain in terms of valid positions. That is on the assumption that any such rights exist; whereas I think the balance of legal view is that, on the High Court decision, a valid issue of a leasehold has extinguished right. I have correspondence from the National Farmers Federation and it does not seem to have the same sort of concern about its position. Like most groups in society, it has come to the conclusion that the proposed legislation is a perfectly reasonable response to the Mabo case, and it does not see the difficulties which the honourable member has.

PARA.TAB: In that correspondence that I have received from the National Farmers Federation—if I recall it correctly—it says that its legal advice is that it thinks it is about a 99 per cent certainty that all valid pastoral lease has extinguished native title. I think the basis of the honourable member's question is totally fallacious. He is merely trying to whip up concern and fear in the Australian community, because those opposite are totally isolated on this issue. They are not supported by the National Farmers Federation or by the vast bulk of the mining industry. Certainly they will not be supported by Aboriginal and Islander people, and I do not believe they will be supported by fair-minded Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Community Services. I refer the minister to his recent consultations with local government representatives across Australia. Can the minister inform the House of the government's agenda for reform of local government and how it compares with alternative approaches; for example, the recent approach of the Court government in Western Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: HOUSING, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND COMMUNITY SERVICES

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. As he indicated in that question, I have been moving around Australia having extensive consultations with local government. At these consultations I have been discussing how reform of local government can be achieved by taking a more strategic and a more regional approach with larger and more efficient units of local government, supported by a population base and financial assets which can deliver efficiencies, structural reform and service delivery.

PARA.TAB: It must be noted how the directions of reform that I have been discussing with local government differ markedly from recent announcements by both the Victorian and Western Australian governments of structural changes to the boundaries and functions of their capital cities. The importance of our capital cities as economic, social and cultural centres is clearly vital. Decisions about the management of our cities can therefore have national importance; indeed, they can have international significance. It is within this context that changes to the structure and management of the cities of Perth and Melbourne give rise to serious concern.

The decision by the Court government to carve up the inner city, creating a CBD council, fails to address the importance of a strategic approach to the management of the city. Sound management of cities involves not only the golden mile of central city blocks but also the management of infrastructure, transport, and land use planning on the city fringe, and gateways to the city. This decision would result in a disjointed approach to proper planning and management of the city of Perth.

The Kennett government response to central city management has been to redraw boundaries in such a way that all of the city's economic, cultural and educational assets have been included in the one municipal council at the expense of residents. This decision directly contradicts the Victorian government's policy of repopulating the central city in inner ring suburbs. In fact, the population of the central city has been cut by one-third, traditional inner city communities have been cut by one-half and services to large public housing estates have effectively been placed in jeopardy.

These are decisions about local government. They are decisions about particular councils; but they affect the strategic centre of two major Australian cities and they set important precedents. Essentially, these conservative governments are setting the precedent of one rule for the inner areas, particularly the central business district, and another rule for other councils. While these governments preach amalgamation and while they seek to group councils into larger units, through these areas of vested interests and central business districts they have effectively acted against the residents. While they talk about the need to bring people back into the cities and to give cities again a human face, effectively, they are separating residents from those cities and reversing a trend, which they tend to support in overall terms, of repopulating inner suburbs.

So these decisions by these two conservative governments certainly run against any conceptual basis, certainly run against their rhetoric, are detrimental to those cities and will have a very serious impact on the inner suburban residents who will now carry a much greater rate burden and will force councils into arbitrary amalgamations which will certainly not be in the interests of good local government or representative, sensible reform in this important sphere of government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs inform the House whether the Mabo bill will include a definition of Aboriginality as it applies to potential claimants under the legislation? If so, what is that definition? If not, can the minister inform the House what definition of Aboriginality will apply to claims and litigation brought forward under the legislation to prevent false claims and to protect the rights of Aboriginal Australians?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tickner The Hon R.E.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —As long as I remain in this parliament, I do not think there will ever be an occasion when I come to this dispatch box with more regret about a question asked in the House than I do for this one asked by the honourable member for Cowper. I feel regret because the honourable member is someone who I believe possesses considerable integrity and who, until now, has had a continuing commitment to Aboriginal people, which I hope he regains.

PARA.TAB: I regret the question because it raises the same pernicious, destructive, divisive issue that the Leader of the National Party raised in a recent speech in Perth, where he would have the Australian community believe that Aboriginal people in this country should somehow be grateful to governments for their current living conditions and situations. In the same speech in Perth, he raised exactly the same line, and he has done a disservice to the honourable member for Cowper by getting him to ask this question because he should have asked it himself. In response to other matters raised in the question—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I am sorry to have to rise on this point of order but I need to make the point that this question is mine and nobody else's. I would suggest to the minister that the crux of the question was in the last two phrases: `to prevent false claims and to protect the rights of Aboriginal Australians'.
—The minister will answer the question.
—Mr Speaker, I am well aware of what the question was.
—Answer it then.

—I am answering it. Honourable members opposite might not like the answer, but I am answering it. In response to that part of the question that the honourable member has further alluded to, it is my understanding that thus far there has not been a need for any definitions to be raised and detailed in the bill because, dating back to the period of the Fraser government and before, governments have not had any difficulty in addressing this question in relation to matters concerning Aboriginal people and government programs. Should there be a need for any definition, I think that it would be appropriate to look to what the High Court of Australia said in relation to this matter and to consider, and give effect to, the statements that I thought enjoyed the unanimous support of this House. They ought not to be the subject of such bitter divisions. What we saw—
—Answer the question.

—I have answered the question. The question that has been raised is yet another attempt by the opposition to raise non-issues, to use the Mabo issue as a party political football. In the 1950s the conservative side of politics used to talk about reds under the beds. The modern-day approach is to talk about Aborigines under the bed. I ask the opposition to rise to the occasion and join with the people of this country—such as the Australian Council of Churches, the New South Wales farmers and all those people who are coming behind this government in supporting this historic legislation—who care about justice and the standing of this country in the eyes of the world. The question does the member a disservice. I regret that he asked it.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development. I ask the minister: is he aware of recent reports regarding the operation of the industrial supplies office network in relation to Commonwealth government purchasing. Can the minister inform the House of the initiatives by the government to enhance the opportunities for locally based companies in Commonwealth government purchasing?

—I thank the honourable member for Brisbane for his question and note in passing his chairing of a parliamentary inquiry which is looking at the broader issue of government purchasing. It is worth informing the House of the sheer magnitude of this issue, particularly in so far as it offers up very considerable opportunities for Australian business—small and medium size enterprises, most particularly. Each year the federal government alone purchases some $10 billion worth of goods and services. That figure is obviously dramatically increased when one takes into account the contribution of the state governments.

PARA.TAB: One manifestation of the federal government's approach to this issue is to ensure that Australian industry gets full and fair opportunity to participate against set criteria. Those criteria go to a range of policy objectives. There will be an opportunity in a little while to review how that process is working, particularly where devolution of purchasing authority has been a feature of the reorganisation of many departments and agencies. In this context there is an ongoing view in some parts of industry that purchasing officers are paying only lip-service to criteria other than price when they are making purchasing decisions and are maybe unfairly disadvantaging Australian companies. Last week, when I spoke at the Australian Chamber of Manufactures annual dinner, I indicated my support for putting Australian companies and workers first when `they have in terms of price, quality and associated issues earned that position'.

Another leg to this double of trying to ensure that Australian business gets plenty of opportunity to participate is the initiative of this government to try to move to a national network of industrial supplies offices, their purpose being to ensure that there is a sufficient flow of information to enable Australian companies to import replace by participating in opportunities as they arise. In that context, I regret to say that the Victorian ISO is engaging in what I consider to be petty rivalry. It is obstructing the move to a national network of industrial supplies offices. I have raised that matter with Premier Kennett in private discussion. Late last week I wrote to my counterpart industry ministers, including Mr Gude in Victoria.

In conclusion, I observe that the industrial supplies office network offers a very real opportunity to enhance the ability of small and medium size enterprise to be part of, at the national government level, a $10 billion purchasing program of goods and services compounded by the state contribution and then swamped by the private sector's involvement in this area. At federal government level, we want to see action taken to ensure that these petty rivalries, the attempt to prevent the national network from being established, are done away with and that we get on as joint partners in this issue to try to ensure that Australian business gets a fair crack of the whip.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence and relates to findings earlier this week by Melbourne coroner, Iain West, in the inquest into the deaths of five members of an RAAF Boeing 707 which crashed off the Victorian coast in October 1991. Has there been a Defence departmental cover-up as is suggested by the widows? Will litigation for Commonwealth negligence follow? What steps is the minister taking to review the coroner's findings? What assurances can I give one of the widows and her mother-in-law that they will be provided with all the facts rather than some abbreviated sanitised version?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has supplied me with an answer which I think goes to some of the points made by the honourable member for Groom. I will try to pick up from that, given that I think it is a serious question that he raised, and I do not intend to go through the normal argy-bargy with it here because it involves tragic circumstances.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I would have thought that opposition members would have been concerned about that, so they might bear with me. A number of issues have been raised by the spouses of the crew members involved in the 707 crash following the conclusion of the coronial inquiry. I do not intend to debate each point but to address central issues and deal with the appropriateness of actions taken by the RAAF.

PARA.TAB: It is clear that the findings brought down by the coroner earlier in the week are consistent with those of the RAAF board of inquiry. The speculation that there was some sort of cover-up by the RAAF is unfounded. The full board of inquiry report was made available to the families of the crew and was provided to the coroner to assist in his deliberations. I am also advised that the summary of the board of inquiry which was tabled in the Senate on 11 October 1992 fairly represents the conclusions of that report.

There has also been some criticism of the manner in which the spouses were briefed by the RAAF immediately following the accident. The circumstances of this situation were somewhat unique in that three of the spouses were serving RAAF members at the time of the accident. They were therefore aware of the accident before official advice and briefing could be provided. While these circumstances are unfortunate, the record of the air force and the other services in the manner in which they deal with briefing next of kin in such circumstances is, on the whole, good.

Let me turn now to the findings and recommendations made by the coroner. Both the inquest and the board of inquiry highlighted a deficiency in the documentation existing within the RAAF regarding the types of manoeuvres which resulted in the accident. The captain was attempting to demonstrate flight at what is termed velocity minimum control air—or VMCA. Criticism was also pointed at the inadequate research into the operating characteristics of the B707, the lack of adequate training and the need to preserve corporate knowledge. Arising from the board of inquiry, the RAAF has instigated full reviews of all operational documents relating to the B707 and all other RAAF transport aircraft. Some documents have already been published, with others approved and awaiting publication and some in final draft format.

Corporate knowledge is being retained through the inclusion of relevant information in documents such as standard operating procedures and flying instructors manuals. Additionally, a written review of this accident is being prepared and action has been taken to create accident reviews on video to enhance the corporate memory and assist with accident prevention.

The coroner also recommended that the B707 flight simulator be upgraded to allow the VMCA, or minimum control airspeed, demonstrations to be conducted. In that regard the RAAF aims to issue a request for tender for the supply of a level five B707 simulator in early 1994. It should also be put on the record that the coroner, in concluding his report, stated:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . the evidence satisfies me that the Air Force chain of command is aware of the deficiencies that have been highlighted at the inquest and that it has either implemented changes or is in the process of doing so, with their paramount consideration being the undertaking of aircraft operations competently and safely.

Finally, I would like to address the issue of compensation. Payments to the dependants of the crew members under the Commonwealth workers compensation scheme were made within one month of the accident. If there are any further issues relating to compensation, they will be dealt with through the normal channels.

PARA.TAB: The Minister for Defence expresses his disappointment that the press has seemingly confused the causes of an accident with the blame for an accident. The fact that pilot error was involved does not necessarily mean that the blame should be attributed totally to the pilot.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sullivan Mrs K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Child care is an issue with which I have been greatly concerned ever since entering federal parliament. Many members here would be aware that I have spoken many times on this important issue in both the House of Representatives and in the Senate. Over the years it has been encouraging to see the growing recognition by members from both sides of politics of the importance of support for families through the provision of adequate child-care services and facilities. It is therefore ironic that in this Parliament House there is no provision for child care for the large number of staff who work sometimes horrendous hours here, much less for any members of parliament who may need such a service. The coalition recognised the need of working parents for adequate and affordable child care in Fightback. I quote a brief excerpt:

SPEECH.PARA: Access to affordable child care is essential for working parents. With more women than ever before seeking to enter and remain in the paid workforce, it is particularly important to ensure that they are not inhibited from doing so by an inability to afford proper child care.

Our child-care policy statement of February 1993, `New Directions for Parents and their Children—Choice, Quality and Affordability', highlighted the coalition's longstanding view that for many families child-care expenses are a necessary cost of earning the family's income.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister (Mr Keating), at the start of the 1993 federal election campaign, promised a package of new child-care measures worth $626.7 million over four years. The Childcare Rebate Bill implements this package, setting out the details of the rebate scheme, which will be available from July 1994, for parents using child care while in employment, training, studying or looking for work. The rebate will not be means tested. The coalition has a problem with that fact. The coalition will not oppose the bill but will move to amend it to cap the payment of the child-care rebate to remove the `child care for millionaires' element. The coalition also has a number of other concerns which I intend to raise.

I point out that we will move to amend this legislation if there is time. We are under the guillotine and this bill has to pass all stages by 5 o'clock this afternoon. So it is possible that we will not have time to move amendments here in the House of Representatives. If that is so, the same constraints will not apply in the Senate, and those amendments will be properly aired there.

The matter of concern which I think ought to be aired at this stage is privacy. Honourable members will recall that earlier this year the parliament passed the Health Insurance Amendment Bill 1993, extending the role of the Health Insurance Commission and allowing it to plan the system by which cash rebates are to be paid. At that time, the coalition clearly stated its reservations, particularly concerning privacy. We warned the government that, depending on the final arrangements established by the HIC, it could not assume the support of the coalition for any subsequent legislation setting out details of the child-care rebate.

Our main concern then was that the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley) had told the parliament that child-care providers would be required to supply their tax file numbers to the HIC. This would have meant that for the first time a government agency would hold both taxation and Medicare databases. The proposal was the subject of significant correspondence between the Privacy Commissioner and the department.

The final arrangements have acknowledged the concerns raised initially by the coalition since the Childcare Rebate Bill does not require a child-care provider to supply a tax file number to the HIC. However, the bill does require child-care providers to register with the HIC as `registered carers' and state that they have a tax file number. In turn, the HIC provides the carer with a child-care provider number, which is to appear on receipts. However, the Commissioner of Taxation can request information on payments from the HIC under section 264 of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936.

Whilst the Office of the Privacy Commissioner has indicated that its concerns have largely been addressed, some misgivings have been expressed on the further extension of use of the TFN and the fact that this bill moves away from voluntary disclosure of TFNs. I understand that the Australian Privacy Foundation has expressed a similar view. If it had not been for the coalition raising this matter in the first place, the government may not have backed down on its original proposal for use of TFNs.

Secondly, there is the matter of equity. When the Prime Minister announced the rebate, the coalition rightly labelled it as child care for millionaires, which I have already mentioned. Two-income families with relatively high incomes will be the big winners. A survey by the Bureau of Statistics, published in 1990, found that only 6.9 per cent of families using child care spent more than $60 a week on it. Almost two-thirds of this group had enjoyed a weekly income of more than $800 per week, putting them in the top one-third of income earners.

Of those spending $100 or more per week on child care, 74 per cent had incomes greater than $800 a week. The rebate is worth most for those with child-care expenses of more than $110 per week for one child or more than $220 per week for two or more children. This means that most of those who will receive the maximum rebate are already relatively well off. However, under the coalition's proposed scheme, a rebate would not have been payable beyond a combined income of $60,000, with payment of the rebate tapering out between $50,000 and $60,000.

The government argues that child care as a work related expense should not be means tested. While we agree that child care is properly regarded as a work related expense, it is still legitimate for the coalition to point out that the rebate is negatively targeted—that is, the higher the household income, the higher the payment—and thus is irresponsible given the economic imperatives confronting Australia.

Thirdly, another concern which the opposition would like to draw the government's attention to relates to the possibility of double-dipping. It would seem that in situations where a child is the dependant of more than one family it may be possible for the two families to collude and split child-care expenses, resulting in a total benefit for one child in excess of the maximum rebate. For example, if the child-care expenses for a child were $150 per week and one family were claiming the rebate, the maximum rebate would be $28.20. If the costs were split between two families, a rebate of $17.70 could be claimed by each family—a total rebate of $35.40. This is a matter which needs clarification, and one which the government should take special note of.

Fourthly, the coalition sees problems with the government's move to establish a national accreditation scheme for child-care centres. The government, through regulations introduced into the parliament on 7 October 1993, is pursuing a wasteful and ineffective national accreditation system for the formal child-care sector and, at the same time, is encouraging the informal child-care sector through the child-care rebate.

The coalition considers that the compulsory system of accreditation is totally unnecessary and its link to eligibility for fee relief represents the beginning of a barely disguised attack on the private sector. Parents have not sought compulsory accreditation. It will do little or nothing for quality and will only add to child-care costs. And, let us face it, small businesses such as child-care centres do not need additional government schemes to administer and oversee. Already a number of child-care organisations have warned that this could penalise low income families and push children back into unsupervised backyard care.

The point the opposition seeks to make is that we have a situation where, at the same time as a flawed accreditation system is to be introduced for the formal sector, a child-care rebate will encourage the less regulated and, according to the government's own reasoning, poorer quality, informal sector. Fifthly and finally, the coalition has some reservations concerning the possibility of prosecution for making false or misleading statements. The Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills has also raised concerns with provisions in the bill dealing with false or misleading statements used in connection with a claim for a rebate. The committee suggests that there may be an inappropriate onus of proof standard used in the bill. The coalition looks forward to hearing the government's response to the committee's concerns.

Earlier in my speech I mentioned that I would come back to the question of means testing the amount of income earned by families eligible for the child-care rebate. I point out that the coalition supports capping the level of income able to be earned in order to be eligible, as a way of recognising those in most need, that is, people on lower incomes and who are more likely to be experiencing increased financial pressure in Australia's present disastrous economic climate.

For many years there has been increasing community recognition of the expense and the inequity of open-ended government assistance and the desirability of targeting those in most need. Failure to do so simply means that struggling, lower income families are required to subsidise high income, two-income families. The coalition believes that this approach would be an appalling misuse of scarce public resources and unnecessarily limits the capacity of government to provide adequate assistance to those in genuine need.

Under our policy, the Liberal and National parties propose that all parents who use child care could claim a generous 20 per cent cash rebate of up to $25 per child per week on the net costs incurred for child care, subject to a maximum combined parental income of $50,000 a year, and for those on incomes of $50,000 to $60,000 the rebate would be progressively withdrawn, with no rebate payable to those whose single or combined income exceeds $60,000. This approach recognises that, in the current economic climate, the country cannot afford to provide `child care for millionaires'. Therefore, the opposition would support an amendment to cap the rebate.

I would like to touch briefly on the issue of access to child care by those parents who choose to remain at home during their children's formative years. The coalition fully supports the right of parents who are not in the paid work force to have access to child-care services for non-work related reasons, in order to enable them to have some relief from their domestic responsibilities.

Further, the Liberal and National parties are aware that many parents caring for children in the home feel that their contribution to effective child rearing and the extent of the career sacrifices which they have made are often not adequately recognised by the wider community. We believe that this issue really needs proper, careful investigation. Therefore, the issue of the role of government in relation to child care within the home should be referred to the Australian Institute of Family Studies for consideration and report. We also strongly believe that there should be improved access to respite child care for parents at home with children, including those living in the country and those with disabled children. Our policy includes initiatives in this area.

As I said at the beginning of my remarks, child care is a subject on which I have been speaking now for nearly two decades in this parliament. I am sure I can speak in a bipartisan sense to say that I welcome the developments that have taken place over the last two decades in the provision of child care in this country. Undoubtedly, one of the major reasons for the pressure to extend that child care has been the matter of single parent families. I would like to believe, however, that another major contributing factor is a more enlightened view on the issue of child care in the Australian community.

This is a subject, in my opinion, of fundamental importance to the structure of our society, dealing as it does with the welfare of our children—future generations of our nation. I would have liked to spend—and could have spent—much longer on the subject. However, I note there is a very long list of members on both sides of the parliament who wish to contribute to the debate. That, combined with the fact that I hope we may have a chance to look at some amendments in the committee stage, means that I have truncated my speech on this subject. I do, however, point out that there will be an opportunity for a longer debate in another place before the end of this parliamentary session.

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate the willingness of the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan) to cut short her speech and I will do likewise in order that other members will have an opportunity to speak. I am pleased to have the opportunity to speak on the Childcare Rebate Bill on behalf of the government. The child-care rebate was an election commitment, along with the home child-care allowance and the other measures in the child-care policy statement. The implementation of these child-care policies is a clear demonstration that child care is no longer a marginal issue. It has been placed firmly on the mainstream policy agenda.

PARA.TAB: This bill clearly shows that the government recognises child care is no longer simply a welfare issue; no longer a women's issue alone. Child-care issues, including the availability of places, work based provision of care, cost of care, and quality of care, are industrial issues affecting all workers, all businesses and all industries. I take note of the honourable member's comments about the provision of child-care facilities in this place. I commend the Speaker, who is not in the House at the moment, for taking steps to rectify that matter.

This is not to say that the government does not recognise that the issue of child care is of greater importance to women. This bill, accompanied as it is by a comprehensive child-care policy, will greatly benefit Australian working women. My point is that it is one of the first steps towards a time when we can stand up in this place and proudly say that there are no women's issues; there are only people's issues.

That may not happen in my time, or even in the time of the next generation of members, but it will come. Future generations of Australians will look back to these times with puzzlement. They will read Hansard and ask themselves why it was necessary for women parliamentarians in their first speeches in 1993 to speak, without exception, of their role in this place as women members. They will look at these times of great achievement for women in much the same way that we look back to the time before universal suffrage. Those future Australians will look at the program of this government and recognise the significant contributions made towards the equality they will enjoy.

The participation of women in the work force will continue to increase. Women are becoming more and more integrated into Australia's economic life. The Labor government has always recognised that women are unable to participate fully in the work force without access to affordable child care. In the term of this government, the supply of government supported child-care places has expanded more than fourfold from 46,000 places in 1983 to almost 208,000 places in June 1993.

Child care has become more affordable, especially for low and middle income earners. The government's child-care assistance scheme, formerly fee relief, now helps two-thirds of families using Commonwealth funded child-care centres. Child-care policy is an integral part of the government's approach to building a highly skilled and adaptable work force. The range of child-care measures, of which this bill is one, is designed to continue this government's proud record in providing appropriate and affordable child-care places. They are designed to give parents choices about the way they combine work and family responsibilities.

The cash rebate scheme expands the objectives of the children's services program to provide the following: recognition that the costs of child-care arrangements are a legitimate work-related expense, assistance to families who make the choice to use informal care or who are unable to get access to formal care, assistance to working families who are ineligible for targeted child-care assistance, and additional assistance to those who do receive child-care assistance.

The rebate will be available for child-care expenses for children up to and including 12 years of age for families where both parents are engaged in full- or part-time work outside the home, or who are studying, training or looking for work. In the case of sole parent families, the criteria need only apply to the custodial parent.

Eligible child care under the scheme will include all work-related formal and informal child care, provided that the carers are 18 years or over. The maximum weekly rebate will be $28.20 per week for one child and $61.20 per week for two or more children. It is important to note that the amount payable under this scheme is paid over and above child-care assistance. An estimated 230,000 families with 358,000 children will benefit from the scheme.

In my electorate, 54.9 per cent of families have both partners in the work force; 42.7 per cent of women are in the labour force; and over nine per cent of families are sole parent families. Nearly 10 per cent of children aged zero to four years in Macquarie come from two parent families with both parents working full time or from sole parent families with the custodial parent employed full time. These figures do not take into account children aged five to 12, families where one or both parents are studying, engaged in part-time work or looking for work. Yet even on these limited figures, it is clear that the introduction of the child-care rebate will be of great benefit to my constituents.

Much has been made in this place and in the media of the opposition's objections to this bill. The opposition had the cheek to compare the child-care rebate we have introduced with the system it proposed during the election campaign. The coalition's proposal would have been about $30 million cheaper. That was its only advantage. It would have cost about $6 million just to administer the means test to the 230,000 families eligible to apply. It would have excluded about 30,000 families from the scheme altogether, and would have reduced the rebate to a further 20,000 middle income families.

More importantly, the government's policy clearly equates child care with other expenses associated with earning an income, which are not means tested. As I have already said, this is important if we are to see child care as an industrial issue rather than a women's issue. It has also been suggested that it would be preferable for child care to be a tax deduction. It would be preferable—for high income earners. Low income earners would get no benefit whatsoever.

The child-care rebate scheme also has the added advantage of being claimable as the expense is incurred instead of up to 18 months later, as is the case with the tax concession. It is also available for those who are studying and looking for work, which is not the case with tax concessions. This is consistent with other concessions, such as the new home child-care allowance. The honourable member for Moncrieff referred to those women who stay at home, and the government has taken steps to care for them. The home child-care allowance will be paid every fortnight directly to the non-earning parent. Families whose tax liability was previously too low to get the full value of the dependent spouse rebate will receive greater assistance from this allowance.

I do not believe the objections raised by those opposite deserve further response. I suggest that the honourable member for Moncrieff take a closer look at the proposed accreditation system for long day-care centres and not listen to scaremongering of certain private bodies out there. There is nothing to fear, and it will provide a higher standard of care for our children without any undue imposition on those institutions. The opposition knows that the Australian community knows this is a fair measure, a measure which will benefit hundreds of thousands of Australian working families. I commend the bill to honourable members.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Mr R.D.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in this debate to highlight the extraordinary lengths to which this government will go to bring our great country to its knees. That may sound a bit dramatic in the context of this very important issue, but it should be very clearly stated that the Childcare Rebate Bill is ill conceived and will create more problems than it will solve for the working parent and families. Why has the government brought on this particular bill? Why does the government choose to discriminate against Australian families who contribute to the future of our great country? Why should the government choose to burden the entire community with an issue that, on the surface, does not highlight the deeper ingrained problems it will develop?

PARA.TAB: This government is devoid of positive solutions to the ever increasing problems of our community and of this bill. Although beneficial to some of our community, it does not address the fundamental issues underlying many problems experienced by modern Australian families. The normal socialist attitude to problem solving is simply to throw money at it; if that fails, throw more money at it; and, if the problem continues to occur, simply ignore it. The government throws money at a problem which may be better handled without government involvement or intervention. This is a particular issue that the government has chosen to throw money at. The government's motive is simple. In this legislation, the government is attempting to satisfy an election promise that was ill conceived and made in an effort to appease certain community interests. It is typical of this government's attitude of policy on the run.

Some could argue that the government's crass attempt at vote buying may have worked. The child-care rebate legislation, as detailed in the Childcare Rebate Bill, is fundamentally wrong for a number of reasons. I will highlight some of the more significant areas of contention. It is argued at this point of economic decay that it is irresponsible of government to spend taxpayers' money on issues that do not primarily address some of our country's most fundamental problems—namely, unemployment and poor economic productivity.

The government indicated in February 1993 that it would spend $626 million over four years on the allowance. We are informed that the problem will cost $151 million in 1994-95, with an administration cost of approximately 10 per cent—but it is estimated to cost more than this. Firstly, we do not need to increase our administrative costs so much when we have systems already in place. Secondly, the bill discriminates. While providing for all those income earners, it neglects the essence of our stable community—namely, those child carers who stay at home to provide care and attention to their children. Thirdly, the legislation does not address some of our more fundamental social problems and, instead, may promote division and resentment amongst many Australian families. Finally, it provides no incentive to those ultimately responsible for children—parents—to maintain links with their families and provide for a future based on responsibility and not dependency upon the government.

To appreciate the true perspective for the introduction of this bill we must look at some of the current problems befalling families and some of the history associated with this socialist driven government. Before doing so, honourable members must remember the following famous quote from the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on 17 March 1970, St Patrick's Day:

SPEECH.PARA: Husbands have been forced to send their wives to work in order to provide the necessities of life. Young mothers have been forced out of their homes by economic pressure. We must not forget that this government has been in office for 20 years. It has had the duty and the opportunity to rectify the present situation. Family life is the very basis of our nationhood. In the last couple of years the government has boasted about the increasing number of women in the workforce. Rather than something to be proud of, I feel that it is something of which we should be ashamed.

I wonder whether his attitude has changed? I do not think so. Let us look at the record of the misguided compassion and irresponsibility of the Australian Labor Party when it comes to helping average Australian families.

TALK.START.PARA: —They don't care.

—That is right, they do not care. Since the introduction of the Family Law Act, which is recognised throughout the Australian community as a watershed for allowing easier divorces, yet contributes to more disputes and provides for little or no appreciation of family values, our community has witnessed the highest levels of family breakdowns than at any other time in our history. We have increased youth suicides, increased crime rates, increased reporting of domestic violence, increased personal bankruptcies and ongoing family problems. Who is responsible for these amazing statistics?
—Labor.

—As the honourable member for Fisher says, I bet the Labor Party would find someone else to blame rather than correctly accept some responsibility for the difficulties that Australian families have endured. We must acknowledge that in the last 20 years Labor has governed for over 13 of them. The basic problem of this legislation—it is typical of Labor Party doctrine—is lack of responsibility.

PARA.TAB: The issue of family breakdowns is central to this legislation and the lack of responsibility which has come to characterise Labor Party doctrine can be found in this legislation. Why is there a demand for legislation of this type anyway? Primarily, the legislation sets out to help those parents who work and are trying to provide for their children by increasing their family income.

I would like to identify a number of obvious difficulties in the present legislation as presented, and they are consistent with other actions by this Labor government, which seeks to impose greater burdens on low to middle income Australians while leaving more wealthy Australians relatively unscathed in these times of restraint. The obvious difficulty with the present legislation is the effect it has on income redistribution. As a result of the child-care rebate not being means tested—that is, cash rebates are paid to eligible parents irrespective of income or family wealth—there is a broad brush approach to assisting families.

The pressure on families to accumulate material wealth is tremendous these days. Community demands require parents to keep up their living standards materialistically, and we now have a community so passionate about material wealth that we are beginning to ignore the priority of our lives, which, simply put, is our families.

Communities around the world do not place as much emphasis as we do on material wealth but they do place a huge priority on the welfare of the family, both immediate and extended. It is a pity that the government does not encourage the acceptance of these family values as readily as it accepts other cultural issues for our community.

Since the Labor Party has been in power we have had huge reductions in real wage levels; in other words, we are earning less for the same amount of work. This is no fault of the employer for he has no control over taxes and prices of commodities such as food and clothing. In fact, actual wages have increased but the silent taxes the government introduces have reduced the spending power of Australian families. That will also be extended by the latest budget of betrayal with the one per cent increase in wholesale sales tax. Therefore there is a greater demand on Australian families for both parents to work in order to maintain a reasonable standard of living which is equivalent to what they were earning 10 years ago.

Couple this pressure with the feminist push which undermines and grossly devalues the role and importance of motherhood, and we see evidence where women who choose to raise their families are looked upon as not pulling their weight, as living a secondary and demeaning lifestyle. There is nothing corrupt or devalued in wanting to care for your own children, yet this legislation promotes just that.

Becoming a parent is an awesome responsibility. One should not take this step lightly because it is about sacrifice—the biggest sacrifice being to give up one's own individuality and independence in return for the care and attention of one's own children. Although we remain the makers of our own destiny, we must never neglect the responsibility of the lives of our own children. The notion of children being an option to our lives, where we take them and care for them on our own terms, is repugnant to me, as I am sure it is to many within the community. The idea of using children to fulfil the emotional gaps in our lives on a part-time basis whilst we are out conquering the world is quite bizarre and detrimental to the development of our children. Yet this legislation promotes such an idea.

What is wrong with remaining responsible to our children, to take their lives into our own hands—the hands of parents—rather than seeking help and financial support from the government to raise them? Let us review the child-care legislation proposed by the Labor Party. The very fact that it is planned to have the rebate available through the Department of Health opens up a myriad of problems, mostly administrative. Why would one want to embark on a welfare payment scheme through a department that is not structured to deal with it when there already is in place the Department of Social Security with systems in place to handle programs such as the family allowance? The major cost of this legislation—some 10 per cent—will be in administering it through a department that has previously had no experience in welfare details. We will have the potential for an administrative nightmare. Other family payments are made through the Department of Social Security.

Upon reading the legislation, a number of discriminatory clauses appear, and I ask the minister to reconsider the potential damage to the community that these practices may develop. Firstly, the legislation discriminates against those parents that plan their finances and their family well enough to provide for a carer parent to remain at home. Secondly, it discriminates against those within our community who are low income earners by not capping the eligibility of the rebate. In other words, a couple who are currently providing child-care arrangements and meeting them financially, can have unlimited income and remain eligible for the rebate.

The legislation aims to provide support to those least likely to be able to afford child care, and therefore discriminates against low income families. The legislation provides for overseas students to claim, and therefore discriminates against Australian taxpayers who are asked to support non-Australian citizens. It also discriminates against carers, in particular the teenager who is out to earn some extra money to help maintain a standard of living. For parents to be eligible for the rebate, the legislation requires that they must use registered child-care providers. The legislation is weak and badly thought out. It will increase division within the community. The only recognisable result from the legislation is increasing costs.

Division in the community seems to be the catchcry of the Labor Party. This government has not surprised anyone with its poor handling of major issues such as unemployment, the republic, the Mabo debate, and also industrial relations. We have a position in Australia right now of the new haves and have-nots—those that qualify for social welfare and those that do not. The dreadful aspect of this is that those receiving the benefits may be in a better position to those that are not. It is therefore time to analyse what we are doing in welfare and whether we are reaching those most in need.

To highlight the haves and the have-nots in this case, working parents can qualify for up to $61.20 a week whilst those that do not work and prefer to care for their children, and arguably provide a more secure environment for their children, do not qualify. The government would argue that the introduction of the home care allowance makes up for this, but it is already provided for as the dependent spouse rebate. There is no incentive to provide a caring environment; rather, there is an incentive to drop parental responsibility and give up the role of carer for one of financial provider. This government sees nothing wrong with that uncaring and grotesque form of socialism. The collective is more important than the individual; that is its motto, and it is working to the detriment of our society.

But if the problem of child care is an issue for working parents—as I am sure it is—and they are in extreme need of financial assistance, why not consider some alternatives? For instance, why not encourage employers to provide child care for the children of their employees? This will result in fewer hassles for the employee, provide a more stable staff relationship, lead to less time spent in down time due to child-care problems, and it could be an attractive benefit to attract employees to the company.

Of course, the government would need to repeal FBT requirements and perhaps provide other employer incentives; but this action motivates the community to look for solutions rather than let the government take control. Why not provide PAYE tax benefits for child-care rebates rather than require people to apply through second and third person systems? This would reduce administration costs. It would also reduce potential rorting opportunities. Why does the government not consider the tax system of the household rather than a straight PAYE schedule? In other words, recognise the coalition idea of split family income to recognise the importance of the parent who cares at home.

Ultimately, parenting is not the responsibility of the government and the Australian taxpayer. It is the responsibility of those who choose to become parents and those who do must never choose to walk away from that responsibility. Ultimately, if we continue down this socialist track we will institutionalise our families to an extent where we consider them part time and the government will control their destiny.

I ask the government to review this legislation; to rethink the administration of it; to address the discrimination aspects of it; to find incentives to encourage the business community to provide the care for its staff rather than the government, for ultimately it affects them to a greater extent; and, very importantly, to recognise more fully the role played by mothers in our community.

Our community values are under threat from this government and I comprehensively support the need to care for our children—our nation's future. Rather than rely on government action, we should promote community solutions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knott Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Childcare Rebate Bill, the purpose of which is to provide payment of rebates for expenses incurred for work-related child-care as announced by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on 9 February 1993. Whether opposition members admit it or not, this is another election promise that the government has kept.

PARA.TAB: From 1 July 1994, parents using child-care while in employment, training, studying or looking for work will be able to get a rebate for part of their child-care expenses. The rebate will be paid for all work-related child-care expenses for children aged up to 12 years. Child-care expenses incurred in formal child care—long day care services, family day care, outside school hours care—and informal care arrangements, relatives and nannies, will be eligible for the rebate. Child-care expenses incurred in informal care have been included in recognition of the fact that almost two-thirds of working families use informal care either by choice or because formal care is not available.

Child care is a family issue and is therefore a Labor Party issue. I am pleased to point out, particularly to the last speaker, the honourable member for Cowan (Mr Evans), the differences in both policy and reality between the major parties on child care at the last election. I was happy to stand for the Labor Party's record against the coalition's basket of woe. For the benefit of those coalition members who are here, I will quote an article from the Sydney Morning Herald of 16 September 1992 that described the coalition's proposed tax system at the last federal election. It stated:

SPEECH.PARA: A tax system which fails to recognise the obligations of marriage and the family must be described as a system of de facto fiscal discrimination against families.

That is where the opposition is coming from, so it should not start criticising what the Labor Party has done. Let me go further: for example, I will quote the Australian Catholic Social Welfare Commission, which had this to say about the Liberals' basket of woes:
From the point of view of its effect on the poor and families—
opposition members have discovered the poor and families and now feign tears for these people—
the person and the meaning of family life—
the last speaker had a lot to say about these things, so it will be interesting to see whether he listens now—
one must question the moral legitimacy of the GST.

In other words, the Catholic Social Welfare Commission questioned the opposition's moral legitimacy. Yet opposition members come in here and talk about standing up for the values of the family. They now feign concern for the poor and the Australian family, yet when they left office only 46,000 child-care places existed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who wrote this speech?
—I did. And they were places initiated by the previous Whitlam government. Opposition members do not care about child-care. They never have; their record proves it.
—Tell us about the fuel tax. Tell us about the wholesale sales tax.

—We are talking about child-care. The honourable member cannot get his mind on to it. The subject is child care—little Australians. The opposition's record proves that it has done absolutely nothing to assist Australian working families in assuring them their children are safe and well cared for. Its fascist mates Kennett and Court have done even less. They have closed down schools—
—I rise on a point of order. The honourable member for Gilmore referred to the Victorian Premier in an offensive way. He referred to him as a fascist. I believe that is disorderly.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—The honourable member will resume his seat. There is no point of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —Fascism is a political ideology. If it happens to be upheld by those people in the way that they treat their electorates they should wear it. The Liberals have done even less. They have closed down schools throughout Victoria. These are the people who feign concern about young Australians. It makes me wonder.

PARA.TAB: On this issue, opposition members should do the decent thing and sit down and shut up, because their party has nothing to say, based on its policy at the last election. It has nothing to say, based on its long record of nothing. This government's record on child care is exemplary. We have gone from 46,000 places to 208,000 places in 10 years. Opposition members cannot deny that; they are the facts.
Mr Evans interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —We are talking about child-care—little Australians. If the honourable member wants to start talking about sniffing leaded petrol, he can go ahead. That relates to young Australians too, and he might remember that as well. In Gilmore, since being elected in March this year I have announced additional places which were allocated to my electorate based on a planning system which identifies and prioritises need. These were community based child-care places.

PARA.TAB: In Australia as a whole 29,000 additional places will be funded this year alone. That is a record. It is a record we can be proud of. The government's child-care assistance scheme now helps two-thirds of families using Commonwealth funded child-care centres. We have made it easier for families to apply for child-care assistance and they may have postal assessment. Families with special needs—those special little Australians who at birth were dealt less than a full hand—receive appropriate care because we care and thus provide supplementary service grants, program support and special services.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the ones staying at home?

—I will answer that interjection. My kids are at home. I have two of them. My wife has chosen to do what she has done. Once she feels that she is capable of going back to work, she will do so. She will do so because there is child care. Sole parents need an income to improve their lot. Those opposite do not know about that because they do not bother opening their eyes and looking into our community to see those people. Their families are better off. Their incomes are improved by their being able to get work.
—Not because of this legislation, though.

—It is all because of this legislation. We do these things not to buy votes but because we care. We know it is important to all working families. We care, unlike this mob of fatherless children on the other side.
—Order! The honourable member might assist the debate by withdrawing that remark.
—Which remark was that, Mr Deputy Speaker?
—You know quite well which remark, and you will withdraw it unqualifiedly.

—I will withdraw that remark. They probably do know their fathers. This bill goes further. It recognises that the costs of all child-care arrangements are a legitimate work related expense. We recognise that the days of Australian women being forced to be barefoot, pregnant and in the kitchen exists only in the minds of some of the dinosaurs on the other side. Women are an integral, valuable and necessary part of the Australian work scene and are no longer restricted to being child bearers and carers. It is a voluntary process and now women may choose what they do because we have provided those places. The coalition was in government for a lot of years and it did nothing about this.

PARA.TAB: Further, the notion of child care being a women's issue should be buried back with the ark. Child care is a family issue. Increasingly, Australian men as heads of single parent families and as partners in the care of their child—as I am—are scrutinising the delivery of child care and the results of that delivery to their family income. This bill recognises that training is an important part of a family's ability to increase its disposable income or the income potential. As a consequence, the cash rebate applies to legitimise expenses incurred in these work related activities. It allows my constituents in Gilmore to seek training to improve their lot.

Further, the bill recognises that studying relates directly to one's capacity to successfully apply for work and thus is a work related activity which deserves consideration. Single parents in my electorate who want to improve their ability to earn money and to be able to provide for their children are able to do so as a result of this bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —They already get it.

—Perhaps the honourable member for Cowan should read the bill. Look at the caring approach Labor has for families and their ability to improve their lot—a practical approach with real help. The bill goes one further in that, besides training and study being recognised as legitimate work related expenses, it recognises that parents need child care for their children while the parents are physically out and about presenting themselves to prospective employers and that the child care generated by these activities is also a legitimate work related expense. How can persons go out and look for work if they have children under their care? They need to be in a position where they can put those children into care and have some remuneration to cover the costs.

PARA.TAB: This bill also recognises informal care and provides assistance for it. Why? Because we know that to some parents informal child care provides them with the security of mind that they need to enable them to seek employment. In other cases we recognise that, as fast as we have been able to provide places, there are still areas where formal child-care places are not available to fulfil the increasing need and informal care is the only option.

The cash rebate scheme set up by this bill provides that families, after the first $16 of weekly child-care costs, can claim 30 per cent of their costs up to a ceiling of $110 per week for one child in care and $220 per week for two or more. The maximum weekly rebate will be $28.20 per week for one child and $61.20 per week for two or more children.

I remind some of the honourable members on the other side of the House that there is a long tradition of child care amongst the working people of the world going back to the tribal development of the human race where, if one were to work in the field, one's kin would look after the children. We are a more formalised society now. Sometimes, because the nuclear family has split, we do not have the extended family situation that we used to. I do not see anything in the philosophy or policies of the Liberal Party which suggest that we should have uncles, aunts, grandparents and other relatives under the one roof as happened in the past.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just break up the family!

—He has to be joking. In that regard, we need this formal and informal service. This bill goes a long way to helping true Australian working families provide adequate and beneficial care for their children. I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aldred Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Community Services (Dr Theophanous) said in his second reading speech on the Childcare Rebate Bill that child care is no longer a welfare issue, it is an economic issue. Let me stress that I would be the first to advocate that children must be cared for both inside and outside their own homes. I also believe that both parents, if they so wish, should be able to add their contribution to the work force and utilise their talents and abilities to the best effect in that regard, provided, of course, that in that process their children are adequately protected.

PARA.TAB: However, what is of great concern in this community of ours is the ever-growing number of mothers who are forced into employment, often for a pittance, merely to be able to give their children the bare necessities of life—food and clothing. This sad situation is a reflection of the growing gap between the rich and the poor evidenced since Labor has held office over the last decade. This was highlighted in the coalition's provision of family services paper, from which I quote:

SPEECH.PARA: In 1982-83 the income of the top one per cent of income earners equalled the total earnings of the bottom 11 per cent. By 1988-89 the top one per cent were earning an amount equal to the total incomes of the bottom 21 per cent.

That really is a terrible indictment of Labor's stewardship of this nation over the last decade. Child-care rebates may seem necessary at the present time to allow many adult members of our community to fulfil their responsibilities to their families' material welfare. However, there is an alternative which would, in my opinion, provide a far better way of caring for children and generally stabilising our extremely sick society.

PARA.TAB: I refer here to something which is not new: a tax concession as opposed to a child-care rebate which, with certain other measures, would help to reverse the unfortunate trend in our society towards family breakdown, divorce and a general destabilisation of family life. In an address to the Lyons Forum in this Parliament House on 7 October this year, Mr Barry Maley, senior fellow of the Centre for Independent Studies, when referring to his book, Marriage, divorce and family justice, published this year, said:

SPEECH.PARA: Seven out of ten Australians nominate family life as the source of their greatest satisfaction—
and yet—
whether by design or unintended consequence, that process—
the decomposition of the family—
is well advanced in this country. The melancholy social and moral consequences are all about us.

Mr Maley suggests, and most of us would agree, that a greater respect for traditional marriage and family is necessary. However, following on from that, and relating to the substance of this Childcare Rebate Bill, Mr Maley mentioned alternative taxation arrangements as an important instrument to help to cure the present ills of our society.

PARA.TAB: As honourable members in this place would know, a massive $40 billion is being spent annually in Australia in social security payments. This is 35 per cent of the total federal outlays and takes far more away from families in tax than is actually returned to them in benefits. Barry Maley asserts:

SPEECH.PARA: The central economic focus of family policy must be tax cuts based on family status, together with equitable childcare provision, both for those who want to work and those who want to stay at home.
The importance of family cannot be overestimated. It was restated by the Liberal and National coalition in its family services paper when it was said:
The place of the community and family are central to Liberal philosophy founded on the freedom of the individual.

The Parliamentary Secretary's statement that child care is no longer a welfare issue but an economic issue is put into focus by certain statistics brought out in the coalition's family services paper. I quote certain of those statistics: the divorce rate has tripled in this generation; 800,000 children live in homes where no-one has a job; and half a million children live with only one parent, many of them receiving some kind of social security payment, including child-care allowance.

PARA.TAB: There are 400,000 sole parents, of whom 90 per cent are women—and most of those are on state pensions. Some 60 per cent of natural fathers of those families make no contribution to the upkeep of their children. Around 25 per cent of births are ex-marital and 47,000 children per year see their parents divorce.
