That is a quite appalling set of statistics and a terrible indictment of the government of this country over the last decade.

Although I support the concept of children being afforded adequate care while parents work, the previous statistics really show that there must be a better way, a different and more positive way, to advance security in Australian society. The answer must be in part a change in philosophy to ensure that the present generation of children is given the stability of background that many of their older brothers, sisters and associates have been denied.

The parliamentary secretary has stipulated that day care centres, preschools, family day care, outside school hours care, vacation care and private child-care arrangements will be eligible for the rebate. But these measures, generous as they may seem, only skim the surface of the real problem. Barry Maley summed it up well when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The decay of the stable two-parent family entails very substantial social costs in more crime, more delinquency, more violence, more drug-taking, more suicide, more child abuse, more poverty.
The remedies for this tragic situation are not easy. However, there are two very practical and important areas that can, with foresight and determination, be addressed—taxation and employment.

PARA.TAB: I particularly wish to spend some time on the first area, taxation. Barry Maley suggests that to bolster the fading fortunes of the family every dependent child under 16 should receive either a tax credit or a cash benefit worth $2,000 per annum. He estimates that this would cost $8 billion to $9 billion for the four million plus children under 16. The figure would be almost entirely offset by the elimination of the dependent spouse rebate, the basic family payment, all child-care subsidies and a portion of the sole parent pension—particularly as the child support scheme for separated parents takes effect.

Mr Maley estimates that this would save $8 billion and there would be additional savings by transferring a large part of the administration to the Australian Taxation Office. There is time to make only the briefest mention of the huge problem of unemployment, but it is a further factor that adds to the great stress on the family today. In conclusion, I will quote from a letter sent to members of this House by the wife of a man recently made unemployed. Her net income of $700 per fortnight disqualified her from any kind of financial support for herself, her unemployed husband and her two teenage children. She writes:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the alternative. Sell the great Australian dream, break up the family, get divorced, then we will all qualify for job search allowance, rental assistance, health card. My children will give up studies and leave home. Maybe this could be of some assistance to your committee study into unemployment, marriage breakdowns, street kids . . .
I seek leave to table the letter I refer to.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Childcare Rebate Bill ensures that child care is affordable for all working families. Child care is now seen by most people in Australia as an important right—and every family should have access to it. I remember when child care was looked on purely as a marginal welfare issue. Women who lived in isolated areas with no family support system had no opportunity to improve the quality of their lives. They were not able to attend classes to improve their skills, to visit essential services such as doctors or dentists or to assist their community in many of the unpaid roles women take on. Nor could they get relief from the task of looking after children 24 hours a day, seven days a week, 52 weeks of the year.

PARA.TAB: It is a full-time job, particularly when the children are young, and it can be extremely stressful at times. No-one in the traditional work force would accept working conditions such as these, nor should we expect our carers of future generations to do so. Access to child care plays an important role in the welfare of people. It is now more than that. It is no longer just a welfare issue; it is an important economic issue and part of the government's approach to building a highly skilled and adaptable work force.

Those who have responsibility for looking after future generations must have access to affordable child care if they are to participate actively in the work force. It is not only confined to women; many men are now taking up the responsibility of primary care for their children. This gives all primary carers a choice as to how much quality time they spend with their children yet also be able to participate in the work force.

This government has made child care a priority. When elected in 1983 there were just 46,000 operational child-care places. Now we see 208,000 child-care places in Australia. The allocation of funds in this budget will lift the number to around 237,000 by the end of this financial year.

As the place numbers have grown, the government has ensured that ordinary Australian families can afford to use child-care facilities. As part of this whole discussion, it has been important to ensure that quality of child care is the best. I am particularly interested in this area, and it is to be noted that part of the registration of child-care providers is to ensure that centres have some sort of accreditation before they are eligible to receive child-care assistance. I received a letter from Community Child Care in Victoria, which informed me that it supports strongly an accreditation system that links child-care assistance to child-care centres in receipt of public funds. I support its concerns that that be so.

There is a requirement that existing centres wishing to continue to be eligible to receive child-care assistance, formerly fee relief, on behalf of parents will have until 30 June 1994 to register their intention to participate in the quality improvement and accreditation system with the National Child Care Accreditation Council. Setting up the new quality improvement and accreditation system and linking it to child-care assistance will ensure the provision of quality care in Commonwealth funded child-care centres.

Quality child care is about well-trained carers who understand that there is a need to stimulate children in care in active and positive ways. Quality care involves providing an environment which promotes the physical, social, emotional and intellectual wellbeing of children. There is a great difference between caring for children and minding children.

Studies have shown that children from stimulated early environments are better prepared and more able to move into a formal learning situation that school provides. It also gives parents peace of mind that their child is being cared for in the best possible way and that there is some form of accountability from child-care centres to ensure that their workers are trained to provide this care.

It will mean that interaction will need to take place between staff, children and parents who support the services and staff development. Attention will be given to the food, health and safety of children in care. To achieve federal government assistance, child-care centres will be asked to put forward a plan of action to be reviewed by the quality improvement and accreditation system to ensure that they fill the criteria for registration.

Tasmania has had a number of problems in the past in ensuring that carers are properly trained as a matter of course and that there is suitable interaction with parents on their needs and aspirations for care of their children. I welcome this bill, which overcomes some of those difficulties as well as keeps the government's election promise to increase the number of child-care places throughout Australia. I support the bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the Childcare Rebate Bill, there are a few things I want to mention, particularly with regard to the matter of equity. I had the earlier connection of being shadow minister for child care at a time when the industry, particularly in the public sector, because of the massive regulation that had interfered with its running, particularly in Victoria, and the qualifications laid down by the authorities on those who could run child-care centres, was almost phasing itself out of the reach of people who had a need.

PARA.TAB: We all need to realise that children are a very precious commodity and they have to be in the hands of somebody who is experienced. But there was the ridiculous situation where the price for child-care services was pushed right out of proportion yet private child-care centres were not being allowed to participate in any Commonwealth programs but were subject to the same regulation. This was ridiculous to the extent that on several occasions people who owned a child-care centre and had an empathy well in keeping with the enterprise they were running were disfranchised for actually running their own child-care centres. I believe that is where regulation goes too far.

I want to speak also, as I said earlier, on the lack of equity. I appreciate that the government is saying this is not a welfare bill. It is related to the economic wellbeing in that child-care expenses should be regarded as a tax deduction or a deductible item in the earning of assessable income. The interesting thing is that once we do that we remove all limits as far as income testing is concerned. The second reading speech makes it quite evident that a person way up the ladder on a high income can still get benefit up to a maximum weekly rebate of $28.20 per week. As somebody in my electorate mentioned to me, it was obviously framed by somebody in the Public Service in Canberra, where those types of incomes are available on a double income basis—not by people in the back of my electorate, where two people strive on farming enterprises earning nothing and still having to be responsible for the wellbeing of their child.

I relate to this an earlier decision on Austudy made through the budget process. Quite a few months ago I went to the west of my electorate to a cattle area that has been suffering three years of drought. The conditions on those properties are dismal and the prospects are just as dismal. I visited a house where the father and mother had been up at first light attending to their duties on the property. There was no division made between their work responsibilities. At 9 o'clock the wife came back to the house and from 9 o'clock to 3 o'clock, with one child in tow, she was trying to teach the other three children through distance education. She was not trained for that, but that was one of her tasks.

At that stage she thought that with the assistance of distance allowances and other facilities such as Austudy they could get their children into boarding schools, closer to the city. The changes to Austudy eligibility have meant that the prospects of those people being able to get a Commonwealth subsidy when they have no income of their own to send their children to these institutions is very bleak indeed, as we must remember again that they have to contribute part of their cash outflow to make it possible in any case.

I have heard of cases where children have voluntarily come out of school because they feel guilty about not helping their parents on the property. The point I make is that this child care is available in a fairly well-defined amount to people on dual incomes with a heck of a lot of income to provide the basis to bring up a child. Education is as vital to bringing up a child as is child care, and this suggests that parents are excluded from claiming the cost of caring for their own children.

The example I just gave honourable members is of a working parent who is obliged to educate and look after her children while people in heavily populated places can get the benefit of the allowance irrespective of their income. These people who are struggling on a nil income are being denied benefits for the upbringing of their children, for education and things like that.

I must confess that I am somewhat alarmed at the administrative costs associated with this whole arrangement. A program with administrative costs of 10 per cent is one that we should look at very carefully. It also suggests to me that, because of accreditation and many other things, the expense involved in administration is going to lead to a confused system. We have talked about accreditation and administrative costs. Certainly, people are moving into the area of child care. I know that the shadow minister at the table, the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan) has had a long-term concern about this matter. I often wonder whether the money that we spend and the programs that we come up with are appropriate in all the circumstances and, more particularly, whether they are fair and equitable to all concerned.

As I mentioned earlier, about four years ago during my time as shadow minister with responsibility for child care, an area in which I found a definite lack of equity was the lack of private carers available to participate along with the public sector. I found that public sector child care was being used as a political ploy in some electorates. While I note that a lot has been done to remove that inequity, there is still inequity in the area that I mentioned.

I refer particularly to my electorate of Dawson. While these child-care facilities will be available within both the city and country areas of my electorate, there is still a large disparity in the ability to cater for different needs. I refer particularly to Airlie Beach, which is a fast growing, very tourist oriented area, in which mums and dads do work together in order to earn money for the economic benefit of the whole family. There are not enough child-care places available in that area. It has obviously been deliberately avoided by the authorities, particularly at the state level. I have had many representations in this regard. I have written to the ministers concerned, including the federal minister with responsibility for this area, and at this stage there has been no response. The interesting point is that what people are looking for is more child-care places. There are unlimited numbers of people who are prepared to do the caring, either at home or in the child-care centres, yet the required approval to provide the places has not been forthcoming.

While we can talk about the costs associated with the provisions of this bill, I think we should be talking about equity, particularly in relation to farming families, who are not getting their fair share of taxpayers'dollars in order to provide for the appropriate care of children in their formative years, within both the education system and the social system.

I have nothing more to say in this regard. I support the amendments that will be moved by the opposition at the committee stage. I ask the House to consider the small minority of people around Australia—be they in Western Australia, in my electorate or elsewhere—who are struggling to do the best they can to raise their children in a family environment and who have been denied assistance at this time.

TALKER.NAME: Dr THEOPHANOUS
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Community Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—A number of members have spoken in this debate on the Childcare Rebate Bill, and I thank them for their contributions. I must say I found the debate somewhat wide ranging. We seem to have discussed everything from economic policy to family law reform, as well as the question that is at hand, which is that of child care.

PARA.TAB: Let me begin by addressing some of the general points made by opposition members. They tried to suggest that the government is not concerned about families, that its general approach has not been family oriented. Nothing could be further from the truth, particularly when one looks at this bill. As I said in my second reading speech, this is historic legislation. For the first time the federal parliament is actually legislating to help to provide direct assistance for child care for all sectors. Even when there are informal arrangements in place, people will be able to get a rebate for child care.

It is extraordinary that opposition members who spoke in the debate—with the exception of the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan), who has carriage of the matter on behalf of the opposition—seemed to be opposed to the bill. Having listened to them, one would think they were not in favour of these historic changes. Let me just go over what is involved here. We had a commitment by the government and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) during the election that this scheme would be put in place. That commitment is being honoured in full. It will help nearly a quarter of a million families. Also, the way in which the scheme has been structured is such that it supplements other programs that are intended to assist in the area of social justice.

While we are talking about social justice, it is extraordinary that some members of the opposition implied that the Labor Party was not concerned about social justice, the poor or with assisting ordinary Australian families. It is part of the historic tradition of the Labor Party to be so concerned, to be involved in social justice issues. In fact, it has never been part of the tradition of the opposition.

It was interesting that today the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) actually tried to claim some credit for some of the changes in terms of assistance to low income families and the unemployed, and other parts of the package negotiated between the Labor Party and the Greens. The opposition had nothing to do with it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Aren't you a little bit off the subject?

—I am simply replying to some of the comments made by the honourable member's colleagues in their very wide ranging attempts to use this bill to attack the government on its social justice credentials. In fact, the changes that were arrived at between the Greens, the Democrats earlier on, and the government were along the lines of social justice. They were concerns which were shared by members of the Labor Party as well as the Democrats and the Greens.

PARA.TAB: What was significant was that during the period of all of those discussions, at no point did we get even one suggestion from opposition members about any ameliorating measures. All we heard was that they were going to stop the tax changes, and that was it. There was no concept of any ideas from them regarding social justice. So it was a bit rich to have the Leader of the Opposition and, later on, the opposition treasury spokesman, the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) talking—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I have no wish to overly inhibit or restrain the parliamentary secretary. He made a comment a few moments ago, in relation to a statement I made to him across the table, that the reason he was talking about certain things was because some speakers had raised other issues. But I point out to you that he is now referring to matters said by the Leader of the Opposition and the shadow treasurer, who have not been participants in this debate. I think it might be time to invoke the standing order in relation to relevance.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Truss)—Obviously, in summing up the debate the parliamentary secretary has a right to respond to issues raised and to comment on them, but I remind him that the bill deals with child care—being the one to introduce it, he should know that—and I urge him to refrain from ranging too widely on the subject matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —As you pointed out, Mr Deputy Speaker, I was simply replying to comments made earlier. I think I have made my point in relation to those comments. I would now like to talk about the context of these changes in relation to the importance of this whole issue of the family.

PARA.TAB: There has been some attempt in our society, especially by the New Right in politics, to create a dichotomy between women at home—especially when they choose to be full-time mothers—and women who choose to go out to work. There has been a prevailing assumption that women who go out to work have been forced by circumstances to do so. That was mentioned by one of the opposition speakers. The real matter of importance in any democracy that respects the rights of women is for women to have the right to choose to be full-time mothers, staying at home, unpaid and doing a very difficult job but—

TALK.START.PARA: —You'd know, Andrew.

—Yes, I have some idea about how difficult it is. I assume that the honourable member also has some idea of how hard women at home work. However, women also have the right, if they so choose, to go into paid employment and organise their situation in such a way that they are entitled to child care. That is the essence of this bill.

PARA.TAB: This bill gives women—I mention women primarily, although it also applies to men who need child care—the right to choose and to have the advantage of child care. That is a fundamental right, or should be a fundamental right in an evolving social democracy. It is not simply a question of privilege.

Not very long ago people regarded child care as a privilege of the few. It should be a universal right. Anyone choosing employment should have the right to reasonable child care. The government has said that in that case it will provide a rebate; it will give everyone assistance. In the past, assistance has been given to people using the facilities of accredited child-care centres. The government is now saying that it will extend its assistance—massively extend it—so that even if a child is being looked after by a next-door neighbour, relative or friend—provided they are prepared to register under the government's scheme—they will be eligible for a rebate of part of the payment for the child-care services provided.

That represents a revolutionary change in the arrangements for child care. It is interesting to note that all the budget commentators who have said that the budget does not contain social measures have overlooked this revolutionary and important measure. It is as though this measure did not exist in the budget; as though this measure was not revolutionary in its content; as though this measure was not a very important social measure.

We have heard the opposition condemn the budget, as though the whole thing had nothing positive in it. Yet this was one of the most important, positive measures in the budget. The Australian people should be made aware that by this measure the government has met its commitment to introducing important social legislation.

After initially suggesting that it would oppose the bill on the basis of certain problems it perceived when this issue was first raised before the budget, the opposition has now indicated that it will not oppose the bill. It will be moving some amendments, and I will have something to say about that a little later. I am pleased to note that the opposition has agreed to pass this bill because, not only should it attract bipartisan support, but measures of this kind should have multi-party support.

Whenever we put forward measures such as this—something which will become a right for every Australian—we should all get behind it because the essential difference between those forms of government which merely have the shell of democracy and those which are substantive and substantial democracies is the recognition of certain social rights in addition to political rights. The notion of social rights, such as the right to unemployment benefits for people genuinely looking for work and the right to a pension, is being extended to include the right to child care. In that context, this measure is of historic importance.

The Minister for Health (Senator Richardson) has done a very good job in overcoming some of the concerns that were raised earlier by the opposition, especially concerning privacy. The Privacy Commissioner has been widely consulted and the scheme that has been adopted operates in such a way that no one should feel that their privacy is threatened. One speaker from the opposition, who obviously does not know what is going on, asked why the health department should be organising this arrangement when we have a social security department. The health department is not organising this. This rebate will be paid through Medicare, which is not attached to the health department; it is a separate statutory authority.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which minister?

—I am now asked to deal with the question of which minister will be responsible. I can tell the honourable member for Moncrieff that the child-care rebate will be dealt with by the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley) while Medicare is dealt with by the Minister for Health. This matter will cross both portfolios. The point about social security made by the honourable member to whom I referred earlier is nonsense. By paying the rebate through the Medicare office the rebate will be much easier to administer because every Australian has a Medicare card. It will be very easy to put the administrative system in place. In fact, we will not have to put a new administrative system in place because an administrative system already exists with Medicare. We are really developing the Medicare system to incorporate this other measure. Therefore the honourable member was completely mistaken.

PARA.TAB: The Department of Social Security deals with one, two or three different categories of people, but it does not deal with those who are working parents. They would have to be enrolled into the Department of Social Security. The suggestion by the honourable member for Moncrieff is foolish, because it would actually involve much more administrative costs than would the system that we are putting into place.

I now turn to the question of how this proposal will work with respect to the privacy provisions. As the honourable member for Moncrieff outlined, and as I outlined in the second reading speech, it is important for us to get this matter very clear so no-one is in doubt about where the rebate can be claimed. When parents want to claim the rebate, they will be able to claim it from a Medicare office. They will need to produce a receipt. That receipt will have on it a number. That number will be for a person who has been registered.

All that persons will have to do in order to be registered is to state that they have a tax file number. They do not have to give the tax file number to anyone. The tax file number will not become available to the department of health, to Medicare officers or to anyone else. Carers simply have to make a statement that they have a tax file number. That means maximum protection. So the concerns that were raised by the opposition have been met in the new arrangement. There will be no access to people's tax file numbers through this system. Given that, the concerns of the Privacy Commissioner have mostly been met. Therefore, I hope that puts to rest that problem and resolves what was formerly going to be a big stumbling block with respect to this legislation.

I now turn to the question raised by the honourable member for Moncrieff about the amendments to be moved by the opposition. Basically, they are saying that, somehow or other, this legislation should be means tested; that it is not correct to give the child-care rebate to everyone. The principle of universality is not to apply in this case, according to the opposition.

What are the problems associated with this course? First of all, it is not the usual practice for rebates to be means tested. So the opposition's desire to means test rebates is achieved by suggesting a different approach to the whole question of rebates than we have had in other areas of legislation. There is also the question of how we would actually do this. The opposition has suggested that we are giving child-care rebates to millionaires. It wants a cut-off point of $60,000—or is it $50,000?—in its amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is $60,000—graded from $50,000 to $60,000.

—The opposition has increased the figure. I will give an example of why the opposition's proposal is a nonsense. Would honourable members call a family consisting of a mother and a father each on full-time, average earnings—that is, about $35,000 for males, and about $28,000 for females—are millionaires? There are many families such as that struggling in this country. The opposition is saying that a two-income family—the male earning $35,000, and the female earning $28,000—should be excluded from receiving a child-care rebate. (Time expired)

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Governor-General recommending appropriation announced.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)Clause 4, page 2, after the definition of "claim" insert the following definition:

"`combined family income', in relation to a family, means the sum of the taxable income in a relevant year of a person forming part of a family for the purposes of subsection 5(1), and the income of the partner (if any) of the person, as defined in subsection 5(1) or (2);".
(2)Clause 4, page 3, after the definition of "registered family" insert the following definition:
"`relevant year', in relation to the combined family income of a family, means the financial year immediately preceding the year in which a claim is lodged;".
(3)Clause 33, page 13, after paragraph (e) insert the following paragraph:
``(ea)the combined family income of the family for the relevant year; and;''.
(4)Clause 36, page 14, after paragraph (a) insert the following paragraph:
"(aa)the combined family income of the family for the relevant year exceeded $60,000;".
(5)Clause 40, page 15, omit the clause, substitute the following clause:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Overall calculation of the amount payable

PARA.TAB: "40. (1) Subject to subsections (2) and (3), the amount of childcare rebate payable in respect of a claim is the amount equal to the sum of each of the amounts payable under Subdivision C in respect of a week to which the claim relates.

Note: Under Subdivision C, amounts of rebate are worked out for each week, based on each weekly childcare expenditure worked out under Subdivision B. To work out the claimant's entitlement, the Commission adds together all the amounts of rebate for the weeks covered by the claim.

TAB.TAB: "(2) Subject to the provisions of this Act:
(a)the maximum rate of childcare rebate is payable in respect of a claim lodged by a parental member of a family with a combined family income of $50,000 or less in the relevant year;
(b)no childcare rebate is payable in respect of a claim lodged by a parental member of a family with a combined family income of more than $60,000 in the relevant year;

(c)childcare rebate is payable in respect of claims lodged by parental members of families with combined family incomes greater than $50,000 but less than $60,001 in the relevant year in accordance with a scale to be prescribed in the regulations to provide for a progressive reduction in the rebate payable so that the rebate payable is reduced in equal increments after the combined family income exceeds $50,000 until no rebate is payable where the relevant combined family income exceeds $60,000.

PARA.TAB: "(3) The amount is to be rounded upwards to the nearest 5 cents.".

SPEECH.PARA: These amendments are to put into effect the principle that I referred to in the second reading debate. All the amendments deal with the point that I raised relating to the means testing of the child-care rebate. The amendments would mean that the rebate would start to phase out when a family's income—for example, in a two-parent situation—reached $50,000 and would be cut out altogether when it reached $60,000.

PARA.TAB: This matter gives me the opportunity to respond to a point that the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Community Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health (Dr Theophanous) made in his second reading reply. He said that the opposition's amendments would attack the principle of universality. As far as I can remember, his words were that it was not the practice, in nearly all cases, to means test rebates. However, there are rebates that are means tested. The first one that popped into my mind, probably because of the debate that is under way, was the dependent spouse rebate. That rebate is means tested according to the income of the person claiming the rebate. There may well be other instances. I do not think I really need go any further because that rebate is highly relevant to this issue being deleted.

I freely admit to being someone who, in the last 20 years, has gone on the record as saying that I do not think that in all cases a dependent spouse rebate is necessarily justified. I would have liked to have seen a limit applied to the rebate being paid in the cases of families without dependent children. The rebate should have to be justified. Be that as it may, that is not the law. The dependent spouse rebate is about to be phased out altogether by the government. I raise the subject not to debate the rights and wrongs of the dependent spouse rebate but to say that the intent of the dependent spouse rebate was, and always has been, to give some financial support to the family where one parent goes out to work and the other one remains at home full time in order to look after children. Nearly all of the debate about the worth of the dependent spouse rebate has been cast in the context that a family with one parent remaining at home in order to undertake the full-time parenting role with children should receive—following that model—financial support from the community courtesy of the taxpayer. That is a very important issue in the context of this debate.

I strongly support child care. My colleagues that the parliamentary secretary chose to refer to as the New Right were trying to point out that we should not try to push everyone into this mould. I have been one who, for a long time—going back 20 years when words basically fell on ears that could have done with a little assistance—has believed in the principle of choice; people ought to have the right of choice.

TALK.START.PARA: —I exempted you from that.

—I know. I point out that what I have been saying over the last 20 years is consistent with what I am saying now. Lest anyone suggest that maybe I have wavered a little in my line, I am just making it a little clearer. Twenty years ago we had to hammer on the doors of industry and say, `Women have a right to work if that is their choice'. I, of all people, am acutely aware that many women in the community were very worried about people like me going around trying to hammer on those doors because they thought we were trying to put them into yet another situation of no choice.

PARA.TAB: It is no more valid to say that mothers must stay at home and look after their children and that they are neglecting their children if they go into the paid work force, than it is to say that the mother who stays at home and looks after children full time is not working. There is a real worry—and it is a worry I understand and share—that the person who is paid by somebody outside the family to rear children is doing professional work, yet the person who is of that family doing the same job is not doing professional work. I would like to see a rather more than just lip-service given to that principle. It is therefore right that the opposition in this debate has raised the issue of support for the parent at home full time in a situation where the family and the individuals involved think that that is appropriate.

As I listened to this debate, that is the point that my colleagues on the opposition side were making. The fact that they were men does not mean that they were taking a male chauvinist view at all. The fact is that they happen to be the people on the speaker's list. I support their right and agree with them that that situation must be defended. I do not know a mother who would ever move to the point of view that the woman who chooses not to go into the paid work force is doing any less a professional job and should receive any less recognition than the woman who moves into the work force. The person who then looks after those children at home receives professional recognition. Lip-service is not good enough. Women are fed up with being patted on the back, or even patronisingly on the head, and being told, `You are doing a wonderful job staying at home and looking after your children but, by golly, don't look to the taxpayer'.

It has been the coalition's policy for a long time that the expenses of child care ought to receive a taxation rebate—since well before the 1993 election. We have gone to more than one election with that policy. The Labor Party is a latter-day convert to it. I was quite startled when the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) made the statement prior to the election campaign that, finally, the Labor Party was going to acknowledge the principle that the cost of child care can be a very legitimate cost of going to work. There is a very eloquent statement by the minister in this bill's second reading speech to that effect, so I will not repeat the words. I suggest that the parliamentary secretary read that second reading speech and he will see all the right words. However, we could also go back and look at some of the speeches, articles and press statements made by the honourable member for Canberra (Mrs Kelly) prior to this becoming the Labor Party's policy. She has often dealt with why it would be a matter of great inequity for child-care expenses to be a tax deduction. She took great pains to promote the view it would be inequitable. Her words are there for all to see. The Labor Party is very much a latter-day convert to this principle. I would not have made that point if it had not been for the fact that the parliamentary secretary sought to cast the opposition, quite falsely, in the opposite position.

Finally, because time has nearly expired on this set of amendments, I want to underline something that I said during the second reading debate and which I shall repeat for the parliamentary secretary's benefit. This bill is being changed by the government—I will come back to this matter again when the parliamentary secretary moves on to his amendment—because the opposition raised an issue. I think it is a great pity that debates come to this point.

I listened to what some of the government members have said when they were attacking the opposition. There were really no grounds for attack. We have a difference about whether or not something should be means tested, but no difference about the central substance and importance of the issue of child care and the government's role in it. However, they are new members and I thought, `We will give them time to settle down and realise that there are times in debate when it really is not appropriate to automatically attack the other side. There are times when you can accept that the other side is basically agreeing with you. If all you can do in your speech is attack the other side, then you really do not have much to say'. I thought these new members might learn that over time. I was a bit disappointed, therefore, to hear it from the parliamentary secretary. I just hope that in the future he might set a better example for those who look to him for guidance and leadership.

TALKER.NAME: Dr THEOPHANOUS
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Community Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government will oppose these amendments. I will respond to a couple of comments made by the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan). She did not spend most of her time talking about these amendments, but she did raise a couple of issues which go to the heart of the matter. It appears that she chose to dissociate herself from some of the comments made by opposition members who spoke on the Childcare Rebate Bill and who did not wish to emphasise the issue of choice.

PARA.TAB: The point has been made about supporting women who stay at home, and it was made as if the government was not doing anything about it. This government has been committed to the introduction of the home child-care allowance—another revolutionary measure. Those who are going out to work will be assisted by the child-care package being put forward by the government, as will those who choose to stay at home. The honourable member for Moncrieff suggested that the government is not going to be assisting men or women—usually women—who are staying at home and looking after the children. The government will be assisting them. We have got both sides: those staying at home and those going out to work will be assisted through this child-care package.

The implication that only those who are going out to work will be assisted—this was very much the stream of comments from other opposition members—is mistaken. This government is determined to assist parents with children—whether they wish to go out to work or whether one of them wishes to stay at home and look after the children.

The honourable member for Moncrieff said that we should attempt to get as much bipartisan support for these measures as possible. There is no doubt that the support of children is something that we as legislators ought to be committed to for the future of this nation. The honourable member also said that this is something which, 20 or 30 years ago, was not sufficiently emphasised by most members of the parliament.

We have recognised how important it is to care for children, be it at home with the mother or in another situation. The government will now be assisting. It has been mentioned that the national accreditation system is a problem. I do not understand why it is a problem. Under that system those people who are going to get very large fee relief, as distinct from those who are getting $28 per child, are asked to go to an accredited centre.

The government is asking those who are going to get large fee relief to go to an accredited centre to ensure that their children are being looked after properly. It would be quite incorrect for the government to support these established centres without some quality and standards control. That is why accreditation is a very important issue. I am surprised that some members of the opposition seem to think that there is something wrong with that.

The honourable member for Moncrieff said that means testing will not affect ordinary families; it will affect only so-called millionaires. As I said before, average families would be in serious trouble if this amendment were carried. If the means test were applied in the way the opposition suggests, 30,000 families of the 230,000 families eligible for the rebate would be excluded from the scheme and another 20,000 would have a reduced rebate—a total of 50,000 families would be affected. Another problem would be the massive machinery that would have to be put in place for the means testing of such a proposal. That would be very costly and very bureaucratic. A large amount of money which could be used to directly support families would have to be used for the bureaucratic exercise.

It seems to me that the opposition's argument is simply an attempt to be critical of the government. The honourable member for Moncrieff said that the opposition was surprised that the government went with this proposal. The government has adopted a revolutionary measure and the opposition does not know what to do. The giving of child care was one of the few positive measures in the Fightback package, but that package has been totally rejected by the Australian people. The opposition would not have been able to afford it because, looking at the figures, it would have had to cut about $10 billion out of the package, and I do not think it would have left the child-care suggestion as it was. The government has been able to fund this package as part of its proposals to meet its promise to provide universal child care, and that is to be delivered. Under the circumstances, the amendment is rejected.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot resist it. Let me take the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Community Services (Dr Theophanous) a couple of steps further down the road. He has had a lot of proper things to say about child care. He said that we should all be committed to this, it is important to the future of the nation. In that context he seems to think that the means testing of this particular rebate is somehow reprehensible. I remind him that it is to do with working, and one would think that income had something to do with that. I would like the parliamentary secretary to enlighten me, in light of what he has just said, on how the government justifies means testing family allowances.

PARA.TAB: The family allowance was introduced by the Fraser government as a recognition of the economic benefit to the nation of parenting. The dependent child rebate was abolished and the money was transferred into family allowance to replace family endowment, which was a fairly small payment. For people on high income the benefit actually reduced, for those on middle incomes the benefit was about the same or slightly better and those on lower incomes were much better off under the family allowance of the Fraser government compared with the dependent child rebate plus child endowment. It was a very significant step, particularly for women. It was a real statement about a community view, as expressed by the government, on the significance of parenting—not just of motherhood, although we know that in most cases it was the mother who received the family allowance. It did not matter what people earned, it was a certain amount of money that was not means tested. But along came the Hawke government and said, `This is wrong. If there is a family income of $50,000 we must means test it'.

This matter was debated quite extensively at the time and I had quite a bit to say. The principle escaped me how the government means tested that payment. The action also raised, for the first time, the issue of reducing one person's entitlement to a benefit because of another person's income. It still remains an inequity. Over 90 per cent of recipients of family allowance are women. The means testing meant that it was their husband's income that was going to determine what benefit they, the mothers, received. The only equivalent treatment of a government payment was TEAS, as it was then. In other words, money paid for students who were fully dependent on their parents was means tested according to the income of the parents. It was the only equivalent payment where one person's entitlement was measured according to another person's income, income over which that first person probably had no control at all and no right of disposal. But the Hawke government extended the practice and decided that women were going to have their family allowance reduced according to their husbands' income. That is the essence of what happened. The logic of that still defies me. Over the years since the federal Labor government has whittled away to the point that family allowances have gone. They have been combined with the family income support—which, again, the Fraser government introduced—to create the so-called family assistance scheme. The two are combined and it is essentially a welfare family support measure. The principle went that parenting was part of the economy of this nation.

It therefore is for me just a little hard to take when Labor Party politicians say, `It is the Labor Party that stands for the mother and for the family. We are the ones who are extending economic recognition'. It is not true. Many women have lost under this government.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is this bill?

—This bill is the government moving to do what we would have done six years ago according to our election promises. The parliamentary secretary tried to dismiss the fact that I had pointed out that it was only just before the last election that the Labor Party finally was dragged kicking and screaming to admit the principle that the cost of child care could be an expense incurred in earning income. It had been the Liberal Party's policy long since that there should be a rebate under those circumstances. I raised it only because the minister moved away from bipartisanship on that. I do not dissociate myself from the members on my side who wanted to emphasise choice. The dichotomy is not on this side but is in the logic of the government saying that in this case means testing is wrong. The logic of this bill is that the child-care rebate is payable only because of income earned. It is logical to then limit the rebate according to the income earned. It was never logical to link the family allowance with the income earned by somebody else.

PARA.TAB: The parliamentary secretary says that the opposition should be ashamed of itself for suggesting this amendment because the machinery would be costly and bureaucratic. There is always a certain risk, when one sits at the centre table in this House, takes advice from advisers and speaks on behalf of government, that one has not thought the subject through in advance. I suggest to the parliamentary secretary that the government could use the machinery it set up six years ago, initially to means test family allowances, to determine who receives family support. The testing is already done with regard to the family income support scheme. The machinery is already there; all the government has to do is hook this one onto it. The parliamentary secretary should not shake his head. I do not get another chance to speak, so I have to get that in at this stage. The parliamentary secretary gets unlimited chances.

The government already has all of the machinery in place. Anybody who wants that family support payment and who is earning income now has only to come to the government and say, `This is the income of one income earner in the family' or `These are the incomes of both parents in the family'. It is all there on the record. Not a thing would change in terms of bureaucracy, machinery or cost. The government should use the expensive bureaucracy it set up initially in order to means test family allowances.

I return to the original point: there is a need to means test. It is lovely to be able to give everybody everything they want, but there comes a point where governments have to rule it off. We believe the dividing line that we have put down in the amendment is very reasonable. I remind the minister that, in my speech during the second reading stage, I gave him information on the percentage of the population likely to be affected by this measure. I remind him that the Australian Bureau of Statistics figures show that people on the sort of income we are talking about are very much in the top percentage of income earners in Australia. So the amendments are not niggardly and unreasonable. After all, we are talking about taxable income, not gross income, of $50,000 to $60,000.

When the parliamentary secretary referred to average weekly earnings, he was referring to gross earnings. In talking about average weekly earnings, that figure when multiplied by 52 gives gross income. In talking about means testing an income of $50,000 to $60,000, one is talking about taxable income. The two things really cannot be mentioned in the same breath; it is like comparing oranges with pears. The parliamentary secretary was on quite the wrong track there.

We have almost run out of time. I would not want to take away from the time that will be available to move the next amendment because I would not want to miss the opportunity of pointing out that it is because of the coalition that the government is moving that amendment anyway.

TALKER.NAME: Dr THEOPHANOUS
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Community Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, it is not correct that only income earners are entitled. It also includes people involved in certain forms of study directed towards earning income and people in various training schemes. The honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan) said that it applies only to people earning income. That is not correct. It applies more universally than that.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, the honourable member accused the government of being a latter-day convert to this matter. In reality, the government has been building up child-care programs in a very big way ever since its election in 1983. It built up the number of child-care centres. For the last 10 years, under the government's program there has been a massive expansion of child care, especially community child care.

This measure is a further major and revolutionary expansion of child care. It is also an election commitment which the government will honour. Notwithstanding the attempt by the honourable member for Moncrieff to pretend that the opposition would have produced similar measures or whatever, in reality it is the government that is delivering this measure. The government has found the money to meet this important election promise which should be supported by the whole parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —We do.
—I am pleased that the opposition is doing that but, unfortunately, we cannot accept the amendments for the reasons mentioned.

PARA.TAB: Amendments negatived.
Clauses agreed to.
Clause 60.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous The Hon A.C.

TALKER.NAME: Dr THEOPHANOUS
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Community Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: Clause 60, page 22, lines 6 to 39 and page 23, lines 1 and 2, omit the clause.

SPEECH.PARA: I table a supplementary explanatory memorandum to the amendment. The amendment seeks simply to delete clause 60 of the bill. This addresses a specific concern of a technical and legal nature raised by the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. It relates to the treatment of false or misleading statements in clause 60.

PARA.TAB: The committee pointed out that subclauses 60(1) and (2) render the making of false or misleading statements strict liability offences. Subclause 60(5) allows a person to claim as a defence that he or she did not know that he or she was making a false statement. However, the wording of this subclause `reverses the onus of proof' in that it forces the defendant to prove that he or she did not know, rather than requires the prosecution to provide proof that the person did know, as is usually the case. The committee pointed out that a reversal of the onus of proof provision is used only where `the matters to be proved by the defendant are peculiarly within the knowledge of the defendant'. It did not believe this should apply to the child-care rebate.

The committee suggested that the offences created in clauses 60 and 61 should not be of strict liability but should require that the prosecution prove all the components of the defence. The amendment to this bill reflects the committee's advice and accordingly omits clause 60 and retains clause 61 which applies to persons knowingly making false or misleading statements and which already places the onus of proof on the prosecution.

Advice from the Attorney-General's Department on this matter concurs with the comments made by the committee. That department now advises that the bill should be amended. It has admitted that its earlier advice on this clause was deficient and it has advised that the simple deletion of clause 60 is preferable from a criminal law policy viewpoint. It has also advised that no change be made to clause 61. I believe this amendment meets the concern of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills and, accordingly, I urge the committee to adopt the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall be very brief because I realise, Mr Deputy Chairman, that you have to actually put this question before the clock's second hand moves on to 5 o'clock. This amendment addresses a problem that the opposition saw in the bill when it first appeared. We expressed our concern, which was echoed in the report of the scrutiny of bills committee. We welcome the fact that the government has accepted this in good faith.

PARA.TAB: I want to make the comment that this sort of thing is an object lesson to ministers. They have to be so careful about the things that their advisers put before them for their signature and support. I do not think it should ever have been in the bill. I am very pleased the government has moved so promptly to remove it.
Clause negatived.
Remainder of bill—by leave—taken as a whole, and agreed to.
Bill reported with an amendment; report adopted.
