DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL TRAINING AUTHORITY AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1993

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 7 September, on motion by Mr Free:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrews Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian National Training Authority was established in December 1992 following an agreement between heads of government in Australia in July of that year. The principal function of the training authority is to draft a national strategic plan for vocational education and training for endorsement by the ministerial council and to allocate Commonwealth and state general funding for vocational education and training. The authority also has as its function the development, jointly with state training authorities, of a state training profile for endorsement by the ministerial council.

PARA.TAB: The purpose of the Australian National Training Authority Amendment Bill (No. 2) is to insert a new provision in the principal act, in relation to the transfer of certain programs from the Commonwealth to the authority, which will enable the authority to undertake the task provided to it. There are also some minor amendments correcting an unrelated drafting oversight in the act. The opening sentences of the Finn report, Young people's participation in post compulsory education and training, proclaims a new educational philosophy for Australia. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Both individual and industry needs are leading towards a convergence of general and vocational education. There is an increasing realisation internationally that the most successful forms of work organisation are those which encourage people to be multi-skilled, creative and adaptable. At the same time schools are broadening their programs and curriculums to offer greater access to vocational education for the increasing proportion of young people staying on at the end of compulsory schooling.

Finn and others have identified the pressing need for Australia to become internationally competitive. They have also indicated that our education and vocational training response will shape the prospects for Australians in the next decade.

PARA.TAB: Concern about the quality of our education and vocational training system has been expressed by a number of sectors—by employers, the trade union movement and the higher education and training sector. To these groups must be added parents and students themselves who have been faced with reduced prospects of finding a job and an often bewildering series of changes in their studies, of which the Victorian VCE experiment is probably the best known example.

Much has been said of late about Australia becoming a clever country; but let us not be a country of clever slogans that give us a warm inner glow and change nothing. These cheap political catchphrases have been used all too often in recent years as a substitute for action. If we were to make a cry, it should be the `industrious country'. We need not only to be better trained, but also to be more productive. The pace of change in Europe, the prospect of major trading blocs involving the European Community and North America, and the rapid development of Asian nations are all causes for national concern. To maintain our standards of living in Australia, which have fallen under this present government, we must be more competitive, and that involves our education system. Education and vocational training are critical issues in tackling this challenge, and they will have much to do with deciding the type of community which we will have in Australia in 10 to 20 years time.
The influential report, A nation at risk, upon which the reform of schooling in America over the past decade was founded, states:

SPEECH.PARA: Knowledge, learning information and skilled intelligence are the new raw materials of international commerce and are today spreading throughout the world as vigorously as miracle drugs, synthetic fertilisers and blue jeans did earlier. . . our concern however, goes well beyond matters such as industry and commerce. It also includes the intellectual, moral and spiritual strengths which knit together the very fabric of our society.

Today, as in any age, it is necessary to continually review the extent to which these factors—knowledge, learning and information—are being imparted and utilised in our society. Indeed, there are sufficient indicators to show that we have failed to achieve even basic levels in the past decade. For example, a survey of Regency College of TAFE in South Australia found that 47 per cent of apprentices and 51 per cent of pre-vocational students had reading comprehension ages of between only eight and 12 years. The New South Wales skills testing program in government schools in 1989 revealed that, for each aspect of literacy and numeracy tested, significant numbers of students had mastered only the most elementary skills. A recent survey by a lecturer at a Melbourne tertiary college found that a significant number of first-year students could not multiply two by three without using a calculator. The mathematics department at Melbourne University has recorded a dramatic decrease in standards since the introduction in that state of the VCE. Even in the last year there has been a 15 per cent decrease in the success rate of first-year students in the mid-year test, compared with the previous year's students who were not particularly strong.

PARA.TAB: We are being constantly reminded by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Beazley) of the increase in school retention rates. It is true that some 77 per cent of students now stay on at school until year 12, compared with just over 40 per cent in 1983. This is pleasing, but it should not be used to paper over the problems in our education system. It is generally conceded, for example, that a proportion of students remain at school because they cannot get a job. We also know that vocational training for 15- to 19-year-olds still remains entirely inadequate. These problems have been remarked on not only overseas, but also here. In 1986, the Business Council of Australia remarked upon the shortcomings of the Australian education system in a report on education. Similar views were expressed by the business higher education round table in the 1991 report, Aiming higher, and in the 1992 report, Educating for excellence.

What did Labor do in response to these problems? It made all the colleges of advanced education universities, or parts thereof, so that everyone could be said to be going to a university. We constantly hear that X or Y thousands of people qualified for university entrance, but missed out. We have to ask ourselves, `Is it entirely appropriate that everyone who currently qualifies for university should be encouraged in that course?'. It is tragic—at just the time when almost 80 per cent of the school population is staying on until the final year of school and the abilities and interests of those students, in consequence, are even more uneven than before—that the federal government has taken it out of our tertiary sector and made applied educational training less available and less socially desirable. So we are getting into a situation, as in America, where we will have people with PhDs driving taxis.

The Dawkins reforms have meant that in the last three years, for example, the number of law courses being offered has doubled, with around 20,000 lawyers being produced every year. That is almost the entire size of the legal profession in Australia. Yet the diversity of courses on offer in the tertiary sector has been reduced as the ex-colleges of advanced education scramble to appear more like universities and, therefore, clamour loudly for the research dollar.

One would have thought it logical to try to aspire to the education models of the countries in the world with the strongest economies, such as Germany and Japan. In both these countries no more than a quarter of school students proceed to university and their industrial training is highly valued. In Japan, this is left to industry and, in Germany, to a dual system in which students do on-the-job training and learn their theory in institutes. Instead, we have set on the unsuccessful courses already charted by America and Britain.

This background leads me to the reports about education and training in Australia by Finn, Carmichael and Mayer. The Finn report, Young peoples participation in post compulsory education and training: report of the Australian education council review committee, was presented in July 1991. The committee was appointed by the Australian Education Council—that is, the Commonwealth and state ministers for education—and was chaired by the managing director of IBM, Mr Brian Finn. The Finn report sees itself as part of `an extraordinary avalanche of policy development and implementation triggered by the joint impacts of rapidly increasing school retention and labour market and workplace reform'. The report's major recommendation is that, by the year 2001, 95 per cent of 19-year-olds are to have completed year 12 or the initial post-school qualification or be participating in education or training.

The Australian Education Council and the ministers for vocational employment, education and training then set up a committee under Mr Eric Mayer, chairman of the business-higher education round table and the former chief executive of National Mutual, to explore the concept of key competencies included in one of the recommendations in the Finn report. The Mayer committee subsequently concluded that there were seven key competencies that all young people needed to enable them to participate effectively in the emerging forms of work and work organisations: collecting, analysing and organising information; communicating ideas and information; planning and organising activities; working with others and in teams; using mathematical ideas and techniques; solving problems; and using technology.

One could be forgiven for thinking that these new competencies have been an integral part of successful training for a long time. The final part of this new trinity was offered in the Carmichael report. Essentially, Carmichael sought to answer the question: how do we get 95 per cent of 19-year-olds to undertake vocational training? The answer is to link trainee wages to participation in the training system based on vocation certificates both in the TAFE sector and the upper secondary school years. It is against this background of the last few years that we can examine the developments in training and education in Australia. As is so typical of the Labor government, the outcome of its programs fails to meet its rhetoric. Recently, in answer to a dorothy dixer question in parliament, Minister Beazley said that the government had `a massively successful record in the area of education'.

The minister must have an interesting notion of success. Let us consider these facts. Firstly, participation rates for students in TAFE aged 17 to 24 years was the same in 1992 as it was in 1984, despite funding increases for the TAFE system. Secondly, total TAFE enrolments, as a percentage of total enrolments by age, declined between 1985 and 1991. These facts are graphically illustrated in a graph which I will seek leave to table at the conclusion of my remarks.

Even if the minister was limiting his remarks to higher education—that is, the universities—where there has been considerable growth in student numbers, a closer examination of the trends in higher education reveals cause for concern. Professor Richard Sweet pointed out in a recent paper:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a striking feature of the growth that has occurred since the Unified National System was established—
that is, the effective amalgamation of the colleges of advanced education and the universities—
is how much of it has been generated from within the system.

Since 1987, continuing students have constituted an increasing proportion of the growth in higher education. These continuing students represented 42 per cent of the total growth between 1987 and 1988 and 66 per cent of the growth from 1987 to 1992. Thus, continuing student numbers are growing faster in higher education than commencing students, who by 1992 were only 28 per cent of students. As Sweet further pointed out:
Over the three year period—

the higher education system as a whole has grown by over a quarter . . . Three quarters of it has come from the increased number of continuing students, at both undergraduate and postgraduate levels. But growth has also resulted from a sharp jump in continuation from one level to another—from those who have had one bite of the cake coming back for another. Whilst undergraduate commencements have only grown by nine per cent, the number of students commencing postgraduate courses has grown five times as fast.

Further, the proportion of students commencing undergraduate studies upon the completion of secondary schooling has actually fallen from 18 per cent to 14 per cent of all graduates since 1989. As Sweet concluded:

Taken together growth in continuation within course levels, growth in continuation from one level of course to another, and growth in those taking a further undergraduate course account for ninety-four per cent of all the growth in higher education student numbers that occurred between 1989 and 1992.

Not only has the growth resulted from continuation of students in study—a fact implicitly acknowledged by the Labor government through its proposals to increase the higher education contribution repayment from students taking longer than a semester to complete their courses or undertaking further courses—but there has been very little change in community access to higher education.

PARA.TAB: As the vice-chancellors pointed out a decade ago, the advent of free higher education had not markedly changed the socioeconomic profile of university students, a fact that led Professor Ronald Henderson, then head of the poverty inquiry, to recommend the charging of fees. Little has changed. To quote from a recent edition of the Department of Employment, Education and Training's Job Report, there has been very `little change in the proportion of students from poorer and less educated families' in higher education. Indeed, almost none of the growth appears to have resulted in wider community access to higher education.

To return to the minister's recent statement, the only thing massive in this area is the size of the self-deception on the part of government. As a proportion of gross domestic product, expenditure on education in this nation has in fact decreased over a decade. Only recently has the government realised its abject failure to promote vocational training. The minister recently said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is a matter of national concern that applications for entry to university are rising faster than the system's apparent capacity to respond and at a time when, given labour market requirements, vocational training may be a better option for many potential students.

Implicit in this statement and the subsequent campaign to attract students to TAFE is a partial rejection of the Dawkins approach to education which sought to bolster already large numbers by OECD standards of students in Australia in higher education.

PARA.TAB: Nowhere is the failure of Labor's approach more evident than in the fact that Commonwealth expenditure in 1989-90 dollars on vocational education was slashed from $460 million in 1984-85 to just over $200 million in 1991-92. This was graphically illustrated in a table on page 3.56 of Budget Paper No. 1 which I will seek leave at the conclusion of my remarks to incorporate in Hansard.

It is true that the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Mr Free), who is at the table, has announced in the last few days Commonwealth funding of $638 million to TAFE, which was in effect a repeat of the promises made by the government in the budget, but it is doubtful whether there would have been, given the record of the government from 1983 to 1991, any substantial increase in the past year had it not been for the substantial commitment to vocational education that the coalition made in 1991.

Let me consider some of the problems that now exist. Compared with other countries, we offer young people very few opportunities to acquire recognised work skills. Only around one in five places occupied by a 16- or 17-year-old is in vocational training. The average in the OECD is one in two. In Europe, the figure is closer to seven in 10. Since 1983, participation in TAFE by teenagers has fallen. ANOP has found that young people's interest in attending university nearly doubled between 1984 and 1990, but interest in TAFE nearly halved. Between 1983 and 1991, the proportion of new apprentices who came directly from school fell from nearly three in four to about one in two. At a time when students leaving school have the highest ever level of qualifications, employers appear to prefer to recruit apprentices from those with some work experience.

In New South Wales, for example, the majority of new apprentices are recruited from early school leavers, even though most students now stay on to the Higher School Certificate or year 12 equivalent. Between 1990 and 1991, one in four of all full-time jobs held by teenagers disappeared. The number of full-time jobs lost by teenagers has doubled in each recession, leading to an acceleration in school participation rates. Around half of those who commence the one-year Australian traineeship system have failed to complete it, and nearly two-thirds of those who have left school prior to completing year 12, for whom it was designed, actually drop out. Finally, dropout rates from TAFE amongst young people are very high. Measured by any objective standards, vocational education in Australia might be described as a considerable failure.

Unfortunately, the drive towards a centralist, coercive, corporatist control that marked the higher education agenda in the Dawkins years is evident in the field of vocational education. The history of education in the past decade reflects an increasing concentration of power, not only federally, but in the hands of the minister himself. This concentration of power has been an abiding feature of education and training under Labor and, paradoxically, the major reason for a failure as a nation to improve our education and training. The Dawkins conceptualisation made higher education nothing more than an amalgam of throughput, input and output—a mere species of central planning and subject to the same management. Centralist, corporatist control is stamped all over vocational education.

Even the language of Labor's approach, the training reform agenda, smacks of predestined control established by central planners in a manner which would have done the old Soviet Union proud. There is also a notion that business has dominated the agenda, reinforced by the chairmanship of Brian Finn and Eric Mayer of two important inquiries. The reality is that the majority of members of these inquiries were public servants, and the secretariats of all the recent national education committees have been comprised almost exclusively of public servants. Again this is the centralist, top-down approach to education.

Central control is reflected in various elements of the agenda. Take the current obsession with core competencies and the domination of the debate by those concerned to classify, measure and report achievement rather than how to develop and use competence. Let me quote again from Richard Sweet:

SPEECH.PARA: In continental Europe a long tradition of scholarly engagement in the study of learning at work has led to a strong concern for embedding process in the way in which vocational education policy and practice are developed.

Here we place little emphasis on process, but demonstrate almost an obsession with structures. The major focus of European interest in key qualifications, core competencies and the like is how these should be developed, not put into frameworks. There is far greater concern with how to ensure that apprentices and vocational education students actually learn in specific practical situations to plan, cooperate and solve problems than with putting these competencies into generalised multi-level frameworks that pose almost insurmountable problems in assessment.

The acceptance of the Australian Vocation Certificate—the pilot system designed to replace apprenticeships and traineeships arising from the Carmichael report—illustrates the problem. Only 84 of 1,100 positions in the first round of pilots were in the private sector, and the framework has been questioned by many employer and industry representatives. Even the language is not understood by industry. In a recent newsletter of the Business Services Industry Training Board in Victoria, the executive director, Sharron Dickman, wrote:

Recently I was a speaker at a Box Hill College of TAFE breakfast seminar on Competency-Based Training. Like everyone in the audience, I was amused by, and in agreement with, another speaker who lamented about how difficult it was for people involved in training to keep track of TLAs—Three Letter Acronyms!

If it is difficult for those who are actually involved in training—which must be one of the fastest-growing industries in Australia today—how difficult is it for ordinary employers to comprehend the language, let alone the changes in the system over which they have little control or say. Consider the following memo distributed by the human resources department of a major Australian company:

COSTAC the forerunner of VEETAC established by MOVEET with funding from DEET and the involvement of the NSW DIRECTFE and other STAs recommended that the NTB be established to ensure that CBT was implemented. The CSBs which may be ITABs or ITCs are responsible for developing national standards. As a result, the development and accreditation of courses must follow these standards and guide-lines established by NFROT and VETAB utilising RATE descriptions. The STAs are also very keen to integrate into CBT RPL/RRC.

I challenge the minister to find one employer in a thousand who understands that memo. I invite the minister at the table to interpret it, if he wants to, in his later remarks. We are staring at a national disaster as we are led up the garden pathways of an acronym-led reform. This confusion is not as significant for large business and industry, which can employ trainers and management to implement a training system, as it is for those who actually provide the bulk of the work and employment in Australia.

PARA.TAB: Employers are concentrated in the service sector industries and the small business sector. Employers who number less than half of the self-employed, of which there are about 850,000, declined by four per cent between 1980 and 1992, compared with a growth in employees of 22 per cent. But 28 per cent of employers are in the retail industry, compared to 15 per cent of wage and salary earners, and two-thirds of employers have less than five employees. In addition, two-thirds of managers are responsible for small businesses.

In Australia today, two out of three jobs held by teenagers are in only three industries: wholesale and retail trade; finance, property and business services; and recreation, personal and other services. The same industries account for 40 per cent of total employment. These industries employ more than half of all school leavers, and over 80 per cent of all employed students. Ninety-four per cent of all jobs in these industries are in the private sector, and 50 per cent of them are in firms employing less than 20 employees. These firms are also youth intensive.

It follows that a national education and training policy that does not involve small business employers and their managers is seriously flawed. Yet this is the model of Labor's training reform agenda. The top-down, paternalistic approach is reflected elsewhere in the training reform agenda—the Mayer competencies, the national curriculum and the Australian standards framework. When anyone utters concerns about the inadequacy of this approach, such as the states did at the meeting of the Australian Education Council in July, the Minister for Employment, Education and Training bullies them with the threat of a cut in Commonwealth funding. Yet a comparison with other nations reveals the extent of the problems in Australia.

I have already indicated the failure of this government to address vocational education in the past decade—a matter that it is only now starting to redress. As the recent report by the Economic Planning Advisory Council indicated, there has been too great an emphasis on expanding places in higher education and too little attention to schools and work-based training.

In his book, The Competitive Advantage of Nations, Professor Michael Porter argues the importance of education and training in competition between nations. He shows that those countries which have invested heavily in training, such as Germany, Japan and Korea, obtained competitive advantages attributable to their human resources. Conversely, OECD reports indicate that ineffective training and education is a major factor in long-term unemployment.

A recent report commissioned by the Employment and Skills Formation Council of the National Board of Employment, Education and Training shows a greater emphasis on on-the-job training in Germany, France, Hong Kong and Singapore than in Australia. This is not new news. The clear message, from comparisons with successful overseas nations, is that a link into the secondary school system is necessary for the realistic development of a vocational education system. However, this is a link that must involve employers at the industry and enterprise level, otherwise the necessary partnership will not exist.

This is the real challenge that faces Australia in providing a world-class vocational education system. The Labor government has finally grasped the need for vocational training, but remains constrained by a centralist approach. Yet there are instances of well integrated education-industry programs that could serve as a model for the nation: for example, the TRAC programs which have been developed by the Dusseldorp Skills Forum in New South Wales, and in the recent New South Wales Directions document on vocational education the important link between schools, education and industry is highlighted.

With three-quarters of students now staying on to year 12, the vocational education link is a necessary feature of future training. The success, therefore, or otherwise of the ANTA board in achieving its objectives and in implementing a more flexible training system will determine largely the future of vocational education in Australia.

As I said at the outset, this bill provides part of the mechanism for ANTA to undertake its tasks. There are some promising signs. The board has a project before it to rationalise the number and coverage of industry training advisory boards and to establish a necessary database about training in Australia. The board was recently charged with the preparation of a national strategic plan for a simplified system. This focus of ANTA is a welcome change from the bureaucratically dominated VETAC, which has provided advice to ministers over the past few years. Similarly, there is a case for a change of focus for the national training board, for it to provide for adequate industry participation if it is to be retained.

The real challenge is to provide a system which will work; that is, internationally competitive vocational education and training. The next generation of Australians will not thank us if we spend millions of dollars on a system which will do little for their skills and prospects for future employment. The tragedy of Labor's decade has not only been the loss of jobs for millions of Australians, and the growing gap between the rich and poor, but the massive failure to provide an education and training system which will allow their children to get jobs. I seek leave to incorporate the graph and the table I mentioned earlier.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Australian National Training Authority Amendment Bill (No. 2). The Australian National Training Authority has been established to develop and maintain, in conjunction with the states and territories, a national vocational education and training system. The authority has nationally agreed objectives, strategies and planning processes aimed at meeting the needs of industry and at supporting an effective training market which includes public and private providers, promoting an efficient network of publicly funded providers, increasing opportunities and outcomes for individuals and improving links with other education sectors.

PARA.TAB: ANTA's operating budget is determined by the Commonwealth-State Ministerial Council, which was established by the July 1992 heads of government agreement on the national vocational education and training system. The allocation for ANTA's operating budget in 1993-94 is $8.892 million. Because the transfer of national programs will occur in the middle of the financial year, the full financial year allocations are different. On that basis of a cash flow estimate, a total of $19.9 million has been allocated to ANTA for national program payments during the second half of the financial year.

ANTA's national program supports vocational education and training activities and services which are national in scope and purpose as determined by the ministerial council. From July 1994, the authority will assume responsibility for several program elements currently administered by the present department, which the ministerial council has agreed to designate as national programs. The resource agreements with states and territories for 1993 provide separately identified funding for recurrent support infrastructure. General recurrent grants for TAFE of $344.681 million are 32 per cent higher in real terms than in 1992. This is primarily the result of the government's intention in the One Nation statement to provide additional funding for TAFE.

In several ways the grants assist Australia's vocational education and training system. They provide a skilled and flexible work force to enable Australian industry to be competitive in domestic and international markets. This is an extremely important measure, one that many parts of Australia are grappling with. The restructuring of our economy, which has been going on since 1984-85 when the first moves were made to float the dollar and move to an international market, has created amazing changes right across the nation.

One of those changes is that we need a skilled and flexible work force. As part of this government I am pleased to be able to say that we have been able to negotiate through many minefields in relation to these issues. ANTA is just part of providing those skills to a flexible work force. Without that we will not be internationally competitive. It is also there to improve the skills and quality of life of Australians and, in particular, the needs of disadvantaged groups.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I know that your area and mine have large power industries which have restructured and are restructuring in the national grid process. We certainly can lay claim to having areas which have disadvantaged groups. It is a bit of an anachronism in today's society that sometimes when we talk of disadvantaged groups we talk of poor people. But, very often, disadvantaged groups come from many of the skilled people who had good salaries in the past but now find themselves—as part of a restructure—living in regions of Australia where the down-sizing of some of these industries has created enormous disadvantages for people.

It is very important that we have a training program designed for and effective in picking up the skills of these people and adding to them. They may have had a skill for 25 or 30 years in a particular industry, but upon moving out of that industry they may find those skills need to be upgraded. This is why it is very important that we have not only a flexible work force but also a flexible training system. The moves towards ANTA and the measures attached to this legislation are certainly extremely important.

The electorate of McMillan, which covers the Latrobe Valley, and which has some of the largest deposits of coal in the world, is certainly a disadvantaged area in relation to training. We are very keen to be involved in the new training programs. We are seeing many of them coming through and being put into effect. We expect that when ANTA is up and fully running we will see many more improvements in the area.

In the region that I represent there has been a strong move to bring together into a single operation many of the TAFE programs which have been and are being developed to assist people moving from one industry to another. Discussions are going on between representatives of our local Gippsland regional TAFE body and ANTA in relation to some programs that have been agreed to by the government. The planning and strategies are being put in place for the future. It will be extremely important that it is brought to fruition as quickly as possible. I am sure that the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Mr Free), who is at the table, is aware of them and will keep lobbying on those matters for the region.

One national cooperative activity is very important. Since 1991, a proportion of TAFE recurrent grants money has been set aside for national cooperative activity to assist in the implementation of the training reform agenda. In 1993, $19.1 million has been allocated to national projects. Agreed projects for 1993-94 fall into six categories corresponding to national goals set by the Commonwealth, state and territory ministers for vocational education and employment training. Some $0.75 million has been allocated under the national training system to flexible delivery and other projects.

The open learning and flexible delivery of national staff development program has now been implemented in several states. In relation to quality, $15.6 million has been allocated to projects which assist the achievement of this goal. These include curriculum and materials, staffing issues and the national management information and statistical systems. Opportunities and outcomes for individuals have also been looked at. Some $0.92 million has been allocated to projects which meet this goal. About $0.5 million has been allocated to the training strategy for small firm projects. That is a very important initiative.

One thing I found in my experience as a member of parliament—in my previous term in the parliament I sat on a committee which for two years studied small business in Australia—was the need for training in the management of small business. That is extremely important and one matter we possibly have not put enough effort into. Many small businesses are really struggling when they move on from the days of employing five or six people. When opportunity knocks they move up to 20 or 25 employees—perhaps to 40 or 50. Very often, one of the great needs of management—and it is very important—of industry is for a training strategy for small firms. It is important that that be fostered; Australia needs it badly at present.

Infrastructure grants are provided for the construction or refurbishment of TAFE facilities and for the acquiring of equipment. In 1993 the allocation for buildings will be $172.5 million; for equipment it will be $31.94 million; and for child-care facilities it will be $3 million. Projects particularly encouraged are those that: generate more places in TAFE, particularly in areas of skill shortage or importance to economic development; upgrade equipment in TAFE, particularly equipment which is associated with the introduction of new and advanced technologies and projects that encourage industry to contribute towards the purchase of equipment; upgrade older facilities to contemporary training requirements; and also, of course, expand child care for TAFE students by building child-care centres. I am pleased to say that only just recently we have opened a significant child-care centre at the TAFE college in the city of Moe, which is very supportive of the students in that region.

The need to generate more places in TAFE certainly is a topic in the education community today. In the electorate of McMillan, we in the region of the Latrobe Valley also have the Gippsland campus of Monash University, which was a CAE. A total corridor is being developed where there is the university campus and the TAFE facilities, and now they are looking at the extension of that into the new business facility where some of the more modern up-to-date training will be developed and put into place. So we have as one of our rather large growth industries in the region education as an industry of itself with the TAFE college and the university.

We also have the changing structures that are taking place in the electricity industry. Many of the people who worked in that industry are moving from government employment and some are going across to the new companies which have moved in and have taken over the privatisation area of the SEC—companies such as Siemens, Fluor Daniel and Geo-Engineering. There are many of them that are now outsourcing the SEC works. They are also using the training facilities to upgrade a lot of their employees. As well as that, the most important issue that we face in the training area relates to those 40 or 50 per cent of former SEC workers whom these companies find, at this stage, until they can generate more work, they do not need on their books. They are finding that these people are taking packages and moving away.

One of the things that are developing very quickly is a service industry from energy resource. In the region we now have groups of these workers who are forming themselves into small consortiums and companies and are in great demand for their skills in overseas countries such as Thailand, Vietnam, Malaysia—all over South-East Asia. We are finding that the connections that have been developed between university, TAFE and our Gippsland group training company are such that the training facilities are at full stretch covering the needs of industry and the opportunities of the future. It is good to see that it is not all doom and gloom, that many of these people are now taking the opportunity in the private sector to move into these new work opportunities. But they cannot do it without the training programs. That is why this government's policies in relation to this have been extremely important. It has all been a package worked out over many years; it is not happening overnight. It is extremely important for these people to be able to get the upgraded skills that they require. There are many programs being developed which will assist them.

I would like to make a few comments on arrangements for 1994 and ANTA. As I have said, it was formally established in December 1992 to be responsible for national strategic planning and funding, and these new arrangements will come into effect fully on 1 January 1994. State and territory training agencies will continue to manage the delivery of vocational education and training and allocate funds at the state and territory level. However, for 1994 and beyond each will develop in conjunction with ANTA a state training profile, that is, a plan for the delivery and support of vocational education and training for endorsement by the ministerial council. This will ensure that all states and territories are working within an agreed national strategy.

This is pretty important because one of the things that I believe Australia has to face up to is that there are limits to the amount of infrastructure and spending that the nation can afford and there are priorities. We have to prioritise where the nation's benefits are to be, and no more so than in the education and training area. I am sure that the regions of Australia outside of the capital cities, and the suburbs of the capital cities, in certain areas are well aware of their strengths and are being given the opportunity now to ensure that those strengths fit into national strategy arrangements.

It is interesting to be involved in an electorate which is part of the national grid discussions that are going on and to see the importance to the national economy of the total structure and how we restructure an industry to go into the international area. These arrangements that require states and territories to work within an agreed national strategy are extremely important. The scatter-gun approach days are over, and we need to really focus on some of the major areas. From 1 January 1994 the funding arrangements under the State Grants (TAFE Assistance) Act will be replaced by new rolling triennial funding arrangements under the Vocational Education and Training Funding Act 1992. Under the new arrangements, a single pool of funds comprising the previously separate Commonwealth recurrent grants and infrastructure grants will be passed to ANTA for allocation among the states and territories in accordance with principles agreed by the ministerial council.

A total of $630 million will be provided to ANTA for this purpose in 1994. This includes an additional $70 million in growth funding above the 1993 funding levels. For 1994 the ministerial council has determined that the same real level of capital funds as was provided by the Commonwealth in 1993 should be allocated for expenditure of a capital nature. The allocation of growth funding will be conditional upon states and territories agreeing with ANTA to pursue specific national strategies, further details of which are provided in a statement of priorities produced by ANTA and endorsed by the ministerial council. Funds of up to $27 million will be allocated for national projects, formerly national cooperative activities.

States and territories will identify specifically in their profiles the activities supported by the Commonwealth's contribution to adult literacy through the general funding arrangements, that is notionally $7 million, and funds of up to $5 million will be allocated to support interstate cooperative projects which increase student places. Examples are through cross-border provisions, key centres and areas of high cost delivery or special expertise, flexible learning and remote area provisions for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.

It gives me great pleasure to support the bill and to have the opportunity to make a few comments on it. The area that I represent in Victoria, as I have said, is an extremely important one to the nation, and at the moment we are going through a restructure which is having enormous effects on the area. A matter that I wish to bring before the House tonight, particularly with the minister present, is the need, in looking at future programs, to meet the requirements of people in regional Australia—to look at how they are going to benefit from training programs and at what training programs will be available.

In my region there is a clear need for structural change at the local management level. I am not talking here strictly about local government boundaries in management; I mean the management by the local people themselves in local government—the skills of local government as such—so that, as an area moves from being a country town, or three or four closely gathered country towns, into a city, there is a need for many of the staff to upgrade their skills, to reach out to larger horizons, both nationally and internationally, and, as workers in local government or participants in local government, to be able to provide the necessary backup and support that industry requires also in developing new opportunities.

There are some programs being developed in the cities region of the Latrobe Valley at the present time between the cities of Traralgon, Morwell and Moe, all of which have populations of 20,000 people, which are coming together in a way that will see them act as a central body on these sorts of issues. I hope that in the very near future they will have a program put forward which will allow for a substantial training component to be part of a development strategy for that total city region. Solid work has been done on this at the present time. We had the opportunity to present a fairly substantial submission to the Kelty task force on regional development, which has the need for training as a major objective.

So I am very pleased to be able to support this legislation. This government has continually moved in the correct direction in relation to policy for education. Our opponents on the other side at times make allegations that cannot be substantiated by fact in relation to how much better off people are today with regard to education than they were a few years ago. It is extremely important that we continue this process, and I look forward to our area in particular participating with ANTA, the government, the states and the ministerial council in developing real programs which will continue to assist our people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Free The Hon R.V.

TALKER.NAME: Mr FREE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I thank the honourable members who have participated in the debate—the honourable member for Menzies (Mr Andrews) and the honourable member for McMillan (Mr Cunningham). I do not know how many members have enjoyed the work of the cartoonist Bruce Petty over the years, but one of my favourite Petty cartoons was published in the Australian newspaper in the late 1960s.
—I'm too young to remember that.

—Let me tell the honourable member about it. It was during the period when mainland China was essentially isolated from the rest of the world. The cartoon was entitled `China Experts'. It featured a picture of the massive walls of the Forbidden City, with signs of hubbub and noise inside. Around the base of this great wall were a number of serious looking, bespectacled, white-coated figures with stethoscopes pressed against the wall, carrying clipboards and taking notes.

PARA.TAB: I have the same kind of problem as Petty's China experts, because since the election I have been seeking clues about exactly what opposition policy is in this vital area of vocational education and training. I really do try to discover what it is the opposition stands for in this important area of policy. For example, I have read the opposition's press releases. They hardly ever get published. I actually read them in their original form but, for my sins, I listen to speeches of the opposition, like the one given this evening by the honourable member for Menzies. I must confess that I come away on most occasions empty-handed, none the wiser. I am sure the honourable member for Menzies is a well-intentioned and very nice person, but I cannot discover what he stands for in this important area of policy.

It is for me a tantalising exercise because occasionally one gets a hint of a clue. Tonight we did get a few hints. I do not think the honourable member for Menzies likes the unified national higher education system. I think I have learnt that much. I think he resents the progress the government has made in building up school retention rates from 34 per cent when the honourable member's party left office to 77 per cent last year.

I think he is concerned about the balance between higher education and vocational education. I am very pleased to join with him in that regard. That is the whole point of the Finn, Carmichael and Mayer exercise. He ought to devote himself more assiduously to understanding some of the complexities. I think he is wrong to question the role of the Mayer competencies, for example. I agree with him that participation in TAFE needs to grow. I am pleased to say that it grew last year. But he does the debate less than complete service by harking back to figures in years gone by.

The whole point of what the government is doing, the whole point of the ANTA agreement, is a recognition that we need to get the balance between higher education and vocational education right, that we need to have the right arrangements with the states, that we need to contribute quite massive amounts of resources from the Commonwealth towards those objectives. That is the whole point of the ANTA agreement; that is the whole point of this legislation; that is the whole point of the Commonwealth's commitment of $1.1 billion over four years to grow a first-class, quality vocational education and training system in this country. I am proud that the government will be funding TAFE to the tune of $638 million next year and I am proud that those funds will grow TAFE in Australia next year by over 40,000 extra places.

The honourable member for Menzies is certainly entitled to question the government's commitment to vocational education and training. That is his job; he is a member of the opposition and that is his job as a member of the opposition. He will have lots of time in opposition to develop those skills even further. At some stage before we defeat those opposite on the next occasion, I seek a clearer statement of his own position and the opposition's position in this area.

It is very easy in this field to go for the cheap laugh on the question of acronyms. It is easy to trivialise the TRA—that is, the training reform agenda—by referring to the acronyms which abound throughout the system. But they are important. They represent important building blocks in training reform. That is not just me saying that; we will get support for those building blocks from organisations like CRA, BHP, IBM and the BCA, not to mention the ACTU. So acronyms very often represent important building blocks, as they do in this case.

It is far too common, when people discuss the training reform agenda, to seek a simple description of the system. Simple descriptions really apply only to simple solutions. One cannot have simple solutions to a complex set of problems. We have a complex set of problems in training reform in this country which the government has comprehensively moved to address with the assistance of industry, the trade union movement and, to varying extents, the states. I am pleased to say there has been quite a degree of positive support from the states—not without some exceptions.

The honourable member for Menzies referred to the ministerial council meeting in Perth in July. Some of his conservative colleagues from the states revealed the same kind of frustration that he showed during part of his speech this evening. They found the agenda too long. One of them said there was too much to read; it was all a bit too tough. That is the impression I get from some of the public speeches by the honourable member for Menzies. I enjoyed one that he gave on 3 June when he talked about the notion of convergence between vocational education and general education which emerged as a central theme of the Finn report. This was the view of the honourable member for Menzies on 3 June:

The cry from the corporate sector and the government is that vocational education and general education should be integrated, but there are two reasons why we should promote a thoroughly grounded general education in the humanities and pure sciences. A more instrumentalist, vocationally oriented education is presumed to best accommodate industry's need for workers in a rapidly changing business environment as the topic for this discussion puts it. I suggest that it is precisely because the business environment is rapidly changing that we cannot allow education to be confused with vocational training. If we do this we will find that we are producing people whose narrowly based skills are already out of date by the time they graduate.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems to me that can be summarised by saying, `It is all too tough; you can't tell what industry is going to require, so there is not much point in developing a training reform agenda'. He reinforced this point later in the speech. He said:

The second reason for rejecting the instrumentalization of education is that we are likely to have a large permanently unemployed workforce. Their education will be wasted if it equips them only to make cogs and perform industrial processes that they will never be involved with because they are unlikely to get jobs.
This was the honourable member's conclusion:
They must be educated for rational leisure.

The only policy I can see emerging from that is a policy of despair, a policy that says, `It is all too hard; let's give up'. If that is the opposition's position, I feel very sorry for it. Nevertheless, at this stage of my search for a clear statement of opposition policy in this area, I am forced to concur with the conclusion arrived at by Jane Dargarville after interviewing the honourable member for Menzies last month. In describing him, she said:

Andrews is side-kick to the coalition's senior employment, education and training portfolio spokesman, one of the Liberal's shining stars, Michael Wooldridge. Wooldridge's and Andrews' stock answers to questions about what the coalition's new education policy will shape up like is that they are in the process of travelling the country, talking to people, trying to find out what is needed and wanted.
She concluded:
It is apparent from talking to both men that there is currently a dearth of wide ranging expertise in the field of education within the ranks of the parliamentary Liberal Party.
I have come to the same conclusion and, as when marking a school report, I note: I wish the honourable member every success in the future; can do better.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Free) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: STATES GRANTS (PRIMARY AND SECONDARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 29 September, on motion by Mr Free:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrews Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I appreciate having the opportunity to say a few more words this afternoon about education, particularly in light of the comments made by the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Mr Free) on some matters of education in the previous debate. The minister took great delight in my expression of what I regard to be a fairly realistic assessment—made by most Australians, if not some people in this place—that, for many people, the prospect of gaining employment under the present government is not that great.

PARA.TAB: We are constantly being reminded that the government established a task force on unemployment. Not so long ago, the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Beazley) admitted that long-term unemployment will be a fact of life for many people. That is a tragedy and we should not simply white-wash the situation and pretend, as this government seems to do, that jobs will be found by snapping our fingers. The Australian public is sick and tired of being told that we are about to turn the corner. This goes back to the famous J-curve: things were always going to get better under this government. But the people out on the street know the reality: that things are tough.

They know we are facing a considerable period of having great numbers of unemployed people in this country. What they are looking for is hope, a sense of future security, and opportunities in education for their children. To be told in a patronising manner that things will be all right when we have had years and years and years of seeing that things are not all right is an incredible approach to the problem.

I also welcome the opportunity to speak on education matters this afternoon because the minister has said, if I can paraphrase his words, that he has been looking in vain for an opposition policy on education generally. I remind the minister that the government's commitment to funding for schools—the additional funding it has promised and which is now being implemented—and its additional funding to vocational education and training seems to be almost million dollar for million dollar what the coalition had promised in the policies it announced back in 1991. It begs the question: had it not been for the coalition's 1991 policy to make substantial increases to education funding in both of these areas, would the government have been moved to match it?

As I indicated in the previous debate, a graph of the reduction in funding for vocational education and training from 1991 to 1993 indicates a reduction of something like $460 million to just over $200 million. While it is true that the government has recently increased that figure to over $600 million, it has taken it a decade to do something about the matter. It now comes along and says, `Well, we are finally doing something'. I congratulate the government for finally doing something but it is a tragedy that we had a decade in which nothing was done when it should have been.

I will not reply to the personal remarks that the minister made in the previous debate. It was not an appropriate level of debate for a matter which is as important to the people of Australia today and in the future as education. However, I remind the minister that there are problems in education—problems about which we are often reminded by the press. The minister complained that I was harking back to some old statistics. Some of those statistics, however, are from the most recent studies available. In 1983-84 the International Association for Evaluation of Education Achievement conducted a study comparing the performance of students around the world. This study, the most recent of its kind—I admit that it is a decade old—revealed that the level of achievement of 14-year-olds in Australia was far below the level in Japan and significantly below that in a number of European countries, including some in eastern Europe.

In 1988 the Australian Council for Education Research found that only 77 per cent of year 9 students achieved the minimum reading competency required in adult society. The study also found that standards in spelling and certain mathematical skills had declined since 1980. Then there was the recent report of the parliamentary committee on literacy that found that as many as 25 per cent—certainly, on recent reports, as many as 10 to 15 per cent—of children leaving primary school are unable to read or write adequately.

If you asked parents with children in any school in any part of Australia what they wanted for their children's education, particularly in primary school, they would say that they wanted a few basic things. They would hope that when their children left primary school they could read adequately, write adequately, and carry out basic arithmetic and mathematics—addition, multiplication, subtraction, the use of fractions, and so on. Yet here we have evidence, reported in newspaper articles particularly over the last few months, that a significant number of Australian primary schoolchildren are leaving primary school without achieving a basic level of skills. It is useless to suggest that there are no problems facing education in Australia; there are. It is no use the minister running away and asking what our policy is. His party has been in government since 1993-94, so why do we still have these problems today?

I come now to the detail of this particular bill. The bill is like a curate's egg: good in parts. We welcome the initiatives which extend support to hostels for rural students. We welcome the support to be given to a pilot program for students with disabilities. We welcome the assistance being extended to students in the students at risk program. However, there are other aspects of the bill that we do not welcome.

The minister said he could not identify our policy. Our education policy was set out prior to the election. Surely even the minister would applaud any political party spending time listening to the people. That is what I have been doing for the last three or four months. I know of the restrictions placed on ministers. Canberra is an isolated place and being a minister is an isolating existence. I suspect that the reality is that the further one moves up the pole of political responsibility, such as to the ministerial level, the more difficult it becomes to get out amongst the people, talk to them, and get advice and input from them. Much of what comes through to the minister, naturally enough, is coloured by what comes through the bureaucracy. While it would be nice for the minister if I came out and made all sorts of fancy statements about doing this or that in education, that would not be reality. I know what the reality is. I have been spending my time listening to the people who have something to contribute to developing education policy. I can assure the minister that I will continue to do that and that he will see that policy in good time.

One of the points, though, in the coalition's previous policy—and it is a standing commitment of the coalition—is that it strongly objects to restrictions being placed on the starting up of new non-government schools. Currently, a school wishing to operate at a new location, amalgamate, provide an additional level of education or separate into two or more schools must give notice two years before 1 March in the year in which that change is proposed. The main effect of this part of the bill is that that period of notice will be extended to three years before 31 October for changes which are proposed to come into operation on or after 1 January 1997.

The clear policy of the coalition has been, and is, to abandon this shackle on the people's choice of education. After all, the education which individuals receive is the key to their success in later life. We owe children from all backgrounds—whether they are from Sunshine, Bankstown, Double Bay or Toorak—a fair go. The situation which has arisen under this government's new schools policy is that, because new non-government schools are given a lower level of government subsidy when they open, they are effectively put out of the price range of those in the community who are not comfortably well off. Yet again, this is an ideologically driven Labor government that penalises its own in the working class constituencies, which, if one looks around the country, is where many of these new schools are commencing. The message is: unless people are well off, they will not have any educational choice or, at least, their choice will be severely limited. They will be compelled to take what they can get at the local state school. My party for one, if the minister is looking for policy, believes that choice for everyone—not only the wealthy—ought to be a fundamental tenet in relation to education policy.

The government also announced in the budget the expenditure of $3.6 million of developmental funding over the three years from 1994 to 1996 to support existing and developing hostels for rural school students. These provisions in the bill implement this announcement. It is notable that boarding schools appear to have been excluded from the additional funds for rural hostels although they compete directly in many cases. For example, in Queensland there is a clear, direct competition between boarding schools and rural hostels. This policy seems to favour the rural hostels over the boarding schools, although the record of boarding schools in providing education is one which I do not believe can be questioned in terms of what they have actually provided over the years. Clause 15(3) seeks to define the number of students receiving education at a school. Clause 15(3)(a) states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the student attends, on a daily basis, a systemic school in the system or the school . . . at the location set out in the list of non-government schools in respect of that school . . .

Although there is provision for the minister to make exception in special circumstances, this provision seems overly restrictive. For example, there are many students who attend TAFE, another school or campus for part or many of the days of the week in order to complete parts of their school course. We were talking in an earlier bill about the desirable flexibility of a vocational education system which integrates both TAFE and work with secondary school, particularly at the upper levels. It seems that this practice is one which would run into problems in relation to this particular clause. There are also students with special needs who attend a regular school, say, for four days a week and a special school for the other day. Again, they are not in attendance at the particular location for each day of their schooling week. Most schools provide excursions or bush camps, and therefore students may be absent from school for those reasons.

PARA.TAB: If one turns to Aboriginal students, which the honourable member for Aston (Mr Nugent) has a particular interest in, there are some who may be absent to attend family or ceremonial commitments. It is interesting that awards and enterprise agreements are now also beginning to recognise that those students may wish to go to those family or ceremonial commitments. Yet, we have the irony that it appears that the effect of this clause would be to preclude those students from being regarded as in attendance at school on such days, unless of course they have obtained the special exemption of the minister. This must happen at every school in Australia, every day of the school week, and it seems ridiculous therefore that one would have to apply for a special exemption in those circumstances. Accordingly, in the Senate the coalition will be proposing that the words `unless there is reasonable excuse for a student not to be in attendance at that location' be added to clause 15—that is, proposed new section 55(3)(a).

That seems to pick up what I think is a fairly reasonable proposition. It is also consistent with state education acts where, for the most part, the regulation or requirement that children attend school in this country usually to the age of 15 has a provision which relates to a reasonable excuse for those children not being at school. It seems that the Commonwealth regulations in relation to this ought to be consistent.

Let me turn then to the national equity program for schools—the acronym for which is NEPS—which grew out of a review in 1992. The national equity program brings together a number of formerly separate Commonwealth programs targeted at removing the educational disadvantage of many school students. The new program framework has already been introduced through the 1993 administrative guidelines and the relevant legislation. During 1993, the programs continue to be administered separately within that framework. The national equity program will, however, be fully implemented from 1994. The long lead time reflects the need for extensive consultation about the changes.

The changes which occur with the full implementation of this program include a reduction in Commonwealth administrative requirements; funding on a rolling triennium basis which will allow education authorities, including schools, to plan more effectively on the basis of more stable funding from year to year; separate funding allocations for the government, Catholic and independent sectors in each state; pooling of funds within the components of the access element—that is, within the special education and English as a second language programs but not between them; and public agreements between the Commonwealth and education authorities receiving funding under the program, covering objectives, targets, mechanisms for community involvement, evaluation and the provision of nationally consistent data on equity outcomes. The Department of Employment, Education and Training consulted during May and June with education authorities and other organisations, including teachers, parents and community groups with particular interest in equity programs, about how these changes should be fully implemented in 1994.

A major issue surrounding the introduction of the program is the Commonwealth's insistence that the states publicly account for the use of both Commonwealth and state funds. This issue is one which is yet to be resolved between the Commonwealth and the states. Of particular concern to the coalition in the national equity program is the fate of the country education project. There is a strong fear in rural and regional Australia that the effect of this bill and the changes in it which will give more flexibility to the states will mean some or all of the funds received by a state or non-government school authority for schools in prescribed country areas or which are declared geographically isolated will be applied instead to the disadvantaged schools of the cities.

At present the country areas program receives $14.2 million as against $60.9 million for disadvantaged schools under the equity component of the federal government's national equity program for schools. The country areas program has been a model of best practice, distributing Commonwealth funds to clusters of government and non-government schools which then share the resources purchased. A handful of field workers in each state liaise with the clusters of schools in order to disseminate information about the latest educational techniques and resources available. It is likely that these may well disappear with the full implementation of the national equity program for schools. The national equity program purports to regard the curriculum as the key to turning around educational disadvantage but will enable the effective dismantling of the very system in the country areas program for broadening the curriculum through resource sharing and the development of innovative educational programs.

Under the new arrangements there appear to be no clear benchmarks to ensure that the pooling of resources continues. What we have now is a three-tier system in which the local community, together with the school councils, makes grassroots decisions about what is best for their schools. It is an example of democracy at its finest, that is, local people getting together to decide their own future. Under the new arrangements, with funding going directly to the individual schools rather than to the areas, it is inevitable that schools will compete against each other for what could easily be ever decreasing funding.

This comes about because, whilst there are specific funds provided to each of the country areas and to the disadvantaged schools, there is provision in the legislation that funds provided for one purpose may be used for the other purpose. The fear which is being expressed in rural and regional Australia is that over a period country areas funding will be frozen or will diminish with greater emphasis on disadvantaged schools, and therefore a program which has been effective in the provision of better educational advantage for country school children will be diminished.

The minister may say to me in response, `That is a problem then for the states'. In effect, he is handing that back to the states and they will decide which funds are used from the pools and whether there is that intermingling of funds. Given that the minister retains some residual authority to designate an area as a country area program, the question is whether there should be some benchmarks in place so that there is some assurance that the country areas programs will continue or whether people in country areas should take up a political fight with the state government, of whatever complexion, in order to ensure that these programs continue.

I am not picking any particular party. We have an instance where that has happened in Queensland under a state government. The Queensland education minister issued a statement on 30 September that, because of the concerns about the country areas funding in Queensland, he would ensure that it continues. All I am saying is that, given that there is a residual authority in the Commonwealth minister and that the minister may declare a country area, should there not be some benchmarks in place whereby there can be a guarantee that there is that funding or at least there can be some review of the way in which that funding is changed?

We propose to move an amendment in the Senate to provide that the country areas program be reviewed in two years time to ensure that current levels of funding remain in place or that there be some measure of assessment of what has happened with the country areas program. Disadvantage may be more visually obvious perhaps in inner Melbourne or Sydney but educational disadvantage may exist in the most outwardly idyllic circumstances in the country.

Rural children simply do not have the same educational opportunities in Australia as urban children. It costs twice as much for a child's education if the child has to be sent away to school or university and there is no real recognition of these costs by this Labor government. Able children are missing out in the country because their parents do not have the incomes to subsidise education at the post-compulsory level.

The letters I have read from country people detailing their plight are heart-rending. I will read one of these letters to the House because government members need the reality of the plight in the country sheeted home, just how much rural Australia is suffering because of the short-sighted policies which, in reality, foster the clueless country rather than the clever one. Kids who once could have got Commonwealth scholarships under us, if they were able students, are now often unable to proceed with their education because their farming parents cannot afford to pay for their education. The letter reads:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . I am a fifth generation farmer but my son is not keen to be a farmer, he does exceptionally well at school recently getting in the top 100 out of 30,000 in a big Science comp, in all the Math and Science comp's he has always been in the top 1%, he has just done work experience in a computer drawing office. My five yearly average income is $12,219 and not likely to improve, he is 15 and a half and there is no way I would qualify for Austudy.
The end result of all this is that he will be locked into a life such as mine.
If I lived in the city his talents would come to be fulfilled.

I realise this is not what you wish to read but writing letters is something that I have great trouble with. For every letter you get a hundred who would wish they could express their thoughts, but don't for fear of being not understood.
Not only have many country kids not been able to get a better education but also in the future kids who seek a different life are locked out by financial restraints of the parents.

This is a real issue at present in rural and regional Australia which is suffering from the effects of the recession and from natural disasters such as floods and droughts. It is for these reasons that the coalition considers it vital that the country areas program remain in place and at least at its present level.

PARA.TAB: The part of the bill dealing with special education provides that the minister may make a determination authorising payment to a state or a nominated non-government school body for special education programs for young children with disabilities and children in residual care, and capital projects for children and students with disabilities.

Parents' groups have expressed concerns about the three-sector funding proposal locking children into a sector and taking away flexibility of movement between sectors to meet changing needs. Some children are currently being educated in two sectors—attending a special school and being integrated part time into a school in another sector. The current administration of special education program funds by non-school organisations means that the services are linked to the child with disabilities and not to the specific school.

Many current providers fear that they will be forced into a bureaucratic and administrative maze of dealing with three school sectors and possibly numerous regions. Special educators are concerned that some schools or school sectors will not appreciate the considerable commitment of resources needed for some disabled children, leading to a reduction in the actual funding.

The three school sectors have no relevance to the distribution of early intervention funds, particularly those used for below pre-school age children. As a consequence, I understand that the minister is looking into this matter and that the funding of non-school organisations has been quarantined for 1994 pending a further evaluation of the program. I raise this matter because it is a real concern for many. Despite concerns about the downgrading of country areas programs, the bill does introduce more flexibility into funding arrangements. The provision of funding between programs will be a matter for each of the states.

In conclusion, the position of the coalition in relation to this bill is that, in line with our policy, we will oppose in the committee stage those clauses of the bill which relate to further restrictions in the new schools policy. I foreshadow that we will seek to move an amendment in the Senate. Maybe the minister will take that amendment on board and give some consideration to it. It spells out that there can be a reasonable excuse for children not being at a school on a particular day, which is consistent, as I said earlier, with state legislation regulating schools.

Finally, we will seek to refer the matter of the country areas program to a Senate committee. We will look at providing in the legislation some way of reviewing the operation of the country areas program in two years time so that we can ensure that those real fears and concerns of people in rural and regional Australia are met.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill 1993. The bill amends the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Act 1992 to give effect to the education initiatives announced by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Beazley) and the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Mr Free) in the 1993-94 budget. The initiatives include $3.6 million for developmental funding over three years from 1994 to 1996 to support existing and developing hostels for rural school students, some $5.1 million from 1994 to 1996 for a pilot program to assist in transition support for students with disabilities and $13.5 million to extend the students at risk program.

PARA.TAB: The bill also gives effect to changes to strengthen the Commonwealth's new schools policy for funding new and changing non-government schools. As well, the bill limits eligibility for Commonwealth general recurrent funding to those students enrolled at non-government schools and attending those schools on a regular basis. The minister is given a discretion not to exclude a student where special circumstances apply. I understand that the opposition spokesman, the honourable member for Menzies (Mr Andrews), who spoke previously, mentioned something about that aspect.
