I am sure the minister will respond to his comments at the conclusion of this debate.

The bill also gives effect to the full implementation of the national equity program for schools in 1994 and funding schedules for programs under the national equity program for schools and joint programs to support primary and secondary education for the remainder of the 1993 to 1996 funding period. I will make more comments about the national equity program later. That is one aspect which the minister is to be complimented on. The initiatives in that program involve taking in a number of subprograms under the one umbrella.

The States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill plays an important role in making sure that all young Australians have access to an education. Whether children live in Canberra or in the small village of Uki in my electorate on the north coast of New South Wales, they have access to quality education. One aspect of education which is becoming synonymous with Australia and needs to be reinforced and propped up by governments is that parents can be assured that when they send their children to any school in Australia—particularly primary students—they will receive a quality education. The quality of education should not be dependent on how much income the family possesses. It is up to governments, state and federal, to ensure that students receive, as far as possible from a government's perspective, an education that is equitable.

One of the most significant achievements in education since 1983 has been the retention rate among year 12 students. It is now the highest it has ever been. In 1983, only 36 per cent of secondary students completed year 12. Today, in 1993, it is well over the 70 per cent mark, and that is to be applauded. All governments of all persuasions that have been involved in education in that 10-year period are to be complimented for their fine work and for the way in which they have taken on board the changing role of education in 1993. I know derogatory remarks have been made by some—occasionally for political reasons—as to how the higher retention rates have come about, although they have not asked why. All major Western countries, including the OECD countries, have found themselves with higher retention rates. Australia is not a follower but one of the leaders, whether we talk about Japan, the USA or any other comparably educated country. The figures speak for themselves. Students are staying at school longer to better themselves. Thanks to government equity programs, they are able to achieve this.

In the last 10 years the federal government has committed itself to education to ensure that all Australians, regardless of where they live or their socioeconomic backgrounds, have access to quality education. The government's commitment to quality in education is unparalleled in terms of policy development and funding. The total funding for schools in 1993-94 is to be some $2.9 billion. Students no longer have to leave their home districts to get a quality primary and secondary education. They can be assured of quality education in their own districts. I reinforce the point that it is imperative that the socioeconomic backgrounds of students do not act as a millstone around their necks stopping their development by preventing them from getting a quality education. The commitment—I speak now as a former teacher—puts young Australians in a position to meet the challenge for the next century head-on and with confidence.

The government should be congratulated for its commitment to equity in education. As we brace ourselves to tackle the changing face of the 1990s, our education system is tailoring itself to the education needs of the future. I know that in different states there are different approaches to some areas of education, but we must keep in mind that it is the education of youth that we are about. We should be giving them the chance to participate fully to reach their maximum potential according to their abilities: education is there to service the young of Australia.

The bill contains a number of programs that ensure equity and access for all Australians. They include the establishment of a pilot program for transition support for students with disabilities; developmental funding over three years to support existing and development hostels for rural students; the students at risk program; and the national equity program for schools. The pilot program for students with disabilities will markedly improve the post-school work and study options for school leavers with a disability. It will include a jobnet service to ensure that school leavers do not lose their skills and confidence if they cannot find work soon after leaving school.

The program also includes the employment of 80 part-time school liaison officers who will act as a link between schools, teachers, educational institutions, potential employers and employment services. This program offers those students with disabilities a brighter outlook for the future. Students with disabilities, whether those disabilities are physical or mental, are now able to complete their education and enter the work force. Even a few years ago, such opportunities were not available. The government's policy to assist disabled students is creating a future for these thousands of Australians. I believe that such programs have also broken down the barriers and have come a long way in reducing the stigma that attaches to people who are disabled.

Sheltered workshops as such are becoming more a thing of the past and the new supported wage system allows people with disabilities the chance to enter the work force. The developmental funding over three years to support existing and developing hostels for rural students will mean that students in rural communities will be able to access secondary education more fully. The students at risk program, as announced in the budget, will be extended for a further two years at a cost of some $13.6 million. In doing this, it will provide a range of school based projects in government schools with low retention rates. This year it was extended to non-government schools. Whilst there has been some criticism in different states about the amount of funding which is available for the students at risk program, it must not be forgotten that the federal government is not the sole provider of education. It is mainly administered on a state basis, and the states also have to pick up their share of the cost as part of their social input.

The students at risk program provides a range of school based projects in government schools with lower retention rates. The program identifies those students most at risk of not completing their secondary education and encourages their continuing participation by supporting these projects. The sorts of projects included in this program are: improving literacy and numeracy skills; in-service training for teachers to better relate to students at risk and the needs of the students at risk; greater involvement of, and feedback to, parents as part of a student's education; and the development of more flexible school arrangements such as combining school and TAFE courses and part-time study.

From personal experience, I know the New South Wales government is increasing the flexibility of school education to incorporate more TAFE courses and the possibility of part-time study. It is making it possible for students to extend their HSC studies over a greater period of time and, in some cases, it might even allow students to compress their studies.

The students at risk program will go a long way to ensuring that students who have been traditionally ignored by the mainstream education system will have a chance to complete their education. For too long the role of the education system was simply to provide a basic education to students and to skim off a certain percentage and direct them into university. The universities have had 50 or 60 years of that luxury. Now the education pendulum has swung back to being tailored to meet the needs of the majority of students to ensure that, as far as possible, 100 per cent of students enjoy real, obtainable achievements and leave school with skills which will prepare them for their adult lives and form the basis of their ongoing education.

A number of ongoing factors are behind the lower retention rates in schools, such as poverty, students with learning difficulties, family problems and so on. All too often, these problems are caused by external factors which can now be identified by the trained teachers involved and by working together with the parents and the families of students. Students identified as being at risk can simply be assisted and given a greater go. To put it colloquially: simply, it is about everyone being given a fair go.

The national equity program will be fully implemented in 1994. It will bring together a number of programs to assist both students and schools that are disadvantaged in any way, whether it be by distance or socio-economic factors. The national equity program includes the broadbanding provisions endorsed by the Australian Education Council, which provides financial assistance under four elements focused on access, equity, national priorities and incentives. Incorporated in the national equity program are the school education program, the country areas program and the disadvantaged schools program.

The special education program assists government and non-government education authorities and non-government voluntary and community organisations to improve the quality and the availability of educational services for students with disabilities. The funding provides for such things as salaries for specialist tutors and teachers, the purchase of special aids and equipment, and the construction and modification of buildings. More than $65 million was spent last year on this extremely worthwhile program.

The problems facing rural schools are now being addressed and assisted through the country areas program. This program was developed to reduce the educational disadvantage of young children which can result from restricted access to social, cultural and educational services and activities. More than 1,200 schools are assisted annually in the country areas program.

The federal government's disadvantaged schools program helps schools that serve students who are educationally disadvantaged due to poverty. More than $58 million was committed to the disadvantaged schools program in 1992, enabling the government to assist more than 2,000 disadvantaged schools and some half a million students. The program has been extremely successful, as completion rates among year 12 students from a low socioeconomic background increased dramatically from some 37 per cent to 61 per cent between 1984 and 1991.

Again, the federal government has certainly given assistance to the state governments through the disadvantaged schools program. It has also built into the program the flexibility which has enabled the state governments to implement the program as they see fit. State governments are the providers of education and, as such, are a little more hands-on than the federal government. The program is implemented by the states in their own manner.

This means that, for instance in my electorate where I have a state border as one of my electoral boundaries, there is often a difference in the way the program is implemented in Queensland and in New South Wales. I will not take sides on the matter, but I highlight the fact that, under some of these programs, the state governments are allowed to implement them as they see fit. The increased retention rates for students through to year 12 prove that the programs the government has instigated have been extremely effective in promoting an equitable education system for all Australians.

The bill will also strengthen the Commonwealth's new schools policy for funding new and changing non-government schools. As we move towards the year 2000, the demand for new schools across Australia will continue to grow. In its continual efforts to improve Australia's education system, the government is making a number of changes to that new schools policy.

Since 1985, the federal government has developed a more cooperative and orderly approach with state, territory and non-government school authorities in the planning of new non-government schools. Applications for new non-government schools and schools making major changes in their operations are considered in each state by a new schools committee or joint planning and coordinating committees, comprising representatives from federal, state and non-government education authorities. Under the changes, there will be a reduction in the regulation of established non-government schools to allow those schools greater flexibility to plan their own development.

From this year, the current maximum enrolment requirements in all established non-government schools will be removed. Schools will be expected to manage their development in a way which will ensure their continued viability with minimum enrolment provisions continuing to apply.

The government will also strengthen the assessment provisions for new schools and schools undertaking certain changes in operations. The maximum enrolment provisions will apply to these areas. That is aimed at ensuring that the financial viability and curriculum offerings of existing schools are not jeopardised.

The national curriculum and assessment project, a joint assessment by the Australian Education Council signed in Hobart in 1989, was a move towards establishing a national curriculum. Regrettably, not enough direction and thrust has been given to that project. I urge the federal and state education ministers to pursue more strongly that national curriculum project.

One way of ensuring national equity is to ensure that people are not disadvantaged when they move from one state to another. Today in the work force, especially in the defence forces and government departments, people are often required to move around the country. Young people are educationally disadvantaged by moving from one state to another. As a federal government, we must ensure that that disadvantage and dislocation is reduced as much as possible. Responsibility for that does not rest entirely in the hands of the federal government and minister; it is very much a cooperative project with the state and territory education ministers.

It is imperative that the education ministers act more strongly rather than simply compile a list of national objectives. They started out with such a list in 1989 and they need to pursue those objectives to ensure a greater standardisation in education curricula across Australia.

Some of the programs in the bill involve a lot of devolution of administrative responsibility to state departments. As I mentioned in my remarks, the state departments do have a degree of flexibility. That is quite laudable and acceptable. The reporting process, particularly with the national equity program, will also ensure that the results that come from the federal government's contribution are accountable. We can see that the results obtained are in keeping with what the program was put in place for. As I have stated earlier, this bill plays a major role in furthering the government's commitment to equity in education. I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Having listened to the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Newell), I think the very first part of his speech was written by the office of the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Mr Free) or his department, but certainly not by him. It was not until the end of the honourable member's speech that we started to hear some truth from him. I think he was speaking from the heart then.

PARA.TAB: The States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill 1993 is an innocuous sounding piece of legislation. However, a part of this apparently harmless bill has caused many real families and communities great concern. They believe that this bill effectively ends the government's commitment to rural education and abandons its accountability to schools, communities, families and students in rural Australia. In fact, few pieces of legislation have ignited such anger within the regional and rural constituency. It is on behalf of those people that I speak tonight.

Among other things, this bill provides for the full implementation of the national equity program for schools—commonly known as NEPS. The NEPS is intended to align all the Commonwealth equity in education programs under one framework. Within that framework, the various equity programs will fall into four groupings—namely, access, equity, national priorities, and incentives. The National and Liberal parties have no fundamental objection to this move as it has been abundantly clear for quite some time that the government's proliferation of education programs was out of control and lacking in direction. No-one, least of all the government, seemed to know where the money was going and what, if anything, was being achieved. In a Department of Employment, Education and Training briefing paper on the NEPS, the department confirms that fact by saying:

SPEECH.PARA: Every year the Commonwealth invests over $1,000 million directly in schools equity. About $280 million of this is through the NEPS . . . Systems and authorities probably invest a lot of resources in equity programs. But no-one really knows how much is going in, nor what gains are being made. This is a serious situation when you consider how many students are affected and what happens to them when they do not receive effective assistance.

I could not have said it better. Unfortunately, the NEPS does not seem to address the gravity of the situation. Most of the changes are window dressing—new names, new headings, a lot of bureaucratic waffle, but not a lot on the ground for those students in need of support and assistance. Some of the initiatives in the NEPS are relatively harmless and some are actually encouraging, including the move towards a rolling triennium funding cycle.

PARA.TAB: I also acknowledge that the government has attempted to improve the data recorded on the outcomes of equity programs. However, this government's obsession with broadbanding, less targeting and more bureaucracy is evident in the most disturbing aspect of the NEPS, which is provided for in part 4 of this bill. It is here that the legislative framework is established to allow school systems at a state level to pool funding they receive for the country areas program and the disadvantaged schools program. These programs constitute the equity component of the NEPS. To allow funds to be interchanged between these two programs would be potentially dangerous and downright illogical. It is for these reasons that the coalition is seeking to have the relevant sections of this legislation referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training for further examination.

No other programs have been broadbanded or combined in this way. For a reason which still remains unclear, the government has decided to combine two completely diverse programs with little in common besides their arbitrary placement under the equity category of the NEPS.

The disadvantaged schools program is intended to assist schools to improve the educational participation, learning outcomes and personal development of young people disadvantaged by socioeconomic circumstance. Essentially, the disadvantaged schools program deals with the link between poverty and educational outcomes.

In contrast, the country areas program aims to assist schools and communities to improve the educational experiences and outcomes of students disadvantaged by restricted access to social, cultural and educational activities and services as a result of their geographic isolation. Each program deals with an entirely different obstacle. The disadvantaged schools program deals with poverty; the country areas program with isolation. The two programs could not be more opposite.

The government would have us believe that there is a need to combine these two programs because they serve much the same group of students. It claims that, by combining the two types of funding, schools can take a broader approach to overcoming the disadvantages and obstacles that their students are faced with and maximise usage of these funds. The government is wrong. As I have already said, they are entirely different programs, and they do not generally serve the same groups of students. In Queensland, for example, only eight per cent of schools eligible for country areas program funding are also eligible for the disadvantaged schools program. On a national scale, only nine per cent of schools eligible for the disadvantaged schools program are eligible for the country areas program. The figures speak for themselves.

Trying to merge two vastly different programs with vastly different clientele is clearly senseless and unproductive. It is as logical as trying to merge Carlton with Collingwood, Parramatta with Manly—perhaps you, Mr Speaker, understand that analogy—or the Broncos with the Raiders. Any Canberra resident would understand that trying to merge the Broncos with the Raiders, even on a football field, will never work because the Broncos always come out on top.

The most crucial concern, however, is that by allowing the funding of these two programs to be pooled there is the very real risk that funding for one could be syphoned off to support the other. That is the very real concern that I have and that many people in rural Australia have. Given that there are so few schools receiving funding under both programs, the possibility exists that some schools will miss out. The National and Liberal parties do not regard this as an acceptable outcome. In fact, the government has had this possibility clearly pointed out to it by the task force that it established to consider the feasibility of a broadbanded equity program for schools. On page 20, the report of the task force states, with reference to those that it had consulted:

SPEECH.PARA: States and systems may also retain funds for system-level initiatives, and respondents were concerned that these were not always in accordance with the needs of, or indeed necessarily found their way to, the designated target groups. As identified elsewhere, respondents felt that broadbanding would make it easier for States and systems to divert funds in this and other ways, to the detriment of the equity groups.

It is quite clearly spelt out in that report of the task force. That is exactly my concern and that of thousands of rural families right across the country. They are quite rightly concerned that this bill will enable state school systems to divert funds from the country areas program to the disadvantaged schools program, for reasons honourable or otherwise.

PARA.TAB: My concern tonight is mainly for the country areas program—in Queensland it is known as the priority country areas program—as it is the smaller and more vulnerable program and the most important to my constituency. I understand many disadvantaged schools program schools are similarly concerned their funding could be diverted to the country areas program, but I will not delve into that on this occasion. It would be a tragedy if funding for country schools were to be diverted to the disadvantaged schools program. The country areas program provides a range of resources and activities including music, drama, art, sports competition and career education to up to 38,000 students in 260 schools in Queensland alone. Nationally, the program currently assists around 150,000 students.

I point out for the benefit of some of my city based colleagues who are not familiar with the country areas program that we are not talking about providing interesting but generally superfluous activities. We are talking about fairly basic components of schooling which are part and parcel of an urban education. Frequently, schools work together in clusters to employ a communal art teacher or to purchase a minibus to transport students to sports carnivals. They do this because they have no art teacher or no means of transport.

This was never more graphically illustrated to me and to the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer) and other members of the coalition than when we recently visited remote areas of the Northern Territory and the western parts of my electorate, including Bedourie, and when we travelled up to Boulia and Mount Isa in the electorate of the honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Katter). In Bedourie, we found that the priority country areas program or CAP had provided a minibus to take students from a school with 13 students down to Birdsville so that they could compete and interact with other children. Without this funding, those students would not be able to involve themselves in those sorts of activities. We are talking about an entire shire where 150 people live in an area twice the size of the ACT.

The schools in rural Australia do not take their country areas program funding lightly. To many it is their lifeline. It is appreciated, valued and staunchly defended. There are 179 schools in my electorate of Maranoa and most of them are eligible for assistance under the country areas program. I have visited almost all of them in the last 12 months. Some honourable members might find that rather remarkable, but that is a fact. Virtually without exemption, their first words to me have been, `What is happening to the priority country areas program? Why is the government broadbanding it?'. They then invariably proceed to point out the building, the books, the musical instruments, the teacher or whatever it is that the priority country areas program provided. The people of rural Australia are justifiably angry about the government's plan to dissolve the country areas program.

The Queensland government—and it is a Labor government, not normally known for its ability to listen to country people—has certainly felt the heat and was recently forced by the weight of public outcry to announce that it will not be part of the federal government's plan to subsume CAP. In Queensland the existing and highly successful arrangements will continue for the time being at least.

The federal government would have us believe that, despite the possibility that CAP funds could be directed to disadvantaged schools, we should not be alarmed because each school system will still be required to report to the government on how it has fulfilled its obligations to the equity target groups including the geographically isolated. This does not fill me with great hope.

This government is remarkably adept at portraying the most damning performance data as a great achievement. We see that every time a new set of economic figures is released and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) tells us the economy is back on track. One million unemployed and thousands of farmers and small businesses tell us a different story. The country areas program works successfully and hits its target—a rare achievement for this government and one most certainly due more to the efforts of the people on the ground. One wonders then why the government is forcing such a dramatic change.

What concerns me most about this proposal is the longer term implications for the country areas program and the 150,000 students it assists. I sincerely hope that this is not the end of the road for the country areas program. Unfortunately, I am not reassured by the broadbanding task force report which contains a particularly disturbing recommendation. Under the section, `Allocation of Funds', the task force, with reference to the CAP index which calculates the school eligibility for CAP funding, recommends:

SPEECH.PARA: For the purposes of the Taskforce's options for broadbanding, the CAP index could be absorbed in the DSP index by adding a weighting for geographic isolation.

I think that says it all. If this were to transpire, it would mean only those schools that benefit from the disadvantaged schools program and that are also geographically isolated would receive any CAP funding. This is a dangerous and potentially disastrous proposal. I am giving the government fair warning tonight: if that is the future it foresees for the country areas program, then it should think again.

PARA.TAB: The reason I have raised this issue tonight is that I believe it explains the federal government's decision to combine two seemingly separate and diverse programs such as CAP and DSP. The federal government appears to be under the impression that isolation is a problem only for the poverty stricken, that isolation is simply an exacerbating factor for those already socioeconomically disadvantaged. The government is wrong. There is a slender link between isolation and poverty, but it is tenuous. This was revealed by the figures I provided earlier. Nationally, only nine per cent of disadvantaged schools program schools are also eligible for the country areas program. If the task force had its way, only those nine per cent would continue to benefit from the country areas program. What about the other 91 per cent?

Many of the families whose students benefit from CAP are not poverty stricken; they are average families who struggle but eventually make ends meet. Primarily, the most daunting obstacles their children face are not linked to income but to distance. It is something the government and its Canberra bureaucracy cannot begin to understand. Families isolated by distance, by inadequate roads and by irregular, non-existent transport services simply cannot provide some things for their children no matter what their financial situation. This is the exact situation that the country areas program identifies and seeks to overcome.

There is no sustainable link between disadvantage caused by isolation and disadvantage caused by poverty. Clearly the government thinks otherwise, so I am warning it now: if the country areas program is subsumed to the point that the only schools which remain eligible for country areas program funding are those disadvantaged schools who also happen to be geographically isolated, then the government will feel the wrath of rural families and communities as never before.

The coalition will not allow the federal government to dissolve the country areas program and, in so doing, absolve itself of all responsibility for the students of rural Australia. We are seeking to have this matter referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training so that the government can see for itself the very real impact of its plans on the 150,000 students whose lives are immeasurably enriched each year by the country areas program.

I believe that, unless the government heeds the warning of the people of rural Australia, it will feel more than the wrath of members on this side of the House; it will feel the wrath of many people of inland Australia. I refer particularly to letters I have received from Helen McKerrow of Cloncurry and Mrs Henderson of Windorah. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —A lot has been said about education in the House today. Even at question time the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Mr Free) advised the House, in response to a question on school education in Victoria, that the federal government provides more than $800 million to that state towards school education. The $2.9 billion that is being provided is still only 12 per cent of the funding for school education in this nation.

PARA.TAB: In speaking to the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Systems) Amendment Bill, as a parent and as a former career teacher, I am aware of the perception of education and the expectation parents have of the educative process for their children. It is our birthright to have the opportunity, regardless of means, to access the best standard of education at all levels. Education in Australia has been a great equaliser. We have educated our nation's children according to their ability and not according to their class, and that is the way it should be.

I was very interested to hear the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott) and the honourable member for Menzies (Mr Andrews) claiming earlier this afternoon that students who attend country schools get a second-rate education and are disadvantaged. I am not sure where they got their facts from. Perhaps the fact that only nine per cent of country schools are also eligible as being disadvantaged schools means precisely that; 91 per cent of them are not disadvantaged.

I am a teacher with 30 years experience, 15 years as a head teacher of science. I taught in city schools, in country schools, in single sex boys schools, in single sex girls schools, and in selective schools. When my children were in primary school, my wife—also a career teacher—and I made the deliberate step of leaving the city to move to the country so that our children would attend a country high school—a school that belonged to a community and that identified with the community. At the time we felt—and I still believe—that is the best form of education.

We have no regrets. My wife and I later taught at that school. The quality of education was first-class, and the staff of that particular high school had experimented with a semester system of core and elective subjects to evolve a great system of education. Dungog High School today enjoys an excellent reputation for producing outstanding students. This school has the support of the staff and the community alike. The fact that it is in a small town and serves a region of only about 5,000 people has proved no impediment whatever, and I believe that this pattern is repeated throughout much of rural Australia.

Only last week I visited some country schools, particularly country high schools, in the towns of Gloucester and Bulahdelah in my electorate. I spoke with the year 12 students who are starting their HSC examinations next week. I can assure honourable members that those kids do not feel disadvantaged. They are being provided with a modern, up-to-date education, and in fact they have advantages that some honourable members are deliberately not seeing.

It often amazes me that a country as young as ours, with a background of being a penal colony only 200 years ago, should have progressed so rapidly and have such a high expectation of education. Obviously, I support the principle of education for all—as does the honourable member for Maranoa. I believe it is being provided. This government intends to provide an even better service by increasing expenditure, encompassing more groups and making education services available to members of those groups.

The question is often asked whether we spend enough on education. The answer is no, and always will be no. We will always be able to improve on our education system. But the bill before us this evening is part of that evolutionary process of expanding services.

This bill identifies that the government will spend $2.9 billion on a nationwide basis on education next year. We can identify a number of specific areas that will benefit. Rural students will benefit from the hostels for rural schools program. Students with disabilities will benefit from an extra $5.1 million over three years. I am pleased to see that the students at risk program will be extended for a further two years with funding of $14 million.

For those not conversant with the students at risk program, it is a program to identify students in government and non-government schools who are at risk of not completing secondary school. Students who will benefit are those experiencing homelessness, family dislocation or abuse, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders, non-English speaking background students, students from low socio-economic backgrounds, students with disabilities, youth offenders, and re-entry students, not aiming at tertiary education in the first instance, but who may go on to further training later.

I visited a school only last week in my electorate—again, year 12. I met a 23-year-old young lady, a mother of two who has returned to school. She is a delightful person. This year she will get her higher school certificate. These miracles are being performed in our schools under the policies of this government and these are the things that we are proud of; we are proud we can ensure they occur.

I am also pleased to see that the component of funding for government and non-government schools reflects the relative populations of students in the students at risk program. It is interesting to note that Catholic schools, which educate about 25 per cent of our school population, are receiving about the same proportion of funding as students they educate. I believe that is also indicative of the attitude of this government.

This leads to equity, which is covered in part 4 of the bill. It is pleasing to see that disadvantaged schools are mentioned. I support the principle of allowing the states to nominate the schools they consider disadvantaged. There are many criteria on which schools may be considered disadvantaged, including location, percentage of ethnic population, socio-economic factors—or any combination of these. The government recognises the problem and has addressed it.

The honourable member for Maranoa does not take into account the professionalism of the teachers involved in this determination and reporting process of saying whether a school is disadvantaged. I think the honourable member for Maranoa is selling teachers far short. He imagines they are not professionals. I believe that people who go out to the country are insulted by the fact that the honourable member for Maranoa believes they are providing a second-rate education. It is certainly not my experience, and I know many teachers. They do not provide anything second rate.

I conclude by saying that I am happy to have spoken in support of these wide ranging initiatives. They positively address some of the problems facing our school education system. I compliment the minister because, as a result of this legislation, the states will have to identify where they spend the money provided under the program; in other words, the states will have to be accountable. I certainly support that. I have pleasure in supporting the bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —My personal experience in relation to the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill is remote. I heard the address by the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott) and the honourable member for Paterson (Mr Horne). They both come at the matter from entirely different angles. The honourable member for Maranoa speaks from the point of view of the constituents, the consumers of education services and government funding. On the other hand, the honourable member for Paterson comes at it from the point of view of a former provider of professional services.
—And a consumer.

—He speaks for himself, as a consumer, rather than on behalf of constituents who are consumers. Of the two points of view, I suggest that greater weight ought to be given to the views of the honourable member for Maranoa and the opinions of the constituents whom he represents. He comes from an area which is very extensive and in which, according to his speech, there are 179 schools. He indicated—some members might find it remarkable—that in the past 12 months he has visited nearly all those schools. I find it extraordinary. It indicates a devotion to his duties beyond measure. It also demonstrates that he is able to speak with conviction and knowledge about the effect of the country areas program. It is an assertion not made lightly; but it gives his views a weight beyond the views of the honourable member for Paterson, whose views as a teacher of 30 years standing are to be respected.

PARA.TAB: This has been an important debate relating to a subject which affects virtually all people at an early stage in their careers. It is significant perhaps that a matter of such importance has been subject to a guillotine, so that virtually all education funding provided by the Commonwealth government for primary and secondary education programs is to be debated in less than a couple of hours, involving approximately four or five speakers. It speaks ill of the parliament that such an important subject is given such scant attention. I commend to the House the speech of the honourable member for Maranoa.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Governor-General recommending appropriation announced.
Clauses 1 and 2—by leave—taken together, and agreed to.
Clauses 3 to 13—by leave—taken together.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I indicated in my remarks in the second reading debate, the opposition proposes to oppose clauses 3 to 13. These clauses relate to further restrictions to the new schools policy. It has been a consistent part of the coalition's education policy for a considerable time that there should be no restrictions in the form of the new schools policy which has been implemented by the Labor government.

PARA.TAB: Far from being a new schools policy, it is our view that this is in fact a policy designed to restrict new non-government schools from opening. The hard reality of the last decade is that when it comes to a decision about education, parents have voted with their feet and, in increasing numbers, they have gone from the government system to the non-government system. It is our fundamental belief that both the government and the non-government system of schools in Australia ought to be of the highest quality and that the Commonwealth, as part of that commitment, should maintain its commitment to both the government and non-government systems. As a matter of social justice parents should choose for themselves which schools they wish their children to attend, and we believe that the new schools policy restricts those opportunities.

At the present time there is a restriction which in effect means that to open a new school, or change the status of a school, a period of notice of two years is required. The effect of these clauses in the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill before the chamber lengthens the period of notice which those proposing to open a new school, or change the status of a school, must give to the federal government in order to obtain funding for that school.

Given the fact that those new schools tend to be in the outer urban areas of major cities and in large regional centres in Australia, this policy affects the people whom one would have thought Labor would be most interested to protect and whose rights it would seek to enhance. As a matter of social justice, and allowing parents the freedom to choose whatever school they think is most appropriate for their children, it has consistently been our policy that we would repeal and abolish the new schools policy. Consistent with that view, we indicate that we oppose these clauses of the bill which further restrict that access to new schools opening.
Clauses agreed to.
Clauses 14 to 43 and schedule 1—by leave—taken together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to read into Hansard a couple of letters that I have received with regard to the country areas program, because I believe it is extremely important that the views of constituents on this matter are made part of the public record. There seems to be some confusion on the other side of the chamber in identifying a disadvantaged school. The disadvantaged schools program is intended to assist schools to improve the educational participation, learning outcomes and personal development of young people disadvantaged by socioeconomic circumstances. By contrast, the country areas program aims to assist schools and communities to improve the educational experiences and outcomes of students disadvantaged by restricted access to social, cultural and educational activities and services as a result of their geographical isolation.

PARA.TAB: I would like to read a letter from Mrs Helen McKerrow, whom I referred to in my speech, who resides in Cloncurry in north-west Queensland. In fact, Mrs McKerrow almost lives closer to Singapore than to Canberra. She says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . For 13 years, PCAP—
the priority country areas program, as it is known in Queensland—

has operated in the North West and in that time it has, with a small amount of funding, made a significant difference to the educational outcomes of geographically isolated students. There is a feeling among PCAP clients that the city-based decision makers do not understand the value of this program to geographically isolated communities nor do they understand the differences between rural disadvantage caused by restricted access and socio-economic disadvantage.
I would like to quote from another letter I received from one of my constituents in Windorah in western Queensland. It is a letter from Mrs D. Henderson. She says:

PCAP as it operates now, brings the parents, citizens and children of these small outback communities together, which is of enormous benefit for the interaction, cultural and community wellbeing of both the adults and the children . . . I would not like to see the format of the Priority Country Areas Programme changed, as it is working as it was designed in the first place—for the benefit of all in these isolated areas of Queensland, where our children do not have ready access to these cultural and sporting activities.

I think those two letters spell out quite clearly the feelings of people in those isolated communities—indeed the entire community—in regard to the country areas program, as it is known here in Canberra, and indicate the level of support the program receives. I urge the government to listen to these people, as the National and Liberal parties have done. They will tell the government how the unique administration of the country areas program has brought towns and communities together, united in a desire to overcome the obstacles which isolation has placed in the way of their children's education

PARA.TAB: If this system is tampered with, if the government's concept of equity becomes cumbersome and untargeted, then some students, like those from the Henderson family to whom I have just referred, are going to miss out. There are 150,000 of these students, and they deserve better. I urge anyone who doubts the sincerity of those people who wrote those letters, or that of the 150,000 students to which the country areas program brings direct benefit, to visit some of those schools, get out of their electorate offices, get out onto the dusty tracks of western Queensland, the Northern Territory, outback New South Wales, or wherever the country areas program operates—and it is nearly always in those isolated communities—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is our program. We are very pleased with it.

—I say to the minister that I wonder why the government wants to tamper with a successful program. I urge government members to get out onto the dusty tracks, visit these small communities, talk to them and see how successful the program has been. The people out there say it is very successful, so why tamper with it? I urge the government and the minister to look at this matter very seriously. The minister's colleagues in Queensland have acknowledged the need to keep it targeted and identified. In fact, the Queensland Labor government is not going to let it lose its identity and be subsumed into other programs in Queensland. It understands the importance of this program. It is the communities out there that have brought it to the attention of the Queensland government, and it has listened.

PARA.TAB: I ask the minister to listen to those people. It would be to the advantage of the minister and some of his departmental heads to meet those people in those small communities which are disadvantaged by geographic isolation. I would welcome the opportunity to take him to some of those communities. They are wonderful people. They are a very small minority in Australia and they deserve our support. I say that very sincerely. I do not intend there to be any political overtones in my speech tonight because I feel very strongly about this issue. I believe the only way we can assist these communities in a most positive manner is to listen to what they are telling us.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate to the honourable member for Maranoa that in future in the committee stage he should be careful not to rehash second reading debates and look more closely at the clauses of the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Horne Mr R.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to respond to the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott). I am very disappointed that he did not stay to listen to my contribution to the second reading debate, because he would have found it interesting. I did extend him the courtesy of staying here specifically to listen to his contribution. I found some of his comments very interesting. The essential falsehood in his argument was that, if a school happens to be in a rural area, that makes it disadvantaged.
—Isolated is the word.

—That is the basis of the honourable member's argument. I suggest that he should look positively at these schools and at some of the enormous advantages that they enjoy. I found in my teaching career that

SPEECH.PARA: students who grow up in these schools become remarkably self-reliant and have enormous initiative. Of course, the professionalism of their teachers ensures that they do get the best.

PARA.TAB: These students generally attend small schools and have to accept responsibility for junior members of their school. These are the sorts of things that do not exist in the 1,200-plus city high schools with large ethnic populations. The children in these city schools have all sorts of problems, such as having no playground and catching a bus to go to sport. Country kids never have to worry about these problems. Their parents are in close contact with the school at all times and the school is a community school.

I can see a school group in the gallery. I have no idea where they come from. We see schoolchildren here every day. I know that schools from my electorate are here every week. Some of those kids come from country towns and some of them come from the city. Essentially, I do not see a lot of difference in the standard of education that they are getting. I make the point that the whole thrust of this piece of legislation is equality of education and equality of access.
