DEBATE.TITLE: VOCATIONAL EDUCATION AND TRAINING FUNDING LAWS AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 29 September, on motion by Mr Free:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrews Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Vocational Education and Training Funding Laws Amendment Bill is to adjust Commonwealth funds for vocational education and training for the 1993-95 triennium by way of amendments to the States Grants (TAFE Assistance) Act and the Vocational Education and Training Funding Act to reflect movements in the price indices applying to these grants. As such, this bill reflects a normal adjustment in these grants; therefore, the coalition will not be opposing it.

PARA.TAB: I take this opportunity to refer to a number of matters in relation to vocational education and training which ought to be repeated on the public record. This afternoon in debate on the Australian National Training Authority Amendment Bill (No. 2), which amends the Australian National Training Authority—one of the major overseeing bodies for provision of vocational education and training in Australia—the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Mr Free) made comments about not knowing, understanding or being aware of the coalition's policy in relation to vocational education and training.

It is worth reminding the minister of some of the principles which were clearly enunciated by this side of the House in relation to vocational education and training. For example, vocational training should be provided in a wide variety of ways appropriate to the range of needs of those seeking training, including the needs of those at different stages of their careers and life cycles. We also said that vocational training should be provided through a flexible and open training market in which the providers are TAFE and higher education institutions, private providers, community and voluntary groups, industry, professional organisations and industry training bodies.

As far as possible, government funding should be directed to people, rather than courses, to leave maximum choice of provider to the person seeking training and avoid the problems which have arisen from centrally regulated and bureaucratic modes of provision. Those who are currently unemployed should have access to training opportunities which are designed to provide a satisfactory basis for skill development and for entry or re-entry into the work force. Vocational training should not be excessively narrow, but, rather, should aim to provide general skills and knowledge which will encourage adaptability and creativity in the workplace. Finally, the costs of training will be shared between industry, government and students. Our policy will facilitate the expansion of industry contribution to training activities for which industry is to be the beneficiary.

The purport of my remarks earlier in the day was to reinforce those principles of flexibility, responsiveness to industry and integration into the education system of vocational training in this country. Quite clearly, those principles are still principles which apply to vocational education and training in Australia. Indeed, as I read the report of the Australian National Training Authority to the ministers for vocational education and training—which was released just this month and which deals with their activities since the establishment of the authority and the directions for vocational education and training in Australia in 1994—I find support for those principles. For example, in the covering letter to the ministers dated 6 October this year, the chairman of the National Training Authority, Mr Brian Finn, says this:

SPEECH.PARA: In discussions with state authorities and with a range of industry parties, ANTA has identified the following areas as those most in need of review. First, the structures and processes established to plan and implement reform are too complex. This complexity is a major problem and the reform agenda should be brought back to basics, relevant to the needs of industry and students.

Unless we have a training regimen in Australia which is flexible, integrated with industry and responsive to its needs, then the reality is that no matter what structure we put in place, if it is top down, bureaucratic in its nature, it simply will not be responsive and integrated in that way. Ultimately, it will fail or at least it will not achieve the objectives that we in this country need it to achieve if Australia is going to be internationally competitive. The second point which Mr Finn made in relation to an area in most need of review was:

Some national initiatives lack focus, specifically the national framework for the recognition of training, while relevant in principle, is not working. Interstate problems with the recognition of training providers, accreditation of courses and an agreed set of credentials are also giving rise to scepticism and frustration on the part of industry.

That is precisely the point I was making. When we ask a whole range of people involved in industry in Australia about the training reform agenda, as it has been termed by this government, they scratch their heads and basically say, `We don't really understand it'. We say, `Is there a possibility that you can actually help to employ someone through this system?'. They say, `It's all too complex; we don't understand it'. Therefore, that is the end of the conversation.

PARA.TAB: These are real concerns being expressed in industry and in circles relevant to vocational education and training. In fact, they were elaborated on in the report in which the authority said this:

SPEECH.PARA: There are growing concerns that the implementation of some of the reforms is not working and that some elements have lost their initial direction and simplicity and have become bogged in complexity and lengthy bureaucratic process. In particular, some of these processes are seen as preventing industry and individuals from getting the training they need when they need it.

In other words, if we have a bureaucratic structure which may look good on paper and may satisfy all the requirements of whatever interdepartmental committee but the reality is that it is not understood in the marketplace, it will not be used. If it is not used we are not providing the training that this country should provide and we are not providing the training that young people and people who require retraining need in Australia.

PARA.TAB: There has been discussion of late, and some speculation, about whether various states would meet their requirement to maintain effort in relation to vocational education and training as part of the agreement between the Commonwealth and the states. In the pooling of money that the states all provide, there is a condition that at least the amount of money which each state has provided will go back to that state by way of training and that additional growth funds will be provided by the Commonwealth, the proviso being that the states maintain their effort in relation to the provision of vocational education and training. As I said, in recent weeks there has been considerable speculation in some parts of the country that some of the states may not have maintained their effort. Paragraph 1.6 in appendix 1 of the ANTA report to the ministers—and I believe this report was prepared by an officer seconded from the Commonwealth Treasury—states:

SPEECH.PARA: All states and territories have stated that they will maintain effort in 1994 either in financial or activity terms and have provided data in support of this projection. On the basis of this information the authority judges that all states and territories intend to maintain effort.

If we turn to the actual assessment that was carried out, we see that it is clear that New South Wales will maintain financial effort; Victoria will maintain financial effort and also the level of activity; Queensland and Western Australia will maintain financial effort, as will Tasmania, the Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory. South Australia will fail by a small margin to maintain financial effort but expects to maintain the level of activity. It is clear on the basis of this report, which has been prepared for the Australian National Training Authority and therefore submitted to the ministers by the training authority, that all the states will maintain their effort in terms of the provision of vocational education and training as required by the agreement between the Commonwealth and the states.

PARA.TAB: I understand that there is a proposal that there be a further amendment by the government to the Vocational Education and Training Funding Laws Amendment Bill which, in effect, would allow the Commonwealth minister to direct ANTA not to pay or to pay only a specified amount of the funds provided under the act to any state or territory which, in the opinion of the minister, had not complied with the heads of government agreement on the national vocational education and training system. In light of this proposal it would seem, at this stage at least, premature. I understand that those states which, at this stage, have not technically complied with the agreement have in place legislation to ensure that they do that. Therefore I wonder what the purpose of the agreement is, given that there is a recommendation and a report at this stage to indicate that the agreement is going to be met by each of the states and territories.

Finally, I will say a few words in relation to TAFE funding of libraries. In recent weeks, the TAFE libraries and TAFE colleges around Australia have brought to my attention—and I presume to the attention of other honourable members and senators—some details in relation to the level of funding of TAFE libraries in Australia.

In the 1974 Kangan report, the state of TAFE libraries was described as `deplorable'. In the previous term of parliament, I was a member of the long term strategies committee, chaired by the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones). That committee reviewed what had happened as a result of the Horton committee of inquiry into the state of libraries in Australia. The long term strategies committee found that very little had been done as a result of the Horton report; that library services in Australia were in a less than ideal state; and that there was a requirement for further funding. I am not sure what the government has done in relation to the report of that committee. I suspect it was very little. It would be a pity if that report went the way of the Horton report because if we do not maintain libraries for educational institutions in this country we are not maintaining those educational institutions.

In 1991, schools spent $20 a head on library resources, TAFE colleges spent between $4 and $9 a head, and colleges of advanced education spent between $81 and $147 a head. TAFE colleges have almost three times the number of students of universities, yet universities have 12 times the expenditure on library and learning resources and 10 times the number of learning resources.

On the basis of those figures it is clear that there is an extraordinary discrepancy between the funding of libraries and learning resources for TAFE colleges and universities. Yet there needs to be much more growth in vocational education than in higher education generally. This situation again reflects the emphasis—inappropriate in many respects, when one makes international comparisons—that this government put on higher education over the last decade to the detriment of the development of vocational education and training.

Figures have been provided to me by a particular TAFE college library in Victoria. Based on the standards which the Victorian TAFE colleges have established, the guidelines recommend a core collection size of 100,136 volumes. The learning resource centre, as the libraries are now called, at this TAFE college has only 63,812 volumes, including teaching department items. The annual acquisition rate recommended in the guidelines is $553,412, yet the amount available to be spent on library resources at this college was only $90,000—not even one-fifth of the recommended amount.

The guidelines also recommended a staffing level for this particular college of 33.2, whereas the actual staffing level is 21.06. From the figures provided by this particular TAFE college, it appears that the provision of resources for TAFE libraries and resource centres is entirely inadequate. I believe some attention needs to be paid to this in expanding vocational education and training in Australia. As I made somewhat more lengthy comments about vocational education and training in the debate on the National Training Authority Amendment Bill earlier this day, I will limit my remarks in this debate so that other honourable members will have an opportunity to speak before the guillotine is imposed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Griffin Mr A.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Vocational Education and Training Funding Laws Amendment Bill 1993 is to adjust Commonwealth funds for vocational education and training for the 1993-95 triennium by way of amendments to the States Grants (TAFE Assistance) Act 1989 and the Vocational Education and Training Funding Act 1992 to reflect movements in price indices applying to these grants. The bill provides for the appropriation of an additional $10.872 million for capital purposes in 1993, and a total of $638.96 million in 1994 and $719.741 million in 1995.

PARA.TAB: Vocational education and training is a crucial sector of our education system. It is part of our future and an area that this government is moving on and needs to continue to move on into the future. When we look back at the technological advancement in our society over the last 100 years, it is clear that the advancement that is likely to occur in the next 100 years will be much greater. The situation we face is one where we must adapt our skill levels, we must be flexible and we must move forward to meet the challenges of the future.

It is also an important part of the micro-economic reform agenda of the government. As we look back over the last few years, with the move to a greater export orientation of the economy, to a situation of labour market reform and productivity increases, increasing flexibility and improvements in skills, the vocational education and training sector is an absolutely crucial part of that approach and is part of our future.

When we look at the question of ourselves as a trading nation and moving in that export orientation area, it is clear in many respects that we cannot compete on wages with Asia and other parts of the world. We do have the potential to develop a comparative advantage in education and training. We can and we must. If we move forward in that fashion, we can look forward to a successful integration into the Asia-Pacific region, development of our export potential and a move forward for this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —We would be able to compete on wages if the opposition got in at $3 an hour.

—Indeed, and would not that be sad? I turn to the question of equity. In the times of serious recession that we face at the moment, but now moving towards recovery, we are in a position where the question of opportunities for our young people is very important. The situation in the future is clear: we will not find a situation where there are huge numbers of unskilled jobs—the jobs that many people were able to rely on when they left school in earlier years. In order to make sure that all of the people of this country moving forward from school into the work force have the skills required to get employment, vocational education and training have to be a crucial part of the way forward.

PARA.TAB: This area of the education sector has been the poor cousin to the university sector in the last 20 to 30 years. It has been a sector where business has shown an unwillingness to invest in training. Many businesses see training as an unnecessary expense and something that is up to the government and the education sector to do and they will reap the benefits at the end of it. That is sad because in many respects it has meant that business has not been ready for the changes that have been made in the economy and therefore has not been able to react to it.

There is also a cultural change required. That cultural change impacts on business and our community. It impacts on the views of our community in relation to education. When I completed secondary schooling some years ago the view very much at that time was that you had to go to university if you were going to have a go, otherwise it was out and get a job. That situation has to change. The move from apprenticeships towards vocational education and training has to occur and it has to be something that the community as a whole sees as being a valued way to approach further education and which kids see as a real option.

When we look at the overseas experience in this area we find that it is not only an Australian phenomenon. Several OECD studies have indicated that, despite a widespread acknowledgment of vocational education and training's economic importance to individuals and to aggregate economic performance, there was not enough acknowledgment of how vocational education and training contributes to skills, which then contribute to improve productivity and competitiveness. Even though the situation was outlined earlier by the honourable member for Menzies (Mr Andrews), vocational education and training has greater acceptance overseas but it still has a problem in being accepted as being a way forward for those countries.

There is also the question of human capital. Human capital is an important part of the production process. Over recent years the question of capital has been seen as machinery, computers and technology. Although those areas are crucial to the future development of our industry, the human capital element—the training and the skills of our work force—are also absolutely vital to our productivity.

The government's commitment in this area has been clear and has been developed in recent times in a fashion which stands us in good stead for the future. The developing national framework is based on three reports, the Finn report, the Carmichael report and the Mayer report. The Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Mr Free) gave an address recently at Tyndale Christian School on this issue. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Finn committee, which was established by the Australian Education Council and ministers for vocational education, employment and training, focused on the growing convergence of vocational and general education. The Finn report recommended the development of an integrated, national entry level training system and the Employment and Skills Formation Council. Carmichael then built on this foundation to propose the Australian vocational certificate training system. The AVC is intended to improve the skills, knowledge and employment prospects of young Australians making the transition from school to further education and training and work. It aims to increase participation in vocational education and training by significantly improving the quality of provision and its relevance to both industry and the individual.
An essential element of this strategy is the further development and implementation of the key employment-related competencies known as the Mayer key competencies.

The provision, assessment and certification of these competencies will provide explicit recognition of the core, employment-related, skills possessed by young people: the skills necessary for them to make the transition to further education, training and employment.

The whole process is based on cooperation and consultation on a federal, state and territory level, with industry, with unions, and with the education and training community. The whole question of cultural change I referred to earlier relies on this. We have to have a situation where this area is seen as a desirable alternative to higher education in the traditional sense or to employment at that time. We have to work towards that and make it happen.

PARA.TAB: On the question of government commitment, in 1992-93 the Commonwealth provided a total of $910.05 million for the vocational education and training sector as a whole. The 1993-94 allocation is just under $1 billion at $998.8 million. There is an additional growth increment above 1993 funding levels in 1994 for the Australian National Training Authority to allocate to the states for vocational education and training. Forward estimates provide for a further increase of $20 million in 1995 and, in principle, an additional $20 million in 1996.

On 1 January 1994 we will see the realisation of a national vocational education and training system. From 1 January, ANTA will be fully responsible for strategic planning and funding for the vocational education and training system, reporting to a Commonwealth-state ministerial council. Also, from 1 January, the funding arrangements under the States Grants (TAFE Assistance) Act will be replaced by new rolling triennial funding arrangements under the Vocational Education and Training Act 1992. New arrangements will see a single pool of funds comprising the previously separate Commonwealth recurrent grants and infrastructure grants which will be passed to the states in accordance with principles agreed by the ministerial council.

A total of $630.795 million will be provided to ANTA for this purpose in 1994. This includes an additional $70 million in growth funding above 1993 funding levels. In 1994, real capital funding levels will be maintained. Allocation of growth funding to states and territories will be conditional on agreement with ANTA to pursue specific national strategies. Up to $27 million will be provided for national projects in the areas such as equity, industry needs and quality provision. States and territories will have to specifically identify their spending of Commonwealth grants on adult literacy. Up to $5 million will be provided to support interstate cooperative projects which increase student places through, for example, more flexible modes of delivery. A total of $630.8 million will be provided under the Vocational Education and Training Act 1992, which is an increase of $78.6 million over what was provided under the States Grants (TAFE Assistance) Act 1989 for the calendar year 1993.

In terms of national programs in 1993-94, skill centres will get $5.583 million. This will involve catalytic funding for industry based skill centres and catalytic funding for enterprise based skill centres to be managed by tripartite management committees consisting of industry, union and government representatives.

In terms of national curriculum development, currently over 100 curriculum projects are under way. In 1993-94, they will continue to be focused on priority industries, such as metals and engineering, rural, automotive, aerospace, building and construction, road transport, printing, food processing, manufacturing, information industries, electrical and electronics industries, and health industries.

In terms of traineeship development grants, $1.335 million will be provided to improve training materials for traineeships, both for those under the Australian traineeship system and career start traineeships. Basic training manuals will continue to be produced by the Commonwealth, with a greater emphasis on competency based training.

I also refer to the training guarantee levy. Part of the government's overall vocational education and training agenda concerns bringing a cultural change in industry, particularly to industry's view of training. A 97 per cent compliance rate is a pleasing indication that a lot of employers have already moved to a greater emphasis on training. Another feature of training is that it is meant to prevent skills theft. Basically, those employers who have been responsible and far-sighted in meeting their training development needs have in the past been subject to poaching from other employers who have not had the same visionary outlook. Pushing along this line creates hope for avoiding that sort of thing occurring.

The simplification of reporting requirements that was recently announced will reduce problems in relation to accountants, et cetera, preying on confused employers. This will be achieved through the two-year averaging technique.

Vocational education and training, as a future direction for this economy, can and must work. The criticism that is often made is that we are training people for jobs that do not exist. In some respects, when we are looking at training needs for the future, this will always be a problem and this argument will always be raised, particularly in times of high unemployment. But we have to make those training changes for the future. We have to look to that future and the jobs that have not yet been achieved or discovered. But they will come, as they came in the past in industries that, 10 or 20 years ago, we never thought would provide large-scale employment.

We should not look at a situation where skills development will necessarily lead to massive job loss. An example of a study of technological modernisation is the Swedish banking industry, which predicted a drop in employment of 10,000 workers over five years on the basis of capital labour substitutions in other sectors. Instead, the result was an employment increase of 10,000, due in large part to dramatic job restructuring and training, adaptation, moving forward, developing the niche aspects of those industries and, in that way, improving productivity and, in many respects, job opportunities. The piloting process for the Australian vocational certificate is under way. I will again read from the minister's speech on the issue:

SPEECH.PARA: At present there are 68 institution-based pilot projects testing the implementation of the AVCS in schools and TAFE. 3,700 students will participate in these projects which form more than half of the 111 projects which have been approved for funding in a first round of AVC pilot projects.

The other 43 projects are work based. The work based pilots will provide employment and training opportunities for approximately 2,200 trainees. All these pilots have been developed through a cooperative national process involving the Commonwealth, state and territory governments, industry, unions and the broader education and training community. That is the way to go for the future.

PARA.TAB: In summary, we face the situation of having to adapt. We have to move forward and develop ourselves to meet the needs of our region and the future. As we look to that future, we can see great change in relation to the labour market and the international economy. We have to adapt to those changes. A key way to do that will be through vocational education and training. It is not the only way. But if we do not do it through this sector, the overall success of this government—which I believe will be successful in this area and with this economy—will not be as good as it once might have been.

We have to take note of that training need by working towards it nationally, cooperatively and consultatively. We have to ensure that industry is onside and is part of the process. We have to ensure that the TAFE sector and other aspects of the vocational education and training field support this process and are a party to it. If those people who are crucial to the actual development of a new system and its operation are not supportive, it will be sadly lacking.

The indications are encouraging. The signs are that the change can be made, that the sector is flexible and adaptable to the changing needs and can develop, as it has developed to an extent in recent years, programs that are required for the new labour market we now face. I am confident that the sector can do so and I am confident that we as a government, through budgetary and legislative matters and through our overall vision in this sector, can make the required changes.

We have to look to overseas experience. We have to look to the needs of the international economy and how that will impact upon us. We have to make those changes regularly and develop a sector which is able to do that on an ongoing basis. That will require funding and cooperation. It will require organisations such as the Australian National Training Authority to oversee it. It will require much of the vision shown in the Finn, Carmichael and Mayer reports. It will develop a situation where the people of this country who in the past were often in low paid and unskilled work are capable of adapting and learning to move into areas of new skilled development and where people are recognised for the skills that they have rather than the qualification they might have. We have to ensure that the development of the system incorporates that. We have to achieve the cultural change that I spoke of earlier. We have to be in a position where we all move together on that basis. We can do it. We are doing it. This legislation is a part of that and I commend it to this House.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Vocational Education and Training Funding Laws Amendment Bill is interesting. The crowd in the chamber numbers seven people plus a couple of Labor Party supporters. For the benefit of listeners, I would like to paint a picture of what is happening out in the world instead of the rather narrow, bureaucratic presentation of the previous speaker, the honourable member for Corinella (Mr Griffin). He ran through the whole gamut of expenditure that can be easily read from the explanatory memorandum. I would like to speak about what I find in the area that I represent.

PARA.TAB: Major educational change rests on a couple of key areas in our community. These key areas are, firstly, middle managers who have lost their jobs and must redefine themselves in the workplace. They have to reskill and relearn a lot of things that they thought they would never have to learn. Often they have spent 20 to 25 years carving out a niche for themselves in the workplace. Upon redundancy they find they have to reskill and retrain. It is not an easy process.

The second group of people with difficulties are those at the younger end of the spectrum who have very modest academic achievements and for whom the educational system offers nothing whatsoever. In fact, they try to run away from formal education by staying on until year 12 in a course they cannot handle. They then enter the workplace at the age of 18 with a poor pass in the higher school certificate and with no ability to attract much support from an employer. Those young people are ready candidates for the unemployment queues.

The next group includes those who leave school at the earliest possible age to avoid the rigours of school life. They drift from unskilled job to unskilled job, never chalking up a record of consistent employment, being occasionally employed or, unfortunately under the policies of the current government, never employed. I also see people who range across the age groups and who have few or little skills. These people are referred to as the victims of changing technology.

In my electorate we have all of these victims of the terrible policies of the federal Labor Party. The government did nothing at the election to promise to rectify these terrible policies. It broke the promises it made. Let us look at what the problem is and see how we might go about fixing it.

TALK.START.PARA: —What promises did we break?

—Has the honourable member not noticed unemployment? Does he have none in his electorate? Surely the honourable member does not come to this place so unobservant and so uncaring for his electorate that he does not acknowledge the record high unemployment in Australia. We have this uncaring attitude being expressed in this House by members of the Labor Party. It is no wonder that the budget program acknowledges that there is not going to be any change in unemployment levels during the next 12 months.

PARA.TAB: The Minister for Justice (Mr Kerr) is also uncaring about unemployment levels. If the minister does not think the solution to unemployment is partially educational, then he should not be in his job. If he does not think part of the problem is a lack of education and a need for new direction in education, then he is wrong. What we need is a change in processes for the educational services of Australia. This applies from evening colleges through to university level. In part these bills try to rectify those problems, but it is a bureaucratic driven process.

In private enterprise there is cutting edge stuff being done in educational services and educational change that the minister does not even recognise or know about. Even the government's low level programs of vocational skills, whether they be in skillshare or in jobs clubs, are let to private enterprise. Is the minister aware of that? No. He has never heard of those programs. He has not been involved with them. He does not recognise the low level education process that starts the kick-on for somebody wanting to climb the ladder of success that can lead from evening colleges or private education to TAFE or universities.

The integration of this process is part of what is advocated with these bills. They are welcome changes. For instance, the Australian vocational certificate is something that starts to put building blocks in place for achievement and recognition. I acknowledge that. But there is much more that needs to be done. It is time that the minister and his government recognised that there is much more that they can do, there is much more integration that can take place, and there is much more innovation that should be searched out and adopted.

In fact the government got it half right 12 months after it should have taken action of this sort, and probably two years after the whole of the unemployment-educational mix became obvious to anybody in Australia—obvious, that is, except to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). Day after day the Prime Minister says in this place, `She'll be right. The glass is running over. This is the one that will bring home the bacon'. Again today the Prime Minister said that the recovery is on the way and that we do not need to worry about jobs problems because he has solved the jobs problem.

That is not right, and it will not be right for a long time. We cannot live on the polemic of the Prime Minister because it is falsely based. The Prime Minister should know that, but every couple of months he says that we are at the point of recovery.

I want to look now at the development of greater flexibility and the need for greater integration between educational services, whether public or private, at the TAFE, technical college or university level. The secondary education system is presently supplying a greater number of vocational skills than it did previously. Part of the problem students have in applying this greater number of vocational based skills is that they are not always relevant to the needs of the workplace. The integration of workplace needs with the schooling system is something that governments—federal and state—have been trying to cope with for a long time.

There have been some welcome changes as state governments have struggled to make the last two years or additional year of education more relevant to the workplace. It is hoped that, with further development of the Australian vocational certificate, there will be a recognition of what can happen in the secondary education system. We have not fully explored that yet, but I believe that the integration of secondary schooling and TAFE is a significant step in the advancement of the Australian vocational certificate.

There is an overemphasis by government on government systems. Introducing a better vocationally based system to the secondary school system, noting the advice of voluntary services and professional groups in our community which assist the development of school based curricula, and identifying vocational opportunities for final year students are all things not yet fully recognised and explored by many state governments and which will need further development.

The next level that needs attention is the mix of evening colleges—which is often referred to as recreational education—and TAFE. Evening colleges in Australia are offering a wider range of courses, and many of these are career oriented—they are not purely a matter of recreation.

Recently, the demand for courses in computer literacy was highlighted by a survey of 2,000 businesses in the electorate of Mitchell. Those businesses outlined the sorts of people they want to employ. Two thousand of them responded to the question: if they were to put on another person, what sorts of skills would they want from that person? The overwhelming response was that every person they employed from now on must have keyboard and computing skills; they must be self-sufficient to some degree. Businesses are no longer prepared to employ computer professionals or keyboard operators as support services. They want people who can be self-supporting—who can find their way around a computer keyboard with the simplest word processing packages or the most common database packages. That was the overwhelming response.

The second highest response from these businesses was that they lacked people with interpersonal relationship skills. They cannot find people who can relate to others, whether they be people in the workplace or clients. I see nods of agreement in relation to that. Neither the minister nor the government has sought to identify how these sorts of skills can be best developed. These are the skills that drive private enterprise. They create opportunities and jobs, produce better sales and service, and inspire a will for excellence. They provide the best opportunities for Australian businesses.

How does our education system cope with these sorts of nebulous demands? The fact of the matter is that the education system is not coping with these sorts of nebulous demands. The only places even slightly catering for the demand—I believe that further development is needed—are the private education and evening college sectors, where short courses of 12 weeks to a year provide basic keyboard skills for people.

The courses provide only basic skills, but employers say that they want basic information. At the moment, there is no recognition of that as a starting point for a more complex computer course. We have a demand out there that the system is not meeting, and because the system is not meeting the demand, the job creation process is not as great as it could or should be.

The third area that I want to deal with relates to mature middle management redundancy, which is so much a part of my electorate. There is a lot of pain, and counselling is needed for people who find themselves, after a career of 15 to 25 years, suddenly out of work. Their expectations have suddenly been crushed. They have been removed from the whole system of their profession or their area of expertise by the flattening of the hierarchy within an organisation so that the steps between the base of the pyramid and the top are reduced. People in middle management are the ones who are squeezed out in that process.

These middle managers, male or female, tend to be married, they tend to have teenage kids and they tend to have mortgages. Suddenly, they find that a major component of family life and its wellbeing has been removed. How can those people get back into the work force and become a productive part of our society, drawing on their experience and knowledge?

In the Mitchell electorate we have found it very difficult to find appropriate courses for that sort of person. Attitudes are part of it because there is a degree of reluctance to admit lack of knowledge and lack of skill. There is even a reluctance to admit an incapacity to prepare a resume. These people have not prepared resumes for many years, so even that basic skill is lacking. To capture a new skill, maybe at a lower level, is something that I believe the educational services of Australia need to be aware of. They need to go out and capture, design packages for, and draw on the expertise of this group of people. It is not happening.

Where will it happen? TAFE—technical and further education—has a degree of flexibility that is almost unbelievable. It is capable of designing courses and providing accreditation. We are on the verge of a very exciting development in technical and further education. We need to supplement TAFE with the building block that takes people once in that process through to the upper university level.

The closest and best known university in the area where I come from in New South Wales is the University of Western Sydney; a university which this government currently does not seem to acknowledge as being worthy of special or additional support.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, Alan. Come off it.

—The minister attended those meetings. He was as surprised as I was at what representatives from the university were saying about the government's administration. The minister heard it. Why does he not admit it? He was there and he saw it. He knows it.

PARA.TAB: There has to be acknowledgment within the government that the University of Western Sydney has special claims. Both Liberal and Labor members in the west have worked together. Tonight we are saying that there are special needs that have to be acknowledged because of the demand for services in Western Sydney, and because of the educable age group of the people in Western Sydney who are most suitable and most likely to take up university courses. Therefore, the government needs to take an initiative and acknowledge that the University of Western Sydney has special claims that are not being met.

Other places do not have the same market. Other places do not have the diversity of opportunity. I believe that other universities do not have the depth of vocationally based courses that the University of Western Sydney offers. Whether it be the south at Camden at the Macarthur campus, the Nepean campus or the Hawkesbury campus, there is a diversity that should be recognised.

I will listen very carefully to hear what the minister says about the government's additional intentions towards the University of Western Sydney because, whilst I think his intentions remain good, I do not know whether the government is prepared to commit itself to the additional resources and support that I believe will help to integrate the levels of educational exchange that are needed from secondary schools, evening colleges, and technical and further education through to the universities so that we can have a full spectrum of government supplied services.

I enter a special plea that those services which are being provided privately are also integrated in that process and some of the skills, knowledge, drive and expertise of privately offered education can be amalgamated with this process as well. I acknowledge the government's intentions for the Vocational Education and Training Funding Laws Amendment Bill and where the government intends to move. I am saying that it is a slow process. It is a bureaucratic process. I would like to see it less bureaucratic and I would like to see greater haste.

I would like to outline the background to and purpose of these amendments to the Vocational Education and Training Funding Laws Amendment Bill 1993. The amendments are being introduced as a precautionary measure pending implementation of all the essential elements of the new training arrangements based on the Australian National Training Authority, ANTA. In particular, the Commonwealth is concerned that most states and territories have not yet introduced the complementary legislation which heads of government agreed would be necessary to give full effect to their July 1992 agreement on the national vocation education and training system.

PARA.TAB: The amendments provide that, if the Commonwealth minister determines that a state or territory has not met its obligations under the 1992 heads of government agreement, the minister could direct ANTA not to pay any or only a limited amount of Commonwealth funds to that state or territory. This new power is tied explicitly to the provisions of the heads of government agreement and could not be used by the government to impose additional requirements on the states and territories.

In introducing this legislation, there is no intention to undermine the ANTA arrangements and there is no criticism of the operation of ANTA itself. Indeed, the objective is to ensure that the ANTA arrangements are put on a firm footing by ensuring that the states and territories meet their obligations from the outset. For this reason the legislation provides that the new power to withhold funds would be available to the Commonwealth minister only until the end of 1995. There would be no ongoing power for Commonwealth intervention in the allocation of funds through ANTA. I present the supplementary explanatory memorandum for these amendments to the bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to respond to the comments by the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Mr Free) in relation to these amendments. The minister has indicated that part of the agreement between the Commonwealth and the states pertaining to ANTA involves the introduction of complementary legislation on the part of the states, that that remains to be done in some instances and also that there is a requirement that the states maintain their efforts in relation to their provision of vocational education and training.

PARA.TAB: As I indicated earlier, the report of the Australian National Training Authority to the ministers for vocational education, under a covering letter of 6 October, indicated maintenance of effort after analysis had been complied with in relation to the states. If the report of the National Training Authority is to be accepted by the ministerial council and the minister, who is at the table, the purpose of this particular amendment can therefore only pertain to the introduction of complementary legislation.

The opposition will not be opposing the amendments here, but I will take the opportunity later to look at them in more detail. I am not thereby indicating that that would necessarily be the position that we would take in another place. My only concern in reading the crucial clause of the amendment, namely 14A(2), is that, whereas the minister in his earlier comments referred to Commonwealth funding, that does not seem to be a limitation in the clause itself.

I understand that the ministers at their July meeting had agreed to a resolution in relation to the process of transfer of funds between the states and territories and the Commonwealth. In their resolution, the ministers expressed a preference for a notional transfer arrangement between the states and territories. If that in fact is the transfer arrangement, then the matter which I am raising by way of precaution does not arise.

However, if there is the possibility that it could relate to all funds transferred to ANTA, then there might be some concern as to the scope of the amendment on the part of the states. I highlight that. If the minister is able to assure me that that is not the case, then he will relieve a concern which arose from my listening to what the minister had to say and reading this particular clause. Apart from that, there are no other matters which I wish to raise in relation to this particular amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Mr FREE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity to set my friend's mind at rest. I am advised that the term `VET funding' refers to Commonwealth funding as provided under the principal act. The other aspect to which the honourable member for Menzies (Mr Andrews) refers, that is, the requirement for the states under the ANTA agreement to actually transfer funds to ANTA, rather than a notional transfer, is a separate matter which is being pursued with the states. It does not apply to this amendment.
