SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry that we appear to be moving quicker than normally is the case under a guillotine and that the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security (Mr Sciacca) or the Minister for Social Security (Mr Baldwin) is not here to deal with this very important Social Security Amendment Bill (No.2) 1993. Hopefully they will arrive at some point during the debate so that they can take note of the important questions that I intend to raise on the bill.

PARA.TAB: According to the explanatory memorandum, the bill is designed to give effect to a number of measures announced in the budget amending the Social Security Act 1991. They are, first, to increase the rate of payment for certain newstart beneficiaries; secondly, to apply the family payment income and assets tests to student parents; thirdly, to reduce the income ceiling and assets test limit for basic family payments; and, fourthly, to limit arrears of family payment. I welcome the parliamentary secretary into the chamber.

As has been the government's wont on these matters, the government has mixed a number of benefits which it has provided for some persons with other reductions of quite a significant character. In the context of this debate, I would like to draw to the attention of the House the changes that have occurred—in particular, the adverse nature of those changes—that affect many individuals who were undoubtedly unaware of the impact that these decisions might have on them at this time.

The first measure is the increased payment for certain newstart allowees. That provides a $3 per week increase in the rate of newstart allowance for single people only. As I understand it, those who are married and have dependent children already receive a higher rate. The recipients of this allowance have to be aged between 21 years and 59 years and not have dependent children or, if they are aged 60 years and over, not have dependent children and not have received a social security benefit continuously for at least six months.

I understand that some 253,300 newstart allowees will benefit from this measure each fortnight. This is in addition to some 31,700 recipients who will benefit from this measure under schemes administered by the Department of Employment, Education and Training and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. That is a useful extension of benefit, but it ought to be understood that it does not cover—this point should be noted in relation to this particular question—the increased costs of living which most unemployed people have experienced as a result of the 1993 budget. When one includes the sales taxes, the fuel excise and the other cost of living increases it is a fairly mediocre sum.

TALK.START.PARA: —You were going to take them off unemployment benefits after nine months.

—I will come to that, because that is one of the matters that I think ought to be noted. This initiative is only of a limited nature. It does not apply to all unemployed persons. Those people who are in receipt of the jobsearch allowance, as distinct from newstart which is available only to the longer term unemployed people who are single and do not have dependants, will not receive any benefit.
—But they will, won't they?

—Does the parliamentary secretary mean that, as a result of the greenmail, there may be some additional benefits? The fact is that the government's intention was not to provide that benefit. That ought to be clearly understood. The government was not interested in social justice. It had to be bludgeoned into it. The benefits that the parliamentary secretary now claims would be available to the wider class of people are only possible because of the decisions that we took in relation to the budget, which put the greenmailers, as I have seen them referred to, in a unique position in dealing with the government.

PARA.TAB: These budget measures have also been designed to dovetail with other initiatives that the government has taken. I, along with the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Howe), have been with ACOSS this afternoon. I know that one of the matters it was very concerned about was the government's decision to introduce activity testing. We dealt with that last evening, and I would not want to reopen debates, but in relation to those tests, which the government did not announce and did not see fit to put in any of its policies before the last election, the government expects to get some 30,000 unemployed people off benefits.

Essentially, the people who will come off benefits will be those of a non-English speaking background, those who are more disadvantaged and less able to understand the complexity of the provisions. The government will put the secretary of the social security department in a position where he will be able to take people off benefits if they are not complying with activity agreements. Activity testing is designed to save money and get people off benefits.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish.
—What did you say?
—That's rubbish.

—The honourable member has qualified it, but they are words of equal colour. He is really saying that these measures were not intended to make savings. The fact is that, if we look at the explanatory memorandum to the Social Security (Budget and Other Measures) Bill, we see that savings were intended. There are no savings unless people come off benefits. Activity testing was designed to take people off benefits.

PARA.TAB: This government is requiring the unemployed to engage in nefarious tasks without finding them jobs. That is what it is involved in. It is a very clear situation of what I would call studied inactivity on the part of this government. The government is not dealing with long-term problems of unemployment; it is simply creating hurdles over which the unemployed have to jump in order to get their benefits. That is what we are seeing in relation to the way in which the newstart allowance and the jobsearch allowance activity testing is being undertaken.

This benefit may help address some of the increased costs that the unemployed will experience. The widening of it in relation to others under greenmail may assist others, but that was not the government's original intention. We know that of the order of one-third of all unemployed persons have been unemployed now for over one year and one-half of these people have been unemployed for over two years. The long-term unemployment problem is expected to worsen.

Let us look at some of the studies that have been undertaken by the government's own agents. I refer, in particular, to a paper by Richard Yetsenga, Maureen Maclachlan and Meredith Edwards of the Economic and Policy Analysis Division of DEET, who are very critical of the government's policies in this area. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Given current policies, it is likely that the level of very long term unemployed will continue to increase over the next few years . . .
The paper continues:

If the levels of very long term unemployed people we can expect in the next few years are a cause for concern, and we believe they are, then what is needed are policies that effectively target this group . . .

In relation to that group which has been unemployed for two years or more—176,000, nearly one-fifth of all those who are unemployed—the number of very long-term unemployed has increased from 34,000 in April 1980 to that figure of 176,000, which is a five-fold increase, and largely achieved under a Labor government. Is it any wonder that I call this studied inactivity? At the moment we are waiting for the government to get around to having a further report from the committee on employment opportunities. It postponed its reporting date. At this time we have no immediate solution. All we have got, even with that report being sought, is another excuse for further inactivity on the government's part.

PARA.TAB: Long-term unemployment is distributed very unevenly throughout the community. It is concentrated amongst such groups as the young, recent migrants, older workers, Aboriginal people, and people lacking skills and education. It is geographically concentrated particularly in the large metropolitan centres of Melbourne and Sydney, which are adversely affected. According to the Brotherhood of St Laurence, one of the major reasons for long-term unemployment has been that this government has not seen it as one of its key priorities. What we have seen as a matter of priority—

TALK.START.PARA: —They are wrong.

—One could not but think otherwise when one sees the amount of attention that is being paid to changing our constitutional arrangements, or in relation to Mabo, which I think is an important issue but which still is not a matter which ought to occupy people's time to the extent that we do not get—
—The committee will report tomorrow.

—I do not know what committee is reporting tomorrow. What I do know is that unemployment is one of the most serious social problems that have ever faced this nation. It is causing unacceptable social inequities, personal hardships and enormous economic damage. It has happened under a Labor government. These are the people who talk about social justice. We are in a situation in which, in this period of unemployment, those people who are rich are continuing to get richer and those people who are poor are further disadvantaged.

PARA.TAB: I must say I was somewhat shocked yesterday when I attended a seminar conducted by the Parliamentary Library on this question of social justice. There was a report from an organisation that the parliamentary secretary's department is involved in supporting the Social Policy Research Centre at the University of New South Wales. I want to quote from that report of its principal, Mr Peter Saunders, entitled Poverty, inequality and recession. On page 19, in relation to this question of inequity, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . it does appear that, among families at least, the recession which began in 1990 has worsened income inequality, possibly by a considerable amount. And it needs to be remembered that this change has come on top of a substantial period—probably extending back to the mid-seventies—during which income inequality has been steadily increasing.

Those are the sorts of comments that I think are particularly germane to these observations that arise when the government increases by such a modest amount the payment to certain newstart allowees. It is not going to address their social inequality. It is not going to address their comparative disadvantage. All of the evidence from the government's own experts shows that those people who are particularly disadvantaged are going to be comparatively worse off.

TALK.START.PARA: —You would have knocked them off the unemployment benefit.

—I am pleased that the parliamentary secretary sees fit to raise matters arising out of Fightback. He is seeking to compare our approach with that of him and his colleagues. In relation to many of the proposals that were contained in Fightback, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in his policy speech Building on Strength said:

SPEECH.PARA: Today we stand against radical right wing proposals which are hostile to fundamental Australian beliefs and Australian institutions and all that we have achieved in recent years.

That is what he had to say about us—right wing ideologues! That is what was embodied in the policies we were pursuing, yet they are the same policies that the government has just proposed and adopted in the bill that we are looking at tonight. That is what it amounts to.

PARA.TAB: In relation to reducing the income ceiling and assets value limit for the basic family payment, the government is adopting the policies that were `right wing proposals which are hostile to fundamental Australian beliefs and Australian institutions'. I find it extraordinary that people who characterise those sorts of programs in that way would adopt them with the enthusiasm that this government has adopted them.

I extend that by noting that it is not just in this area—in this bill. I have extracted a list of 11 items—initiatives that were first outlined in Fightback—which have either been adopted or which were unannounced changes and commitments which have been put in place for the purposes of saving money, which the government had clearly been working on and developing but did not see fit to include in any of its policy statements before the election.

One only has to look at them: increasing the women's pension age from 60 to 65, another one of those right wing proposals which are hostile to fundamental Australian beliefs; another is the stricter jobsearch and review activity for both the jobsearch allowance and newstart. They were born in Fightback. We walked away from them because the unemployment situation had not improved, but those in the government, as soon as the election is out of the way, adopt them in their entirety.

We see it again in relation to the requirement for eligible pensioners to claim an overseas pension before claiming the Australian pension. We had not even thought of that one. It involves another $33 million of savings. There are people who will be disadvantaged by that because they will not be eligible to get the benefits that might attach to their overseas pension that they would get if they were in receipt of an Australian pension.

Then there are the students turning 16 who will have to remain on the additional family payment rather than being able to transfer to Austudy. It is a matter we discussed last night. There is the inclusion of certain employer provided fringe benefits as income under the income family test. There is the issue of the family income test being applied to student parents, one of the matters we are dealing with in this legislation. Then there is the reduced income ceiling and assets value limit for the basic family payment which takes out 116,000 families from the basic family payment as a result of reducing the income ceiling. That is one of the initiatives we outlined in Fightback and which the government characterised as being `radical right wing proposals which are hostile to fundamental Australian beliefs'; then it includes them in a bill of this sort.

Then there is the limiting of arrears in relation to the family payment. This will limit 25,000 family payments where arrears might have arisen because people had inadvertently not been able to claim family payments at the date when they first became eligible. There is the treatment of compensation payments, particularly the statutory deviser—

TALK.START.PARA: —Which you originally supported.

—Which we have referred for review, as the parliamentary secretary knows. Then there is the income test for the family payment to take into account foreign payments—a matter which we brought to notice and one which I imagine, if we had included it in Fightback, the government would have also characterised as being a `right wing proposal hostile to fundamental Australian beliefs'.

PARA.TAB: I want to make it very clear that as far as I am concerned this is Labor's day of shame with regard to social justice. If government members believed in any of their rhetoric, they would not have been a party to the deception that was involved in each of these proposals and that is involved in these initiatives tonight.
It is interesting, is it not, that we are dealing with eligibility for family payments. During the National Family Summit on 11 November 1992, it was the Prime Minister who said:

SPEECH.PARA: Families with children often have greater financial needs and it is up to us as a society to ensure that the next generation is clothed and fed and sheltered and educated . . .
Less than a year later the government is introducing proposals, which it has described as being right wing and ideological, limiting the benefits that 116,000 families can achieve.

PARA.TAB: I also want to pick up on the family payment and income test as it applies to student parents. I have received correspondence—I dare say the parliamentary secretary and the Minister for Social Security have received similar correspondence—from students who are concerned because they are in the middle of their courses and have been paid certain benefits under the Australian Postgraduate Research Awards for undertaking important higher education study here in Australia; research often designed to benefit this country. People are now being told that the family payments, which were part of their award conditions because they were not tested against this, will no longer be payable to them.

One student rightly complains that the benefits he may lose as a result of the passage of this legislation could cause him to have to discontinue his PhD because he had budgeted upon the receipt of certain income over a three-year course between 1993 and 1995. He made his financial commitments on the basis of that total income package, and he is now not in a position to meet them. I dare say that the parliamentary secretary would say that that is also a matter of social justice.

The government was moving by legislation to ensure, by specific words, that the right of certain people or a principle in administrative law was overturned. The parliamentary secretary pointed this out in his second reading speech. He had to make reference to it deliberately and draw it to our attention, just as, similarly, the legislation had to deal with that matter. It is contained in clause 18 of the bill which deals with certain determinations which are not to be reviewed.

I simply note that the parliament, particularly through the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, has seen fit to draw our attention to this matter. It is a particularly important matter. The committee notes that the proposed amendment does diminish rights preserved by general principle of law. The committee draws that matter to our attention, as it says that it may be considered to trespass unduly upon personal rights and liberties and thus be in breach of the committee's terms of reference. The opposition will not be pressing the matter in relation to that question, but it is important that people know when the government is proposing changes of that sort.

As I said earlier, this legislation marks Labor's day of shame in relation to social justice because it is the last piece of legislation dealing with unannounced substantial changes in eligibility for benefits which were not foreshadowed during the last election. I regard it as a grave breach of good faith with the electorate every bit as bad as a broken promise. Every statement given to a minister as a minister, which he knows he intends to give effect to, in my view, ought to be included in his policy program and commitment so that people can make an honest assessment of his legislative program.

It is very clear that each of these initiatives were major in character; the government clearly knew of the significance of each of them—they would have been worked upon by the department over a long period of time; and I am sure they were clearly in the government's mind when it went to the people. I am sure that the government, if it were of good faith—if it were fair dinkum—could have outlined each of these in its policy document, Building on strength. But it left it until a matter of months after the election, then trotted them out in a budget as if they were in some way a miraculous conception—unthought of, not dreamt about, not considered remotely in any way by the government.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't believe this, do you?

—I believe it, and I think the parliamentary secretary recognises—I suppose it is the reason for his mirth—that the government conned the electorate, that it was deliberate and knowing, and that the government was not deserving of the electorate's support. It is for that reason that, as a second reading amendment, I move:

PARA.TAB: That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: "whilst not opposing the provisions of the Bill, the House condemns the Government for:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) its failure to inform the Australian people of its intention to apply the basic family payment and assets test to student parents, reduce the income ceiling and assets value limit for family payment, and limit arrears of family payment; and
(2)the inequity of the Budget which treats low income earners in a harsher manner than high income earners, and its failure to maintain a fair and equitable income distribution parity; and further
(3)its inability to deal with the problem of long term unemployment, and the consequent social dislocation".

Any member of the government who is genuinely concerned about social justice; genuinely concerned about the plight of the most disadvantaged in our community; genuinely concerned about the extent to which in this country the rich have got richer and the poor have got poorer under the Labor Party; genuinely concerned about the breaches of good faith and the failure of the government to articulate in advance its intention to deprive hundreds of thousands of Australians of benefits which they had been receiving, would support this amendment.

PARA.TAB: We know the way in which these things happen in this place. We know the discipline to which members of the Labor Party are forced to adhere, and I suspect that we will even hear rather poor responses designed to try to defend these changes. But I would like to hear a reasoned, intelligent, thoughtful presentation from any member of the government that can justify this breach of good faith with the Australian electorate.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Fitzgibbon)—Is the amendment seconded?

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the amendment.

—Talk about a lot of huffing and puffing over nothing. The opposition has been moaning and groaning for 30 minutes but it is actually supporting this legislation. We have had half an hour of this waffle and then the honourable member has the hide to talk about looking for reasoned arguments. He then says, `We agree with it. We are in favour of it. We will not oppose it'. These are the same people who opposed a tax on wine because it hurts the poor and the same people who opposed tax cuts, because they did not think of it first. They oppose everything that moves except this. They are not opposing this; they are agreeing with it.

PARA.TAB: The sheer audacity of the honourable member for Berowra (Mr Ruddock) leaves one a bit bewildered. He would have us believe that we knew all this back in February when the election was called but kept it all a secret, including the $3 extra for newstart. What he is suggesting is that we deliberately did not announce before the election that we were going to increase newstart—and we are so stupid we still win an election! If that is what these guys opposite really think, it says an awful lot about them.

I think this explains why the opposition lost, and why it will lose again and again. Quite frankly, the crocodile tears shed here tonight, confirmed by the opposition's support for the legislation, will not impress low income Australia. It will not impress people who are paying taxes, who support the welfare system and who want us to run a decent, honourable, fair system where people operate under the same rules. That is what these amendments are largely about. The most important amendment is the increase to newstart. The extra $3 a week is important because the figures show that that group has in fact been sliding back.

The honourable member for Berowra skated over so much, but when he talked about the pain and hardship of the poor and low income people, he did not mention that the big shift in the asset levels under the assets test for family payments is from $607,000 to $550,000. These are the poor! These are the people that he is wailing and gnashing his teeth about whom we have ignored and neglected—people with assets of over $550,000! Even then, there is a hardship provision. If those assets cannot be used to earn productively, they may be disregarded. He would have us believe that this was all part of a sinister plot, hatched before February and camouflaged.

I am really pleased the honourable member for Berowra has quoted the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) because it means that we can quote the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) about Fightback and Sunday, because Sunday was in fact not a black day, just a bad day for the Liberals again. Fightback lives on, minus the GST. `Nine months unemployment and you're finished' is back to life. Sunday reversed all the statements made for everything—

TALK.START.PARA: —He knows that.

—No, I do not. We heard the phrase `studied inactivity' over and over. The election was in March. We have brought in a budget since then. The great labouring of those opposite before they would agree to these amendments in the first place has achieved nothing, yet we are accused of studied inactivity. If ours is studied, what is theirs? Total inactivity? I accept the praise—at least we are studied about it. There is no word that could qualify the activity of those opposite. They have done nothing. They have just sat on their butts for six months doing nothing but opposing these amendments.

PARA.TAB: There should not be a debate on these amendments because those opposite are agreeing with us. Their amendments do not go to the substance of the legislation. Their proposal does not change anything. Why would they spend half an hour of what they keep telling us is inadequate time for debate to agree with us? Nothing ever ceases to amaze me. After 10 years I thought I had seen it all until these last two nights. Bronwyn is in the wrong seat. There is a real spot in Berowra. Give her six months and she will have a policy. She would not be talking about our deliberately having held back a $3 newstart policy from the election.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you talking about the legislation?

—I am talking about what those opposite are talking about—inactivity. In six months, from March until now, those opposite have had no changes in their policy. On Sunday, six months later, the opposition leader announced, `Fightback is our policy, apart from the GST'. Those opposite have put forward nothing else. What I am suggesting is to bring Bronwyn into the House in the seat of Berowra and give her social security.
—We can't do that.

—She deserves it. At least she has done something in six months. If it was not audacious enough of those opposite to take half an hour of waffle to agree with us and to accuse us of inactivity, on Sunday whatever those opposite have said since last Christmas was reversed. They are now back to where they were in November 1991. `Less GST' is what we heard from the Leader of the Opposition. `Studied inactivity' is what we have heard over and over from those opposite.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Berowra also suggested that we should not be activity testing. He talked about forcing people into nefarious tasks. The implication was that we should just ignore the works test, we should just ignore the rules and we should just ignore loopholes as they emerge. I do not doubt that when we are debating the fringe benefits tax he will tell us to ignore those. He will tell us to let senior public servants in South Australia get family payments because they can get fringe benefits rather than income. He will tell us how terrific it is that people who run companies can somehow manipulate the system to get Austudy in full. He will support all these things. It will be very interesting to hear him talking at the same time about his concern for the poor. We also heard a lot from him about the long-term unemployed. As I said last night, I am getting to the stage of being not just appalled but disgusted at what the opposition is doing in this House and in this country and with its dishonesty.

After what I said last night, a number of people have approached me and confirmed what I had said regarding Liberal and National parliamentarians and schemes in their electorates. Whether they be training schemes such as skillshare and jobskill or other schemes such as LEAP, parliamentarians opposite are privately endorsing those schemes and publicly saying that the government is doing nothing. They are referring people to those projects—only those they know—whilst in this place they bag them, and in Fightback they get chopped very heavily. So we are back to cuts in skillshare.

The fact that those opposite do not support those schemes publicly in their electorates and in this place is an insult to the people for whom those schemes are designed, it discriminates against the people they refer to the schemes, and it is dishonest in the extreme because those schemes are successful. Whether they are training schemes like skillshare or employment schemes like jobskill or LEAP, they are enormously important. They help literally thousands of people.

In the last six months we have seen this dishonesty from an opposition pretending to care about the long-term unemployed, whilst rubbing its hands in glee and walking away from those people when it knows it could help them. The opposition wants the figures to increase. The tragedy is that the next election is three years away, and the opposition will spend three years undermining and damaging not only the schemes but also the futures of people whom the schemes are designed to help.

I predict that within the next six months, week after week, we will receive examples from honourable members opposite—the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Slipper) and the honourable member for Cowan (Mr Evans), in particular—of scandals, waste, and disgraceful behaviour on this scheme and that scheme. Those same honourable members, I do not doubt, will be referring constituents to those schemes at the same time. It happened before with the CDP when Liberal and National party members had the capacity to be so dishonest.

The shadow minister for education, employment and training, the honourable member for Chisholm (Dr Wooldridge), came in here and talked about the long-term unemployed. He asked what we were doing about the problem. He knows what we are doing about it, but is he helping? Was there one positive word in his speech about what is being done? There was not one.

The honourable member for Berowra shakes his head. He is correct. He should keep shaking it, because he did not say a word about it. Those opposite cried crocodile tears, yet showed a lack of support for what they know is happening. The honourable member for Berowra has skillshare in his electorate. I will take his comments to mean that he does not support skillshare in his electorate of Berowra.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not say that.

—There is no other conclusion to draw. I take it that the honourable member does not support jobskill or LEAP in his electorate. If he has the hide to go back to Berowra, talk to people involved in those schemes and come in here and talk about inactivity, then that is not just gall; it is a disgrace. If he is talking in any way about any of those programs, approaching those schemes and presenting certificates, referring people to LEAP, or announcing projects, then he should be absolutely ashamed. He knows that those schemes are helping those people. Is the honourable member suggesting we should cancel skillshare, jobskill and LEAP? Is that the idea?
—I never said that.
—Does he support the schemes or not?
—Are these interrogatories?
—You started it.
—I started more community support schemes than you have ever seen in my electorate.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Fitzgibbon)—Order! Would the honourable member for Newcastle speak through the chair and refrain from asking questions of the honourable member for Berowra. Would the honourable member for Berowra be quiet and let the honourable member for Newcastle be heard in silence.

TALK.START.PARA: —If that were only half true, it would be terrific; but it is totally false. It is most important that these schemes be promoted by the people's representatives. The Liberals and Nationals do not promote the schemes. But not only do they not promote them; they automatically bag them.

PARA.TAB: In making the remarks that the honourable member for Berowra did earlier about the fact that we are doing nothing, he is bagging those schemes, and he knows it. The fact is that he will go back to Berowra on Friday and in the weeks and months after he will say great things about skillshare. He comes down here and says, `They are doing nothing'. He knows it. It is not just him; all his colleagues do exactly the same thing. It is sheer dishonesty.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been going on for years.
—It has been going on for years, hasn't it?

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I draw your attention to standing order 75 which says that no member may use offensive words against either house of the parliament or any member. On many occasions, I have heard the honourable member for Newcastle call members of the opposition dishonest. I find that offensive and I ask that the comment be withdrawn.
—I have not been noting the frequency of the use of the word `dishonest', but I will be listening very carefully from now on.

—I will repeat over and over that it is sheer dishonesty by those opposite. I am not surprised that the honourable member for Fisher takes exception to that suggestion. It is not the word to which he is taking exception; it is the truth of it. He is being made to face what the opposition is doing. The shadow minister tonight took half an hour to agree with these amendments. A lot of that time was taken up with his talking about no support for the long-term unemployed. He will go back to Berowra, run around the traps and tell people what he is doing and how great it is, and then he will come back down here and bag.

PARA.TAB: He said he is genuinely concerned and more concerned than we are. That is so false as to be offensive. He knows that those schemes need public support from parliamentarians on both sides. If there were bipartisan support for all those schemes, the effect on the morale of those people would be enormous. People are being bagged and they are being treated as second-class citizens by the opposition. The opposition knows that these schemes are effective and that they work. What is more, the honourable member for Berowra just laid claim to it. He said that the schemes came from the Fraser government. Not only does he support them, he is trying to own them—and then he says that we are doing nothing. It is a case of `Bronwyn, we need you'. We do not; those opposite do. Whatever her failings may be, at least she has some logic about her.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't go overboard about logic. She hasn't got that much logic about her.
—She is not very profound, so she does not need much. Mr Deputy Speaker, that was probably inappropriate in view of the earlier comments.

PARA.TAB: Basically, the most important amendment relates to the $3 per week for newstart recipients. The others are essentially housekeeping amendments. As we find with most of our legislation, these measures do get misused from time to time; they do need adjustment from time to time as incomes change and values change. They are basically housekeeping and certainly post-budget.

The idea that the amendments go back to February of this year is absolutely ludicrous. It is a tawdry gimmick of the honourable member for Berowra and his amused colleagues to somehow try to tie them back to the election. They are not doing it to make a point of logic or a point of policy. They are not even doing it to make a political point. They are doing it to explain why they lost. They are trying to say that they did not really lose at all. It is so unfair. I am glad they are not sportspeople. I am glad this is not actually a sport, although some people might think it is. If they are going to play the game, if they are going to take part in the contest, they should at least know how to lose.

We have seen a lack of dignity and pride from those opposite. They have been grovelling and grasping around saying, `Hey, it really was not our fault. We did not really lose. We got cheated'. I think it was Mr Snedden who said, `It was not that we lost, we just did not win'. Do honourable members remember that famous one? He did not actually lose the election but he did not win it either. At least he conceded a bit more than that which we are hearing from those opposite. They have used every possible issue to try to explain their incompetence and their rejection by the community.

The honourable member for Berowra spent half an hour speaking against these amendments, at the end of which he indicated that the opposition would not even be opposing them. Everything he said was meaningless and was contradicted by his actions. That is indicative of why those opposite lost the election. The reason they lost was sheer incompetence. As I said, if Bronwyn is looking for a senior frontbench position—

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member should refer to people by their correct titles.

—I do not quite know how to refer to people in that chamber. I am sure that had she been a shadow minister for the last six months Senator Bishop could not have done a worse job than someone who comes in here, spends half an hour attacking amendments, and then supports them. She could do no worse than someone who, six months after an election, says, `We still have our policy from November 1991, less GST'. The opposition is back to square one. At least she would have some policy. We are seeing nothing from the opposition—six months of nothing, not even study. The amendments should go through and—(Time expired)

—Before calling the honourable member for Fisher, I note that he earlier took a rather convoluted point of order. This debate has been conducted in a somewhat argumentative way, but there has been no deliberate malice. To the best of my knowledge, the words `dishonest' and `dishonesty' have been used in this House on numerous occasions without anyone taking offence to their use. It is fair to tell the honourable member that I believe he did not have a point of order, but I will discuss the matter with the Speaker.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. During his speech, the honourable member for Berowra made numerous and quite detailed references to the government, to the Prime Minister, to what he saw as dishonesty and misleading behaviour, and to how the election was won. The honourable member for Fisher was not here at the time, but he should know—

—Order! The honourable member will resume his seat. That is not a point of order; it is more or less support for your own position. As I said, there was no malice in anything that was said here this evening. It has been a fairly friendly debate, and an interesting one. I am sure that the honourable member for Fisher will continue in that vein.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I take exception to your suggestion—
—Order! Are you taking a point of order again?

—If it is necessary for me to get the call, I will take a further point of order. I had proposed to speak to the previous point of order in view of your allegation that I had taken a convoluted point of order. My point of order was clear and precise.

—Order! The honourable member will resume his seat. As I told the honourable member for Fisher, I will refer this matter to the Speaker and you will be advised at a later date of any decision made by me. You now have the opportunity to speak on the bill before the House.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. When you refer this matter to the Speaker, I would like you to draw his attention to the actual words I used when I took my point of order. My point of order objected to the use of the word `dishonest' on a number of occasions by the honourable member for Newcastle. I am quite happy, Mr Deputy Speaker, for you to refer this matter to the Speaker, but I do respectfully suggest that it is inappropriate to say that the way in which I presented the point of order was convoluted.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order.

—Order! The honourable member will resume his seat until I have responded to the other point of order. If the honourable member for Fisher has a clear understanding of the word `convoluted'—which I am sure that he has—then we will not debate the semantics of various terms at this point. However, I have been informed by the clerk that the term `dishonest argument' is acceptable. If somebody uses the term `dishonest member', that is unparliamentary. For the life of me, I cannot recall—I suggest that, for the life of you, you cannot recall either—whether anyone called you a `dishonest member'. I do not believe that that statement was made. I find that you have no point of order, so you will retain your seat while we hear a point of order from the honourable member for Newcastle.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, my point of order is that if you refer to the Speaker any matter that occurred in tonight's debate, as you have been requested to do by the honourable member for Fisher—a request that I suspect you are required to agree to; I do not know whether you have any powers to refuse such a request—I would urge that you also refer to the Speaker the comments of the honourable member for Berowra. The honourable member for Fisher was not here at the time.

—I think the honourable member for Newcastle will decide, after the conclusion of tonight's proceedings, that everyone here has been treated most fairly and there has been a bit of time wasting. I now call the honourable member for Fisher.

—On a further point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker, I ask that you seek advice from the honourable member for Newcastle as to whether he did in fact refer to us as being dishonest. I believe that he did.

—For the time being, this matter is closed. I take exception to the honourable member for Fisher continuing in this vein. I believe that he is not showing due respect to the chair. I call upon the honourable member to speak to the bill before the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slipper Mr P.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker, but it is not disorderly to take a point of order. The honourable member for Newcastle (Mr Allan Morris) addressed this House for 20 minutes, allegedly on the Social Security Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1993. It would possibly be of benefit for me to draw to the honourable member's attention the three main changes to the bill. They relate to: an increase in the rate of the newstart allowance payable to some single people over 21; a reduction in the income and assets tests thresholds for certain family payments; and the making of certain family payments to persons previously receiving the payment not recoverable. So there are three relevant aspects to this bill.

PARA.TAB: It should also be noted that the honourable member for Berowra (Mr Ruddock), in a speech which I thought was very interesting and very much to the point, proposed an amendment asking that this House condemn the government for:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)its failure to inform the Australian people of its intention to apply the basic family payment and assets test to student parents, reduce the income ceiling and assets value limit for family payment, and limit arrears of family payment; and
(2)the inequity of the Budget which treats low income earners in a harsher manner than high income earners, and its failure to maintain a fair and equitable income distribution parity; and, further,
(3)its inability to deal with the problem of long term unemployment, and the consequent social dislocation.

Over the last few months and in the run-up to the election the government has not come forward with its true agenda. We have seen that true agenda unravelled slowly but surely over the last six months. We have seen the election promises which said that the government would deliver to us a great Australia, an Australia which would be fair to all with no new taxes. We all know what has happened in the budget and we have all seen increased taxes after increased taxes. While we are not allowed to use the word `lie' in this place—and I certainly would not endeavour to do so—we have seen that the people of Australia now see the taxation situation confronting them as being quite different from that which they had anticipated, given the policy speech of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating).

PARA.TAB: It should be noted that the first point raised in this legislation relates to the increased rate of payment for certain newstart allowees. While apparently about one-quarter of a million of Australia's unemployed will benefit to the tune of some $6 a fortnight by this measure, it should be remembered that a further three-quarters of a million Australians are receiving some form of unemployment benefit. They are on the dole scrap heap as a result of this government's policies and they currently have little hope of improving their financial situation and standard of living. This measure does not solve the problem; it does not improve the lot of three-quarters of a million Australians whose plight has been forgotten. The tragedy of unemployment continues to stalk these people who have no hope as a result of this government's policies and certainly no hope offered by the bill before the House.

The government should be focusing on this major problem of unemployment and the creation of real jobs—jobs which will benefit Australia's economy, Australians and the families of those one million people who have been thrown out of work. The $3 a week increase for single people without dependent children who receive the newstart allowance will be welcomed by that small section of the community who will receive it. But what these people really need most and what they are entitled to is the opportunity to turn their backs on newstart and jobstart allowances and enter or re-enter the work force.

Unemployment remains one of Australia's most pressing problems. There really should be a multipartisan policy. It should not be a matter on which people score political points, because the tragedy of unemployment cuts right across the social spectrum. I can see the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security (Mr Sciacca). I know that he has a real concern in this area. Like me, he must have been terribly disappointed over the lack of budget initiatives to create opportunities for Australia's one million people out of work.

Unfortunately, the bill before the House, while helping a small number of people, contains stop gap measures which help a minority of people but which ignore the problems suffered by the remaining people who are out of work. One ought only to look at the continuing unemployment situation and the month by month figures. While the number of Australians receiving newstart and jobstart fell marginally last month, it ought to be seen as only a slight improvement. The tragedy of unemployment continues for a very large number of people, most of whom want to work. The reason for the small decline in unemployment is that many people who wanted full time jobs have had to be satisfied with part-time employment.

In some parts of the electorate of Fisher, the situation is very grim. The number of people on newstart and jobsearch allowances paints a very grim picture. I refer to the major urban centres in my electorate. In Caloundra, 2,520 people are out of work. Kawana Waters has a jobless rate of over 1,800 people, which increased by a staggering 16 per cent during August. In Caboolture and on Bribie Island, the unemployment rate increased marginally during September, bringing the number of people on the unemployment benefit to 4,159.

In the wider Sunshine Coast-Caboolture region, there are almost 17,000 people in Labor's job queues. Given the opportunity of an extra $3 a week, as promised by this bill to a quarter of those people, or an opportunity to start back in the work force—an opportunity to have a job and provide a future for their children—very few people in the dole queues would not take the opportunity of full-time work.

In his amendment, the honourable member for Berowra has condemned the government's proposal to extend the family payment and income assets tests to student parents. Many of those people have undertaken their current studies on the basis that certain benefits are available. While the government might well have an argument that payment ought not to be made to some of those people, we on this side of the House, and indeed many reasonable people opposite—if there are any left—disagree. I can only see one person on the government benches, and that is the parliamentary secretary. I know that he is reasonable on many occasions.

Sadly, it is quite unfair that there is an element of retrospectivity in this legislation. People who have possibly given up work to undertake further study on the basis of receiving certain benefits to assist them to complete that study will be disadvantaged. Given the current economic climate, it could well be that they will be unable to find work. They might have to give up their studies, and their lives could well be destroyed. We are talking about fairly piddling amounts of alleged savings in this measure in view of the overall budget deficit.

I understand that the savings are a mere $0.4 million in 1993-94, $0.8 million in 1994-95 and the same for the following year. While it could be that only a small number of families will be affected by this measure, I think it is something that the government ought to look at again. If there is only such a small amount of money involved and a small number of families who will be affected by this measure—which, to a large extent, could well be deemed to be retrospective—then the government might well take on board the idea of scrapping this particular measure at least as far as the retrospective element is concerned.

There were two other matters I mentioned when I commenced my speech: the reduced income ceiling and assets test limit for the basic family payment and the limiting of family payment arrears. The last three measures were not foreshadowed in the election campaign, and so people voted for the government. It cannot be doubted that the election was won by the government and not by us, despite certain allegations made by honourable members opposite, but sadly the government did not give notice to the Australian people that these measures were coming in, and, in fact, a lot of people would have voted for the government believing that these measures would not be included in the bill before the House. Had the government come forward with its actual program, a number of people in a number of electorates might well have voted against the government, with the result that the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson) could now have been the Prime Minister and the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating) could now have been living elsewhere—in the south of France or somewhere else beyond our shores.

It is clear that the government has misled the Australian people in relation to some of the measures in this particular bill. I must say also that it is very hard morally to justify removing the right to claim arrears in the area of family payments. If the government or the bureaucracy has made a mistake and has wrongly denied someone the opportunity to claim moneys which legally are claimable, it seems a bit rough to limit the arrears. That is quite unfair. The whole idea of this measure is not a desire to be fair to those involved, but rather a desire to remove people from the welfare system.

It will be very important that discretion is exercised in this regard, because it could well be, through no fault of the particular person involved, that the necessary notices of changes of address have not been passed on to the Department of Social Security and someone could well miss out on family payments as a result of a wrong decision of the bureaucracy.

If the government wishes to proceed with these matters before the House and if it wishes to make the savings outlined in the material which it has distributed, then possibly those savings could be used to treat Australia's pensioners and retired people, in the area of managed investments, in the same way as the parliamentary secretary and the Minister for Social Security (Mr Baldwin) have agreed to treat the deeming of shares. I hope the minister will take that on board. I know that I have written him innumerable letters as have almost all honourable members on this side of House and, I suggest, honourable members on the other side of the House. It is probably a matter that the parliamentary secretary would like to have happily resolved, but to date, despite his efforts in that area, there has not been a satisfactory resolution.

We ought to reinforce the wording of the amendment before the House. The opposition does not oppose the general thrust of the bill. That was stated by the honourable member for Berowra in his excellent speech a few minutes ago. What we are doing is condemning this government. We are seeking to have this House condemn this government for its failure to inform the Australian people of its intention to apply the basic family payment income and assets test to student parents, reduce the income ceiling and assets value limit for family payment and limit arrears of family payments.

We also condemn the government for its inequity in the budget, whereby low income earners are treated in a harsher manner than high income earners. We condemn the government for its failure to maintain a fair and equitable income distribution parity. We further condemn the government for its inability to deal with the problem of long-term unemployment and the consequent social dislocation in Australia.

In the months leading up to the election, the Australian people were treated—and I use that word loosley—to a list of promises from the government. The government promised us that somehow Australians would have a great future without any new taxes. From the time of the election on 13 March through to now we have found that these promises have been shredded one after another.

Quite frankly, when we look at the opinion polls, which show that this government is totally disregarded by the Australian people, that this government is being totally rejected by the Australian people and that the ratings of this government are almost nonexistent, we can see that the Australian people are demanding honesty in politics, integrity in politics, and ethics in politics. Quite frankly, the message that is coming into my office—and I know that it is coming into the office of the honourable member for Cowan (Mr Evans) and all of the people on this side of the House—is that people want another election soon. They want the opportunity to confine this government to the political scrap heap of Australia. They want to confine this government to the history books.

This government is the worst government that Australia has ever had. It is a government which is bringing in policies which are not favourable to the Australian people. The people of Australia want an opportunity to throw this government out. On behalf of the electorate of Fisher, I call for an election as soon as possible. I encourage those in the other place to reject as many measures as possible to force this government back to the Australian people so that it can be held to account for its conduct over the past seven months.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SCIACCA
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —There are only a few minutes left of this debate. I suggested to the honourable member for Cowan (Mr Evans) that he might want to speak for a few minutes, but his colleague the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Slipper) did not give him much of a chance. Nevertheless, that is okay.

PARA.TAB: I want to make two comments. There really is not much that one needs to rebut in terms of the opposition's discussions here tonight. Frankly, the contributions from both members of the opposition contained a lot of hot air and a lot of repetition of some of the things that were said last night. Frankly, it was a bit of filibustering.

I want to mention the position mentioned by the honourable member for Berowra (Mr Ruddock). He talked about the new enhanced activity tests that we are bringing in for certain jobsearch allowees. The position, as he puts it, is that a lot of disadvantaged clients, including migrants and Aboriginals, will be thrown off the queues. The reality is that these new enhanced activity requirements are being done for exactly the opposite reason than the one he suggests. We are trying to have earlier identification of people who will be at most risk of being long-term unemployed; we are trying to ensure that we have proper case management; and we are trying to ensure that these people get the special attention that they deserve, rather than having to serve 12 months on the jobsearch allowance before they sign an activity agreement under the newstart arrangements.

The opposition continually whinges about the fact that we did not supposedly give notice about these matters before the election. It is pretty obvious to me that those opposite have been out of government now for so long that they do not understand or they have forgotten the process that takes place when budgets are formulated. The fact is that these matters are discussed at length in the lead-up to the budget. Some matters are excluded; some matters are brought in. Spending proposals and savings proposals are discussed, as a result of which a lot of these measures have been brought in, particularly those that we are bringing in today. One would have to be an absolute goose not to go to the population and say at election time, `We are not going to increase the newstart allowance by $3 a week', as we have done. In conclusion, I thank honourable members for their contributions. Obviously, we do not agree with the amendments proposed by the honourable member for Berowra. They contain the usual rhetoric, theatrics and antics that he uses in this House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Mr R.D.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the last hour we have again been debating the merits of the Labor Party's love affair with socialism and the desire to treat the Australian people as a collective rather than as proud individuals. It is not for the Labor Party to reward industriousness; nor will it recognise those who want to work hard for their country, their families and themselves. No—the Labor Party just wants it easy. Every time an Australian wants to get ahead, he or she is bashed over the head by the Labor Party's notion of democratic socialism. In other words, base everything on the lowest common denominator and work against those working to improve their lot.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Labor Party is based upon mates. They are mates in everything they do. It is Australian mateship that holds us back. It is the mateship that gave us the tall poppy syndrome. Mateship that gave us the award structure where good workers get the same as poor workers, for it is impossible to reward good workers under the mateship award structure. Mateship sees us as one of the least productive countries in our region. It is mateship that derides anyone who says that we are sucking up to the establishment if we are taking a caring attitude towards our country.

The Labor Party and its paternalistic mateship withholds the development of women in our society. It encourages a breaking down of our family unit and it encourages collectives where the individual can be sacrificed for the group, the mates. They say in the Labor Party that we are all just great mates and we look after each other and stuff the consequences of everything else. Now we see the collective nature of their mateship move into the social welfare area of our community. Whose idea was it within the Labor Party that `if everyone is on the government payroll they will never vote us out'? Who was that purported great Australian, that great political misfit, that great charlatan? This government is moving slowly towards achieving the goal—all mates together on the payroll and stuff the consequences.

The point is, though, can the country continue to support this notion of Labor collective mateship? The answer is simply no. As we continue to spend more as a government than we attract as income we will surely go further downhill. The only way governments can attract income is through tax, and we are now one of the highest taxing countries in the region. Yet what do the mates say? They say, `Let us keep spending. The world will get us out of it. The money will never have to be paid back. Who cares about debt? What can they do?'. This totally irresponsible attitude towards finance and the future of our country is typical of the sanguine mates of the Labor Party. They have no financial responsibility at all. They just have a spend, spend, spend attitude.

One hundred years ago we were the envy of the world. We had the opportunity to lead the new world with development and lifestyle. Yet once the labour movement wreckers got hold of some power they began ripping us apart. Mateship Labor Party style has a lot to answer for and it is time for us Australians to care about the future of our country and for the visionaries to take a more responsible attitude to the way we go about helping the community and encouraging growth.

To quote the words of the Parliamentary Secretary for Social Security, (Mr Sciacca), the Labor Party is committed to the Australian family. This is rubbish, absolute bunkum. Spending is not a commitment. Giving taxpayers' funds away to the privileged few is not a commitment. Commitment is ensuring proper health services, not unrealistic queues for hospital care. Commitment is supplying education as an opportunity, not making it impossible to place children in preschool centres or universities. Commitment is ensuring a strong economy based on growth, not increasing our debt to buy services we cannot afford. Commitment is giving financial security to those who want it by providing the environment for full employment, not regulating and destroying wealth creators.

This government is committed to one thing, and that is to ensuring that we have an environment where we become reliant on the government to provide for us rather than seeking self-determination, self-fulfilment and self-respect. Senator Walsh, in his valedictory speech, put it in these words:

SPEECH.PARA: I fear that Ben Chifley's Labor Party . . . has lost its way—and mouthing Chifley rhetoric is a poor substitute for sharing his beliefs, especially his belief that economic growth, or development as he would have called it, has a paramount role in improving the life of ordinary Australians.

Chifley said of social welfare that Australia should maintain a lifestyle of quality for all Australians but he meant that we should help the disadvantaged, not have the government pay for everyone without any sense of financial responsibility. The Liberal Party offers the nation financial responsibility, an environment that will promote growth and a commitment to all Australians, be they wealth creators or the genuinely needy. Our commitment to the families of Australia is very different to that of the Labor Party. No-one believes the Labor Party any more. I am looking forward to 1996 when that will be shown at the ballot box.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Henzell Ms M.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It must indeed be a sobering experience for the colleagues of the honourable member for Cowan (Mr Evans) to read the hard copy of his contributions to this House. I am not sure about tall poppies, but I suggest empty vessels may be a better analogy.

PARA.TAB: I rise to talk about the historic events of the last couple of days when we have indeed achieved a most remarkable negotiated solution to the Mabo issue. It is a great tribute to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and to all those who have been involved. I refer to his position in his Redfern address when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: As Mabo was an historic judgement this is historic legislation, recognising in law the fiction of terra nullius and the fact of native title.

We will look back on this week in the International Year for the World's Indigenous People and be able to say that this was a crucial moment in our history. This is in stark contrast to our opponents in this House who have not been able to rise to the occasion and will therefore be marginalised, possibly on the scrap heap of history, on this issue, as on most of the great issues of our time.

PARA.TAB: But their position has its historical antecedent in the philosophical position of the founder of their party, Robert Gordon Menzies. As Judith Brett suggests in her insightful analysis of his political career, Menzies' denial of issues was consistent with the Australian people's avoidance of historical truth. She says:

SPEECH.PARA: The defended island continent of Australia and the homes of the middle class were also built on denial—the historic denial of the prior occupancy of the Australian continent by the people who became known as the Australian Aborigines, and of the brutality and lawlessness with which their land had been taken. White Australia's continuing fear of invasion must be seen as a massive collective projection of the knowledge of white Australia's origins. As Bernard Smith argued in his Boyer lectures, in order to survive, a culture must have the ethical self-confidence to be able to justify itself both to itself and to others.

We have been able to do this because we as a party have had the commitment and the vision to do so. I feel proud to be an Australian and a member of the government that has at last brought justice to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people of this country.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Televising of the House of Representatives, Committee

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I would like to congratulate you and your committee on the recommendations concerning televising the House. I am pleased to see that your recommendations coincided exactly with my own submissions to the committee. The government was extremely unwise not to accept the recommendations, both politically and in principle. Its refusal reinforces the public view of the government as isolated and arrogant and it is going to further erode the faith of the public in parliament.

PARA.TAB: No matter what sophistry the government mounts to justify guided democracy, what it has done is to cut across the public's right to know—a right that the public now demands in all aspects of government, and a right that is fundamental to democracy, particularly when the public is paying $3 million a day for this institution.

Regrettably, much of the debate earlier today was beside the point. The honourable member for Swan (Mr Beazley) argued the indefensible extremely well, but his argument was paternalist and about fears more than reality. It was an argument for censorship and protection of the public that would be well received in Jakarta but not in this country.

The honourable member for Watson (Mr Leo McLeay) put the partisan view and detailed many defects of honourable members, the media and the way the place is run. But rather than suggest remedies, he simply took the view that these problems should be hidden from the public. The honourable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding) gave an extremely good exposition of the ultra-conservative position about the virtues of the Westminster system and a member's duty to parliament, but he did not mention our duty to the public. In essence, he put the antiquated view that parliament is sovereign, whereas I think that the vast majority of the community believes that the people should be sovereign.

Even the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), while taking the correct view, spent most of his time on a sidetrack with a partisan conspiracy theory about the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). The point is that, no matter what the defects of this institution are and no matter how honourable members or the media may misuse their position, all proceedings of this parliament should be open to the public. The many problems that exist should be addressed directly and not just hidden. Of course there will be problems from a fully open system, but they will be minor compared with the problems that flow from any form of censorship or secrecy.

It is true that television has enormous power; it is information at its strongest. It caused the collapse of communism. The footage of the point-blank execution of a prisoner by a South Vietnamese officer was the turning point of the Vietnam War, just as the scenes of the Dili massacres have turned around the Timor question, and the TV coverage of dead Americans in Somalia has altered American foreign policy.

The advent of television into this House in 1991 will inevitably be a major factor in the constitutional reform which will take place over the next decade. The people's perception of parliament has already altered irreversibly, even though much the same things have been happening for the past 75 years. The government is deluding itself if it thinks it can continue to prevent the public realising the way parliament is run, or if it thinks it can continue the executive dominance of parliament that has existed in the past. The government places itself in the same futile position as the diehards of the Chinese government who still believe that the nightly electronic jamming around Beijing will keep ideas out.

This debate has also thrown up further reinforcement to the brutal fact that the Senate is now the people's house. The Senate's less restrictive position on television access, its more representative membership and its freedom from executive dominance is making this House less and less relevant. How can the government, with its endless rhetoric about the need for change and micro-economic reform, justify separate rules for radio, print and television and separate rules for both Houses?

The spectacle of the Labor members of the committee reversing their committee position and voting against their own report just demonstrates how party interests always come before public interest, and how very little can be debated in this chamber except in terms of partisan advantage. It has underlined yet again that this House is just a rubber stamp for the executive. The government may have forced its Galileos on the committee to recant on this occasion, but the attempt to restrict public access is doomed to failure in the long run.
