TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take this opportunity to point out the increasing need for education institutions in regional centres of Australia and to voice my strong support for two groups in the Sunshine Coast-Caboolture area striving with success to improve tertiary education opportunities for people living in the region. The Sunshine Coast area, as many members would be aware, is among the fastest growing regions in the nation. The electorate of Fisher, which includes Caloundra city, Caboolture and Bribie Island, has the highest population growth rate. Since 1986, the population of Fisher has increased by a staggering 41.4 per cent. Neighbouring Fairfax is ranked third in the growth stakes with a population increase of 38.7 per cent over the same period. Fisher and Fairfax, however, are also listed eleventh and ninth, respectively, when ranked according to the highest rate of unemployment.

PARA.TAB: Furthermore, the electorate of Fisher is ranked fourth in a field of 147 in families with an average annual income below $16,000. Less than eight per cent of the Fisher population has tertiary qualifications. In summary, Fisher is the fastest growing electorate in Australia, yet one of the poorest and least educated at a tertiary level.

Since the electorate of Fisher has one of the lowest per capita incomes for families Australia-wide, it is extremely difficult for many residents to travel to obtain a tertiary education. One only has to look at the fairly terrible statistics on those students from the Sunshine Coast and Caboolture areas who have applied for tertiary admission.

In 1991, 7,000 students applied and only 2,000 were accepted, leaving 5,000 who were unable to find tertiary places. This year, taking into account the growth rate in the Sunshine Coast-Caboolture area—a growth rate of eight per cent—it is anticipated that there will be 10,000 applicants for about 2,000 places, leaving 8,000 students unable to find places.

It was therefore with delight and some relief that I welcomed the news in late August that the Sunshine Coast University Association had been successful in its bid to have an independent university established in the region. It should be noted for the record that the chairman of the committee is Mrs Alison Kerr-Jones, the joint deputy chairman is Dr Professor Melvin McMichael and the other joint deputy chairman is Professor Frank Kelly, the father-in-law of the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles). The committee members are Peter Campbell-Kerr and David Friend. The university, to be based at Sippy Downs, is expected to open in 1996.

There is also a committee in Caboolture, sponsored by the Caboolture Shire Development Association, working for the establishment of a university in the Caboolture Shire. A university campus in the Caboolture Shire would service residents living in the southern areas of Fisher as well as the northern suburbs of Brisbane and the Brisbane Valley.Having regard to the way in which the area of Caboolture is growing, I am very pleased to lend my support also to the Caboolture Shire proposal in addition to the proposal on the Sunshine Coast.

There is widespread support, both within the Caboolture Shire and from local authorities around Caboolture, for the Caboolture Shire university proposal. The present and future population in the core student catchment zone establishes a requirement for a university campus in the Caboolture Shire. I have been advised that the current population in the core catchment area comprising the Caboolture, Pine Rivers and Kilcoy shires and Redcliffe City currently exceeds 212,000 people and will exceed more than 350,000 in just over 10 years.

The proposal submitted by the Caboolture Shire Development Association covers the projected population growth, identifies a number of sites for the campus and outlines opportunities for making the campus a viable option, such as promoting the university as an exporter of education. Given the local demographic trends and trends in participation in higher education and training in general, it is both logical and economic that appropriate learning centres are established in the Caboolture Shire sooner rather than later.

The two universities would complement each other, provide employment opportunities and improve Fisher and Sunshine Coast residents' ability to access tertiary education. Education provides the key to the future for many Australians of all age groups and generations. I am therefore strongly supportive of these groups which are endeavouring to lift the level of education and provide access to education for people living in the Sunshine Coast and Caboolture regions.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to talk about the perpetuation of myths and inaccuracies that occurs in this House and in the media. I refer to the use of the term `terra nullius'. It has been said in this House—very often by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating)—that it meant that no people occupied Australia. It, of course, never meant that. It never had that connotation. It refers to `no use of the land'. It has been held by the Supreme Court in the United States, by the court in Canada, by the Privy Council and previously by the High Court of Australia that occasional traversing of the land by nomadic peoples did not constitute use of the land. For the High Court, therefore, to say that Australia was not terra nullius, overturning 200 years of established belief, was simply historically incorrect. Australia was terra nullius because it was terra nullius after the fact. It was created that way by the government. One has to look at the way in which the British operated in their colonial domains. Everywhere they went, they sought treaties. That is why Malaysia, India, New Guinea, New Zealand, Fiji and North America are covered by treaties—treaties which have their own problems.

PARA.TAB: Clearly, instructions to Captain Phillip were to sign treaties with the inhabitants of Australia. The fact that he did not do so was because he could find no-one with whom to sign the treaties. I think it is the height of arrogance for the High Court to say that it, 200 years later, could have done better.

I think judges do have to consider their position. If judges take it upon themselves to dictate laws, they will find themselves increasingly becoming part of a political battle, in danger of being held in contempt by the public. If the public lose faith in our judicial system, they will be in danger of being defied and our stability as a nation will be threatened. In the end, it is in the best interests of the judges themselves to take their responsibilities to the majority of Australia seriously. That is what I am asking them to do—to consider their responsibility to the wider community.

If we take the example of the High Court Mabo judgment, we will see that the majority of justices put themselves above the general public instead of being responsible to it. There is talk about the common law being the vehicle for social justice. The common law of course was never such a vehicle. The common law was a body of law established for the good governance of society. As such, it is inappropriate to stand common law on its head. Common law should be an evolutionary thing, not a revolutionary thing. The High Court has decided to make it a revolutionary thing and upset 200 years of established practice.

What else might be said about judgments? Some of the language, particularly from Justices Gaudron and Deane, was highly emotive, including the phrase `unutterable shame' in respect of past treatment of Aboriginal people. By doing this, they symbolically separate themselves from that history and absolve themselves from the blame. They can see the shame so they are pure. People who can test their version are, by implication, part of the society and process which they condemn.

It is interesting that this unutterable shame does not prevent the justices drawing mammoth salaries and associated perks which would not be possible without the Aboriginal dispossession which so exercises their conscience. The Chief Justice receives $191,550 per year. Other justices receive substantial amounts too—$174,122 per annum, courtesy of the Australian taxpayer. Although the High Court sits in Canberra, only one justice lives there. The others jet in from other cities and are paid a Canberra allowance of $18,108 a year for their troubles. How much of their salaries and perks has each justice personally donated to Aboriginals? It must be nice to be able to parade a social conscience for such a lucrative return while society in general bears the consequence for this show of high mindedness, quite apart from the consequences—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I am listening very intently to what the honourable member has to say about the High Court and the judiciary, but I would refer him to standing order 75 and just caution him about some of the language that he may be tempted to use because of his concern for this issue.
—It is because of that standing order that I was being very restrained in my critique of the High Court. As your interruption has used up the time, I am happy to leave it there.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 5 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: Has the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner inquired into or reported on the activities of any State insurance or superannuation office or its subsidiaries extending beyond the limits of the State concerned; if so, (a) when were the inquiries first held and reports first made and (b) how frequently have inquiries been held and reports made.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: The Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner has not inquired into or reported on the activities of any State insurance of superannuation office or its subsidiaries extending beyond the limits of the State concerned.

Section 5(1) of the Insurance Act 1973 provides that the Act does not apply to State insurance whether or not extending beyond the limits of the State concerned. Section 8 of the Insurance (Agents and Brokers) Act 1984 and Section 9(2) of the Insurance Contracts Act 1984 provide that these Acts do not apply to State insurance.

Section 5(1) of the Life Insurance Act 1945 provides that the Act does apply to State insurance extending beyond the limits of the State concerned. Discussions were held with the Government Insurance Office of New South Wales (trading as GIO Australia) about writing business outside NSW. These discussions resulted in the GIO setting up a subsidiary company, GIO Life Limited, which was registered under the Life Insurance Act 1945 on 1 September 1988. The completed privatisation of GIO Australia led to all its life insurance business being transferred to GIO Life Limited. Extensive inquiries were made by the Commissioner into the general and life insurance operations of GIO Australia as part of the process associated with the authorisation and privatisation of that organisation.

The Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner's supervisory role with regard to superannuation is confined to the operations of superannuation funds wishing to be considered for relevant taxation concessions. The Insurance and Superannuation Commission currently has no authority to supervise the activities of a `superannuation office' whether it be a State or private sector entity, unless that entity comes under the life or general insurance legislation.

The Commissioner obtains, on a voluntary basis, statistical information from State general and life insurers. These statistics are published in `Selected Statistics on the General Insurance Industry' produced yearly by the General Insurance Group of the Insurance and Superannuation Commission, and in the `Quarterly Statistical Bulletin' produced by the Life Insurance Group of the Insurance and Superannuation Commission.
Parts (a) and (b) of this question do not apply.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 17 August 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Was the Commonwealth Bank's logo changed; if so, why.
(2) Was there any deficiency with the previous logo; if so, what was it.
(3) What improvement was achieved with the new logo.
(4) What was the total cost of changing logos.
(5) What advantage did the Commonwealth Bank gain by changing its logo.
(6) What is the meaning of the new logo and how is that meaning represented.
(7) What was the meaning of the old logo.
(8) Is he able to say whether there is a public perception that the logo is meaningless, a failure and a waste of money.

(9) Has the Commonwealth Bank conducted any surveys to determine the (a) extent of public acceptance and recognition and (b) success of the design of the new logo; if so, will he make the results available.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Commonwealth Bank of Australia (CBA) has furnished the following information concerning the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The bank changed its logo in September 1991 as part of a broader program to introduce a new "corporate identity" and to recognise a new corporate structure.
(2) The previous logo was designed in 1960 and research had suggested that it had become outdated and was putting the Bank at a competitive disadvantage.
(3) The new logo and corporate image have provided the Bank with a modern competitive image and have led to direct efficiency gains.
(4) Introducing the new logo and corporate image was a commercial decision made by the Bank and the associated cost is commercially sensitive.
(5) See answers 1, 2 & 3.

(6) Research showed the Bank's traditional yellow and black colours were very popular and well known. Accordingly, the focus of the identity program was to be a vehicle to display these colours to advantage.

The shape chosen has its origin in the stars of the southern cross and thus it is synonymous with Australia. The yellow portion of the design links the five points of the southern cross while the smaller black section completes the geometric form of the symbol.

(7) The old logo was a map of Australia surrounded by three circles and the words "Commonwealth Banking Corporation". The circles represented the Commonwealth Trading Bank of Australia, Commonwealth Savings Bank of Australia and Commonwealth Development Bank. The Commonwealth Banking Corporation and the Commonwealth Savings Bank no longer exist.

(8)&(9) Public and media response has been very favourable to the new logo and corporate identity, so much so that the Bank has not seen the need to verify this formally with market research. The Bank is confident that the new logo and corporate image are already among the most recognised in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 17 August 1993:

PARA.TAB: What was the import penetration ratio in each year since 1980-81, including an estimate for 1992-93.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: There are a number of alternative measures of the import penetration ratio. The measure favoured by the Australian Bureau of Statistics, however, is the `imports to sales ratio'. This represents the ratio of endogenous imports (imports of goods excluding fuel, certain large items of equipment and certain other government imports) to sales (defined as private final consumption expenditure on goods, plus private gross fixed capital expenditure on dwellings, non-dwelling construction and equipment, plus public gross fixed capital expenditure, plus exports of non-rural goods).
The following table provides current ABS estimates of this measure of the import penetration ratio for each year from 1980-81 to 1992-93.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 18 August 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to remarks by Mr Graham McMahon, Managing Director of Ansett, to a travel industry seminar in Queensland on 2 August 1993, (a) stating that the third runway at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport will not automatically fix delays at the airport and (b) suggesting that it will be necessary to change the route of aircraft over different suburbs, remove the curfew and move light aircraft operations.
(2) Will significant delays still occur at the airport.
(3) Will it be necessary to (a) change the route of aircraft over different suburbs and (b) remove the curfew to increase the number of flights handled by the airport.
(4) Will light aircraft operations be removed from the airport.
(5) Is he able to say whether the statement made by the Managing Director of Ansett is generally representative of the views of major air carriers using the airport.
(6) What steps will the Government take in response to Mr McMahon's suggestions.
(7) Will the Government accelerate the development of the Badgerys Creek airport.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport and Communications has supplied the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) I am aware of the remarks made by Mr McMahon.

(2) The new parallel runway will allow Sydney Airport to meet forecast demand into the next century efficiently and within acceptable limits of delay. It is expected that by the years 2005/2010 the new airport at Badgerys Creek will have been developed to a standard capable of accepting a significant proportion of airline traffic in the Sydney region.

The potential for any significant delays after the parallel runway becomes operational will be influenced by the scheduling practices of airline operators. The airlines' present practice of `cluster' scheduling is contributing to the delays currently being experienced. The airlines are currently examining the possibility of establishing a Schedule Co-ordination regime for Sydney.

(3)(a) There will be changes to flight paths when the parallel runway is opened. These were discussed in the EIS for the runway. In accordance with the Government's decision on the runway project, the new flight paths are now being refined in consultation with the local community as part of the Environmental Management Plan being prepared for operations with the new runway. There will be no departures to the north from the new parallel runway and the east-west runway will only be used when adverse weather conditions preclude use of the other runways for safety reasons. The result will be a marked reduction in the overall number of people seriously affected by aircraft noise.
(b) No. The Government is committed to retaining the curfew at Sydney Airport.
(4) No. Peak period pricing has been introduced at Sydney Airport to alleviate congestion and to increase the efficiency of use of airport facilities.

Partly in response to peak period pricing, the regional airlines in NSW have rationalised their services to and from Sydney Airport. For example, there has been a trend to the use of larger aircraft for regional services to Sydney. This has been made possible by regional airlines adopting `hub and spoke' type networks where small feeder aircraft concentrate traffic at major centres for on-carriage to Sydney by larger aircraft. Another development has been the adoption of `triangular' routes which serve more than one country centre.
As about 38% of passengers from regional carriers interlined with major carriers at Sydney in 1992/93, it makes sense to continue to cater for these operators.
In recent years the proportion of light aircraft movements at Sydney Airport has declined. With the exception of regional airlines, light aircraft comprised 9% of aircraft movements during 1992/93.
(5) As far as I know, no spokesperson for any other major air carrier using the airport has publicly expressed views which would corroborate the comments attributed to Mr McMahon.
(6) The Government's position on the suggestions made by Mr McMahon is reflected in my answers to questions (2), (3) and (4). No further action is proposed at this time.

(7) Construction of the initial general aviation airport at Badgerys Creek will commence later this year and the airport is expected to be operational in 1995. Subsequent stages of development will be in accordance with aviation demand and the commercial viability of further investment.

The Government recognises the importance of ensuring that potential opportunities for services to the new airport are not overlooked or unreasonably constrained. The Government therefore asked the FAC to examine the opportunities for the early commencement of international air freight services at Badgerys Creek and the viability of bringing forward subsequent stages of airport development to cater for these services.

The FAC's report on this issue is expected to be available shortly. The Government will then be in a position to consider the implications of advancing the rate of airport development at Badgerys Creek.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 1 September 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) What did the Insurance and Superannuation Commission spend on artwork for its annual reports for (a) 1991-92 and (b) 1992-93.
(2) What did the artwork comprise in each case and why was it considered necessary.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) (a) In 1991-92 the ISC spent $14,318.00 on artwork for its annual report.
(b) The 1992-93 annual report is not yet complete. The artwork budget for this year's report is $1,075.
(2) Artwork costs for the 1991-92 comprised:
Design advice
Design of front cover
Design of contents
Colour proofs
Laser proofs
Graph production
Imagesetting
Photo scans (financial statements and letters)
Production on bromide
The ISC commissioned a professional design company to undertake this artwork in an effort to improve the report.
Artwork costs for the 1992-93 will comprise:
Prepare organisation chart
Production on bromide
Artwork costs for the 1992-93 report will be considerably lower as:
experience gained last year will allow the ISC to move to in-house production; and
there will be greater use of free artwork services provided by the Australian Government Publishing Service.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 7 September 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Did the Minister announce on 29 June 1993 that there would be a review of funding of multicultural consultative mechanisms.
(2) Did the Minister say that he would ask the Office of Multicultural Affairs (OMA) to engage a consultant to conduct the review.

(3) Did the Minister further say that it was essential that all Australians, including those of non-English speaking background, were able to make their views on multicultural affairs known to government authoritatively and effectively.
(4) Were Yamine and Associates engaged to conduct the review.

(5) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to an article in the Sunday Telegraph of 5 September 1993 which reports that Mr Rick Yamine of Yamine and Associates had claimed that (a) the OMA had decided not to advertise for submissions to the review but to use a selective approach involving so-called stakeholders and (b) advertising would have resulted in more submissions than could be handled.
(6) Is it a fact that Yamine and Associates have adopted a framework for the review which effectively excludes most of the public.
(7) Did the Minister approve a process involving a selective approach; if so, how can this be reconciled with all Australians being given the opportunity to make their views known.

(8) Will the Minister insist that the opportunity to make submissions is advertised; if not, how will the Minister ensure that all Australians have the opportunity to make their views on multicultural affairs known authoritatively and effectively.

(9) Is Mr Yamine a member of the Federation of Ethnic Communities Councils of Australia or any other ethnically based group; if not, is the Minister able to say whether Mr Yamine has any connection with any ethnically based group.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes. My press release B18/93 stated, among other things, that:
"The Federal Government will review the funding and effectiveness of mechanisms for ensuring community input into Government policy and decision making. . . .
(2) Yes.

(3) Yes. It is important that people of non-English speaking backgrounds as well as people from English speaking backgrounds are able to make their views known to governments. The focus of this review is the effectiveness of the process by which the Commonwealth consults with the ethnic communities, in relation to all aspects of Federal policy and programs.

(6)-(8) The approach adopted is appropriate to the task and one which is adequate to ensure that the views of a range of interested groups, including major stakeholders, are gathered. The review is about the efficiency of consultation mechanisms used by the Government for seeking views of people from non-English speaking backgrounds on different aspects of Federal policies, and not about multiculturalism in general. The objective of the review obviously and naturally limits its scope and methodology used to meet this objective.

(9) Mr Yamine is not a member of FECCA. His contacts with the ethnic communities and his knowledge of multicultural affairs contribute to the skill mix required to successfully carry out the review. He has indicated that his other interests do not present any conflict of interests, in relation to his involvement in this consultancy.
